Disclaimer Statements / Disclosures
Estimated reading: 6 minutes
This section contains a library of
statements / disclosures
which must be said to customers during certain situations.
Social Security Number Disclosure
The SSN Disclosure statement must be read to the customer before you obtain the SSN.
Welcome to JEA.
JEA collections social security numbers from customers for the purposes of:
Opening credit accounts,
Evaluating customer creditworthiness and
For credit reporting as allowed by the Fair Credit Reporting Act and the Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act.
JEA is also governed by Florida Public Records law and only releases information in accordance with Florida Statute 119.071.
May I please have your Social Security Number?
Experian Credit/Identity Check Disclosure
The Credit Check Disclosure statement must be read to the customer before you run a credit check.
JEA determines if a deposit is required on your account based on your credit history.
With your permission, we can use your Social Security Number for a credit check to assess whether a deposit is required and for authentication purposes.
May I utilize your SSN to process the credit check?
May I have your previous address?
May I have your current address?
(address where the letter will be mailed)
Schedule Service Start Message
To make sure your services start on your request date of XX-XX-XXXX, you may pay your deposit today or any time before services are scheduled to start. Before you device when you want to pay, there are a few things to consider:
Half deposit: $XXX.XX
If you pay anytime between now and noon on the day services are scheduled to begin, the fee is $10 per service.
If you pay between noon and 3pm on your requested start date, the fee is $25 per service.
Any deposit paid after 3pm on the requested start date will delay starting service until the following business day and will have a $10 fee per service.
In the event you did not pay the full deposit amount on or before your requested start date, please call us back to reschedule your start date.
Pay Plan Terms & Conditions
We are extending your payment of $XXX.XX to be paid no later than XX-XX-XXXX.
If not paid, your services may be interrupted and the entire account balance will be required for reconnection.
Please be aware that this payment extension will not be shown on your bill.
Do you have any questions? [Allow customer to respond]
Payment Arrangement Terms & Conditions
Your Payment Arrangement in the amount of $XXX.XX has been broken up into XX monthly installments. The amount of each installment is $XX.XX. This amount along with your monthly usage will appear on your next bill, XXXX-XX-XX.
It is very important that you pay each month’s bill amount in full by the due date.
If you do not pay the full amount of your bill by the due date, this Payment Arrangement will be cancelled, your service will be scheduled for disconnection, and the full account balance becomes due.
While on a Payment Arrangement, your account is not eligible for any other payment extensions offered at JEA.
At any time, you may pay the full amount owed early.
If you do choose to pay the full balance early, please contact JEA for the amount needed to satisfy the Arrangement.
Do you have any questions about your Payment Agreement?
[Allow customer time to respond.]
MyWay General Overview
The JEA MyWay service is a pay-as-you-go option for utilities. You will be pre-paying for all services. There is no monthly statement and all notifications will be received by phone, text or email to keep you aware of your account status.
At any time there is an option to convert to traditional services. A payment of any unpaid balances and a full deposit may be required in order to do so.
With JEA MyWay you are in control of your account and able to pay as little or as much as you like, as long as a credit balance is maintained. Your account status and history can be viewed 24 hrs a day/7 days a week at myusage.com or on the app, JEA MyWay.
MyWay Medical Needs
Is there anyone residing in the home that will be on medical equipment powered by electricity?
If “yes”: JEA MyWay is not eligible for anyone who is medically dependent on electricity.
MyWay Starting Credit
To start, a minimum starting credit of $50 plus any applicable fees will be required.
The account will have a starting credit of $____ to go towards future consumption after connection fees are billed.
MyWay Deferred Balance
We are able to place a maximum of $750 in deferred billing. Once service begins, 35% of each payment will be allocated to this debt, until the balance is paid in full.
At this time we are placing $___ into deferred billing. Starting with your next payment, 35% of the amount paid will be allocated to this debt, until the balance is paid in full.
MyWay Alerts
All notifications will be received by phone, text, or email. How would you like to be notified? The MyWay service is run strictly on the alert system, so if you make any changes to your contact information, please log into myusage.com to update or contact JEA MyWay Customer Service to update, to ensure your alerts will continue.
Please be aware that standard text messaging rates will apply, according to your cellphone plan, for all alerts received (must say).
There are three different alert types that will be received. The first is a “Low Balance Threshold Alert.” The threshold defaults at $10, so no alerts will be received until your account credit balance is below $10. The second alert type is the “Pending Disconnection Alert.” This alert lets you know when your account has reached a 0 balance or has gone into the negative status. Once this alert is received, you have 24 hrs to make a payment, before your service is in danger of interruption. The final alert type is the “Disconnection Alert.” The disconnection alert lets you know your service has been interrupted for non-payment. Once service is interrupted, there will be a minimum payment required of $25 as a starting credit plus any unpaid usage to restore service.
MyWay MyUsage Account Setup and Password
With your MyWay account, you receive a Welcome Packet by email and have access to MyUsage.com and the JEA MyWay Mobile App. This website and mobile app allows you to view your account history and status. To login you will use your email address for the username. Your password will be the word PASSWORD (in ALL CAPS).
Are there any other questions you have regarding JEA MyWay service?

Appendix
Estimated reading: 7 minutes
Appendix Overview
There are various systems and additional tools commonly used by Customer Advisors. Within this page you will find a collection of supplementary resources that will help with assisting a customer.
Fidelity Express
When a customer makes a payment to JEA through a third party like a convenience store or grocery store, their payment may not post their JEA account immediately.  Unfortunately, occasional delays may prevent a payment from being posted to the customer’s account. If the customer paid through third party and the payment is not showing on the customer’s account, you will need to access Fidelity Express and search for the payment information
Click the image to enlarge.
How to Access Fidelity Express
Customer Advisors can access Fidelity Express via two methods:
Via Website URL
Via Edge Favorite
From your web browser (Chrome or Edge), type the URL:
www.fidelityexpress.com
into the search field in the upper left-hand side of the screen. Press
Enter
.
The link is also saved in the Favorites (three dots on the far right) in the
Customer Service
folder in the Microsoft Edge web browser.
Click the 3 Dots
Fidelity Express Favorite
The Grid
The Grid (
http://thegrid/
) is our internal website comprised of JEA related information that keeps us connected as a company and navigate our daily lives at JEA. It provides information about Benefits, Health and Wellness, Human Resources, News and Current Events, Internal Contact Information, and more.
How to Access The Grid
The Grid is the default homepage when you log in to any web browser (Google Chrome or Microsoft Edge) on a JEA computer.
Customer Experience Dropdown Menu
Pay Plan Enroll Button
Search The Grid
Sidebar
JEA.com
JEA.com (
https://www.jea.com/
) is a website geared towards our customers and others interested parties who need to locate general information about JEA’s services. JEA.com is a great way for customers to engage with us. The website uses responsive design to re-flow content according to the screen size for desktop, tablet, and mobile users. JEA customers can find general information such as rates, report an outage, manage their account, pay their bills, and start/stop/transfer services, among many other features.
JEA.com Favorites
In the table below you will find linked pages on JEA.com which are frequently accessed or needed by Customer Advisors or Customers. Click the link to visit the individual pages.
Page / Link
Description
Alerts
Customers can sign-up for free JEA account-related alerts such as when their bill is ready, bill is due, or when their usage has reached a certain dollar, electric (kWh), or water (gallon) amount.
Assistance
An overview page on bill-pay solutions and financial utility assistance options.
Bill Estimator
Looking to estimate the electric and water portions of an upcoming bill? Use our bill estimator.
Billing and Payment Options
An overview page on payment options, bill delivery options, and bill management options.
Boil Water Advisories (BWA)
A list of precautionary boil water advisories within the JEA service territory.
Commercial Forms and Policies
Commercial account forms such as adjustment forms and account-related policies.
Commercial Rebates
Rebates to encourage the use of efficient commercial equipment and to make upgrades more affordable for our customers.
Generator Safety
Preparation tips for using a portable generator, safety measures, and a link to register a standby generator.
Outage Center
Information on JEA service outages, both planned and unplanned.
Residential Forms and Policies
Residential account forms such as adjustment forms and account-related policies.
Residential Rebates
JEA offers rebates on home upgrades that help customers save money today and over time through lower utility costs.
Service Availability (Sages)
A cloud-based solution for electronic document submittals and plan reviews for new water or wastewater service.
Solar PV (Distributed Generation)
Customers who wish to purchase a renewable generation system and connect it to JEA’s grid must apply for Interconnection under the Distributed Generation Policy. This page contains the highlights, requirements, and links to forms that customers must complete.
SolartSmart
JEA SolarSmart gives all JEA’s residential and small- to medium- sized commercial customers an option to benefit from solar energy without having solar panels.
Streetlight Reporting Tool
Help keep our neighborhoods safe by reporting streetlights out. Use this page to report streetlight outages.
Notepad & WordPad
Using Notepad or WordPad is the preferred method at JEA for CAs to take notes when speaking to customers because:
A customer’s information is more secure than taking notes on paper.
The CA can save time by cutting and pasting their notes from the application into CCB (C2M).
It is eco-friendly.
IMPORTANT
The notes captured on Notepad or WordPad should
NEVER
be saved. Any notes that you type should be deleted after each interaction with the customer. Information typed in Notepad or WordPad
MUST
be deleted at the end of your shift.
How to Access Notepad/WordPad
Follow the steps below to access the Notepad or WordPad applications:
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
Click on the magnifying glass in the lower left-hand corner of the taskbar. Type
Notepad
or
WordPad
in the
Search Bar
to access the application.
Click the image to enlarge.
In the list of results that appear, click on the
Notepad
or
WordPad
icon.
Click the image to enlarge.
The application will open and you can begin to use NotePad or WordPad. There are two features that you will find useful. Please see the table below for instructions.
In order to resize the application …
Left click on your mouse and hold any corner of the application. Drag it until you reach the desired size.
Wrap the text …
NotePad:
Click on the
Format
menu button. Then, click
Word Wrap
.
WordPad:
Click on
View
in the top menu bar. Then, click on the
Word Wrap
drop down menu. Select
Wrap to Window of Wrap to Ruler
.
USPS.com
USPS.com
is the official website of the United States Postal Service. You will use this site to verify the customer’s mailing information every time you start, stop, or transfer a service, as well as when you add a mailing address that is different than the service address.
How to Verify an Address on USPS.com
Follow the steps below to verify an address on USPS.com:
Step 1
Step 2

Quick Tools

Click on Quick Tools

Look Up a Zip Code

Find by Address

If the address you entered is correct …
The site will display the full address with standard abbreviations and formatting. In most cases, the extended zip code will also be included.
Result
Review the address.
Always
use the address displayed in the bottom half of the address results. The first address displayed is the is the one that you entered in the search.  Notice the difference between the way the address was entered initially, and the proper formatting required by USPS.
If the address you entered is incorrect …
You will receive the following error message:
Error

Cisco Finesse Desktop
Estimated reading: 4 minutes
Cisco Finesse Desktop is the phone system used throughout JEA to interact with our customers. Additionally, Finesse provides robust data that captures information about your activities which is used to measure your performance.
The following information will help you use this application to manage your calls and daily activities.
Launching & Logging In
The following steps will walk you through launching and logging into the Cisco Finesse Desktop.
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
On your desktop, click on the
Cisco Finesse
icon. The Finesse Desktop and a CCB window will open.
Enter your 4+2 and extension.
Click the
Sign In
button, the Finesse Desktop will open into a
Not Ready
status.
To change your status to
Ready
:
Click the drop-down arrow next to your current state.
Select the
Ready
state.
You are now logged in and ready to take customer calls.
Agent Status
The Agent Status defaults to
Not Ready
upon logging in. You must go to
Ready
to accept calls from customers. The other Not Ready statuses can be used for their appropriate reasons such as the following.
Logout Signout
Break
Call Block
Coaching
Call Block
Lunch
Personal
Meeting
Safety Meeting
Technical
Training
The
Wrap-Up
status is not available until you are talking on a call. Wrap-Up can be preselected during the call & will allow you to finish your work and prepare for the next call.
Wrap-Up Status
Receiving an Inbound Call & Making an Outbound Call
When receiving an inbound call from a customer, a new CCB tab will “pop” open so that you may access the customers information. If the customer verifies their account through the IVR, the CCB tab will open with the customers account loaded, ready for you to access their account.
To make an outbound call, you must be in a
Not Ready
status. The
Make a New Call
button will appear.

Dial-Pad

Name
.
Search Field

Direct (Cold Transfer)
Consult (Warm Transfer)

button.

Outage Map Tab

Assist Line & Escalations
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
Customer Advisors should take ownership of the call and use all available resources to ensure the customer’s issue is resolved. If you need assistance during a call, you may contact the Assist Line or a Manager.
Contacting the Assist Line
Use the following steps to contact the Assist Line:
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
Step 4
Step 5
Ask the customer to hold:
May I place you on hold for 2-3 minutes while I research this?
In Cisco Finesse, click the
Consult
button to open the dial-pad.
Dial
2520 (Assist Line)
and click the
Call
button.
The customer will be automatically placed in a hold status with music; you will be in the Asssist Line queue.
If you are able to reach someone …
Provide the customer’s account number and the situation while the customer is on hold.
Proceed to the next step.
If you are unable to reach someone after 90 seconds …
Advise the customer that you will need a little more time to research their issue, obtain a contact phone number, and call them back as soon as you get assistance.
After you consult with the Assist Line, in Cisco Finesse you can choose to
End
the new call,
Retrieve
the customer on hold,
Conference
in the customer, or
Transfer
the call.
If the Assist Line would like to speak to the customer, introduce the parties when the call is conferenced together.
When you return from the call, you should state:
Mr./Mrs. __________, think you for holding. I have researched your account and…”
Handling an Escalation Call
In the event that a customer requests to speak to a supervisor, we should always attempt to deescalate; if the caller still requests a manager, follow the steps below:
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
Step 4
Step 5
Ask the customer to hold:
May I place you on hold for 2-3 minutes while I locate one of my supervisors?
In Cisco Finesse, click the
Consult
button to open the dial-pad.
Dial
2520 (Assist/Escalations Line)
and click the
Call
button.
The customer will be automatically placed in a hold status with music; you will be in the Escalations queue.
If you are able to reach someone …
Provide the customer’s account number and the situation while the customer is on hold.
Proceed to the next step.
If you are unable to reach someone after 90 seconds …
Click the 2nd
End
icon to disconnect from the escalations queue.
Apologize to the customer and advise the customer that all of the supervisors are with customers and that a callback will be necessary.
Create an
Escalations to Mangement
case; inform the caller that someone will call them back:
If the case is submitted prior to 2PM, a callback will be made later the same-day.
If the case is submitted after 2PM, a callback will be made before noon on the next business day.
Click the
Conference
button to join the customer withe Escalations line; the two lines will be joined.
Click
End
to leave the conference call.

Handling Call Types (Threats, Employee & Abusive Calls)
Estimated reading: 6 minutes
There are various call types that Customer Advisors will encounter. This section details how to handle these various call types and any actions that should follow.
Handling Customer Threats (Emergency Notification)
The actions that you take when observing a threat by a customer depends on if the threat was received by phone/email or in-person; the actions that you take are determined by our
Emergency Notification Process
. Click the tabs below to review the steps to take when a threat is received.
Threat by Phone
Threat by Email
In-Person Threat (Call Center)
In-Person Threat (CSC, RA, Pre–Service)
Customer Advisors should:
Place yourself in
Meeting
status in Cisco Finesse.
Document the direct quote of the threat, and if applicable customer information.
Information to collect includes their name, address, and phone number
Note the time of the call or estimate “call was in the last
X
minutes”.
Call JEA Security at (904) 665-6200
.
Notify your Manager or a Manager on duty.
Notify Workforce via email (
adhexcreq@jea.com
) that a threat was received and that you are in
Meeting
status.
Remain in
Meeting
status.
Answer calls that may be from an unknown number for the next 30 minutes.
Managers should:
Check-in with the Customer Advisor:
Are you ok? Are you safe? How can I help?
Verify threat incident information.
Review or “pull” the call via Impact 360 to identify the exact time of the call and verbiage in the threat. (Calls are usually available to retrieve 30 minutes after.)
Create an email using the Outlook group created for threat alerts (
threatalerts@jea.com
) and include the customer’s information, attach the recorded call, and include your contact number.
Click here for the full Emergency Alert Process via PolicyTech
Customer Advisors should:
Place yourself in
Meeting
status in Cisco Finesse.
Preserve the written threat.
Call JEA Security at (904) 665-6200
.
Notify your Manager or a Manager on duty.
Notify Workforce via email (
adhexcreq@jea.com
) that a threat was received and that you are in
Meeting
status.
Remain in
Meeting
status.
Answer calls that may be from an unknown number for the next 30 minutes.
Managers should:
Check-in with the Customer Advisor:
Are you ok? Are you safe? How can I help?
Verify threat incident information.
Review the threat email.
Create an email using the Outlook group created for threat alerts (
threatalerts@jea.com
) and include the customer’s information, attach the email with the threat, and include your contact number.
Click here for the full Emergency Alert Process via PolicyTech
Customer Advisors should:
Remove yourself to a safe location;
if an imminent threat exists, call 9-1-1
.
Document the direct quote of the threat and a description of the persons(s) making the threat.
Call JEA Security at (904) 665-6200
.
Repeat the exact words used in the threat.
Provide pertinent information such as description of the person(s), and, if applicable, the customer’s name and address.
Remain in a safe location.
When safe to do so, notify your Manager or a Manager on duty.
Remain available to leadership, security, and law enforcement.
Wait for the “All Clear” by security.
Managers should:
Check-in with the Customer Advisor:
Are you ok? Are you safe? How can I help?
Verify threat incident information.
Create an email using the Outlook group created for threat alerts (
threatalerts@jea.com
) and include the customer’s information, attach the recorded call, and include your contact number.
Click here for the full Emergency Alert Process via PolicyTech
Customer Advisors should:
Activate the duress button
Secure drawer, if applicable to your position
Notify coworkers and remove yourself to a safe location;
if an imminent threat exists, call 9-1-1
.
Announce the code word that indicates that a threat occurred.
Remember the exact words used in the threat.
Call JEA Security at (904) 665-6200
.
Repeat the exact words used in the threat.
Provide pertinent information such as description of the person(s), and, if applicable, the customer’s name and address.
Remain in a safe location.
When safe to do so, contact the Customer Solutions Center/Revenue Assurance Specialist, Group Leader, or Manager to report the incident.
Remain available to leadership, security, and law enforcement.
Wait for the “All Clear” by security.
Managers should:
Make contact with the employee(s) to ensure their safety:
Are you ok? Are you safe? How can I help?
Obtain the customer’s information/description of the person(s) and details of the incident.
Create an email using the Outlook group created for threat alerts (
threatalerts@jea.com
) and include the customer’s information, attach the recorded call, and include your contact number.
Click here for the full Emergency Alert Process via PolicyTech
Handling Employee or Known-Caller Calls
Call center employees are authorized to make any changes needed or actions requested on a JEA employees account or a known-caller that fall within JEA policy.
Examples of changes that fall within JEA policy include:
Starting, Stopping or Transferring services
Using the Pay Plan or Payment Arrangement Validator to get approval for the PP or PA
Anything else that falls within standard JEA policy
Handling an Abusive Call
Abusive language is defined as directing derogatory or attacking statements to you as a person. It does not include directing derogatory or negative statements towards JEA. If, during a phone interaction, a customer uses vulgar, profane, or abusive language, the following steps should be taken by the CA:
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
Step 4
Advise the customer in a professional and calm tone that their language is not professional, and in order to assist them, the call should remain professional. Explain that you are here to assist them.
If the customer’s abusive language continues or intensifies, remind the customer that the call must be kept on a professional level or the call will have to end.
If the customer’s abusive language continues, remind the customer that you cannot assist them if the abusive language continues.
Example statement:
Unfortunately since you have not honored my request to keep this professional, I will have to end the call. **Pause for five seconds to see if they calm down.** I am now ending this call due to abusive language.
IMPORTANT
It is not acceptable to release the customer until these steps have been followed.
Create a Customer Contact noting the interaction and the reason the call was released. Do not include the actual language used and do not include any derogatory remarks about the customer.

Creating a Help Desk Ticket for an Adherence Adjustment
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
For Residential, CART, BSC, and CSC Customer Advisors Only:
When a technical issue hinders a Customer Advisor from performing their duties and they require an adherence exception, such as laptop, phone, or system issues, Customer Advisors will be required to obtain a Help Desk incident ticket number before contacting the SICK line. This process will help us accurately identify technical issues and the impact on operations.
MUST FIRST
create a ticket (
Incident Record
) via the JEA Service Portal.
If your system issue prevents you from creating a ticket online, please call the Help Desk (dial HELP).
AND THEN
call the SICK line at (904) 665-SICK, leaving the
Incident Record
number in the voice message, along with the details of their issue.
If you were able to resolve your own issue (a reboot for example), but still need an adherence adjustment, include a statement that the issue has been resolved when describing your issue during ticket creation. This will enable TS to close the ticket without contacting you.
Follow the steps below to create an

and then call the SICK line for an adherence adjustment:

Personally Identifiable Information (PII)
Estimated reading: 5 minutes
Personally Identifiable Information (PII) is information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, either alone or when combined with other personal or identifying information that is linked or linkable to a specific individual. Such as information associated with the Fair and Accurate Credit transactions Act (FACTA) and the Health Information Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) i.e., name, account number, address, telephone number, social security number, date of birth, driver’s license number, etc.
Sensitive Information
Data that is not legally protected, but should not be made public and should only be disclosed under limited circumstances. Users must be granted specific authorization to access since the data’s unauthorized disclosure, alteration, or destruction may cause perceivable damage to the company.
Disclosure of Public Information
Account Holders, Authorized, and Unauthorized Callers who inquire about Public Information may receive it upon request. CAs will provide publicly available information by responding to the caller’s specific questions. If the person inquiring refuses to identify him/herself, the CA will document the account record as “unknown caller.” CAs may not ask probing questions to identify the caller. Refer to the Account Information Inquiries document for more information.
Disclosure of Sensitive or Protected Information
Unauthorized Callers who request Sensitive or Protected Information must be referred to JEA’s Public Records Department. Account Holders or Authorized Users who request Sensitive or Protected Information may, in limited cases, receive assistance by the CA. Refer to the Account Information Inquiries document for more information.
How Does JEA Protect PII?
JEA ensures that we are in compliance with protecting customer PII as required by FACTA, FCRA and FIPA by:
Policies & Procedures
–
provide an overview of the program and guidelines to follow to identify and prevent identity theft.
Training – provides JEA employees and agents with the knowledge to identify and prevent identity theft.
An annual report is provided by Compliance to the Compliance Oversight Committee.  The report summarizes the incidents of identity theft and suggests changes to strengthen the program.
JEA updates the Identity Theft program annually to ensure the program keeps pace with the changing world of identity theft.
The Compliance Oversight Committee provides oversight for the program.
FACTA
stand for the Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act which was established in 2003. (Also known as the FACT Act).
It is a federal consumer-rights law intended to lower risk of identity theft.
FACTA requires organizations to develop and implement an identity theft prevention program.
FCRA
stands for the Fair Credit Reporting Act which was enacted in 1970.
It is a federal consumer-rights law that promotes the accuracy, fairness, and privacy of consumer information contained in the files of consumer reporting agencies.
FCRA protects consumers from the willful and/or negligent inclusion of inaccurate information in their credit reports. FCRA regulates the collection, dissemination, and use of consumer information, including consumer credit information.
FIPA
stands for Florida Information Protection Act which was enacted in 2014.
The Florida Information Protection Act expands Data Breach notification requirements for covered entities that acquire, maintain, store or use personal information of Floridians.
It contains reactive and proactive components for protecting personal information in electronic format. All entities in the state of Florida are required to comply with FIPA regulations.
Publicly Releasable Information
The procedures for account inquiries allows CAs to provide callers with public information. CAs will provide publicly available information by responding to the caller’s specific questions. If the person inquiring refuses to identify him/herself, the CA will document in the account record as “unknown caller.” CAs will not ask probing questions to identify the caller.

Handling Call Types (Not Responding, Outbound & Transfer Calls)
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
There are various call types that Customer Advisors will encounter. This section details how to handle these various call types and any actions that should follow.
Caller Not Responding or On Hold
Upon answering or ending a call, the caller does not respond, but the line is connected. Effort should be made to get the attention of the person on the line.
Say the following to the caller:
[Caller/Customer Name if known] if you can hear me, I cannot hear you. Should you need further assistance, please call us back at 665-6000. Thank you for calling JEA, I am releasing the line at this time.
When a customer places you on hold, advise them due to call volume you are able to hold for up to 2 minutes.
If you have to release the caller, notate the account that the call was released due to excessive hold time.
Say the following to the caller:
[Caller/Customer Name if known] the timeframe for which I am able to hold has expired. The caller has abandoned the line and I will be releasing the call.
Handling an Outbound Call
Every outbound call from a recorded line is required to provide a disclaimer advising the call could be recorded for quality purposes. Even if the caller was unexpectedly disconnected and you are calling them back, you will need to advise them that the call may be recorded. Each party that you speak to must be given this disclaimer. For example, if you speak with one person and they pass the call to someone else, you will need to provide the disclaimer again to obtain their consent. Calls that are intercepted by an answering machine or voicemail do not need the disclaimer provided.
Say the following to the caller:
Hello, this is [Your Name] from JEA. I want to let you know this call is recorded for quality monitoring purposes. May I please speak with [Customer Name]? I’m calling about [Reason].
Handling a Call Transfer
When transferring the customer to the IVR you are to release the line/cold transfer the customer.
Always “warm transfer” and introduce the customer and other party by name. When transferring the caller to another department or employee, release the line as soon as your services are no longer needed.
When transferring a call outside of JEA, provide the phone number you are transferring the customer to in case they get disconnected. Transfer the call and drop off of the line.
IMPORTANT
Employees cannot accept any bank account information or credit/debit card payment information from the customer. This information is required to be entered into the IVR system or on JEA.com by the customer. If you are transferring the call to the IVR for the customer to make payment, you cannot remain on the line while the customer submits their payment.

Kiosk Check Processing (CSC)
Estimated reading: 4 minutes
To address day-to-day operational handling of customer check payments made through the Customer Solutions Center (CSC) lobby kiosk. Addresses proper presentation of a physical kiosk check to JEA’s bank when the check to JEA has an anomalous characteristic. Examples of anomalous characteristics are physical checks that are unsigned by the customer, or a numeric dollar amount is not synonymous with the dollar amount written on the check. Also addresses returned payment handling.
Daily Operational Check Handling Process
Lobby payment kiosks will accept personal checks, business checks, money orders and cashier’s checks.
As the customer presents a check to the kiosk for payment, the kiosk will retain the check. The kiosk will also make a digital image of the front of the check as it is presented to the kiosk. The digital image is stored within the transactional record kept within the Adcomp Systems payment transaction portal.
At the end of the business day, a designated Customer Advisor or Advisors will collect the physical checks from the kiosks and take them to the balancing room. Each of the checks are validated against the information captured within the Adcomp Systems portal. The checks are visually scanned by the Analyst to ensure that the check is endorsed by the customer and that the numeric dollar amount of the check matches the handwritten amount on the check.
Inside the portal, the checks are validated by checking a box for each check transaction for that day.
Established end-of-day check preparation guidelines for the CSC are to be followed, with the checks from the kiosk being kept and bagged separate from any check payments collected at the counter during the day.
The armored car picks up the checks the next day for delivery to the bank.
RETURNED PAYMENTS
Upon being notified via the daily Wells Fargo Payment Return report, RCS will cancel the payment from CC&B, and mail a returned payment notice letter to the customer. There will be no further action required by the CSC.
Unsigned Checks
Checks that are unsigned by a customer should not be validated or presented to the JEA bank, as they will not be honored.
Unsigned physical checks are to be retained by the CSC within the vault room for a period of 10 calendar days, and should be mailed back to the customer by RCS once those 10 days have been exhausted.
A case entitled “Kiosk Check Errors” has been created for use by the CRC employees to notify Desiree Carnes that the customer didn’t sign their check.
The case will also be used to notify RCS that the physical check must be mailed back to the customer after the 10-day hold.
Cathy or Desiree will call the customer to advise that they either need to bring another check to the CBO for submission, or fill out the necessary information on the check that we have in-hand.
Once the check payment requirement has been satisfied, it may then be presented to the bank.
Check Amount to Be Verified
Wells Fargo uses the LAR or written amount on the check, not the CAR (courtesy amount recognition) to determine the correct amount of the check payment.
Checks that have an LAR that does not match the CAR (numeric amount) will still be honored by the bank and may be submitted to the bank using the amount as indicated by the LAR.
Checks that have a
blank
LAR should not be validated or presented to the JEA bank, as they will not be honored.
Physical checks without an LAR are to be retained by the CSC within the vault room for a period of 10 calendar days, and should be mailed back to the customer by RCS once those 10 days have been exhausted.
A case entitled “Kiosk Check Errors” has been created for use by the CRC employees to notify Desiree Carnes that the customer didn’t complete the LAR (legal amount recognition) line on the check.
The case will also be used to notify RCS that the physical check must be mailed back to the customer after the 10-day hold.
Cathy or Desiree will call the customer to advise that they either need to bring another check to the CBO for submission, or fill out the necessary information on the check that we have in-hand.
Once the customer has been contacted, Cathy or Desiree will send an email to the Customer Solutions Center Manager, and the Assigned CAIV employees within the area, so that they may be informed of the customer’s intended actions to address/resolve the check issue.
Once the check payment requirement has been satisfied, it may then be presented to the bank.

Neighborhood Energy Efficiency (NEE) Program
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
The JEA Neighborhood Energy Efficiency Program is available to assist customers in making energy and water efficiency upgrades in their homes. These customers live on low or fixed incomes in disadvantaged neighborhoods as designated by the U.S. Census Bureau.
JEA sends the Neighborhood Energy Efficiency (NEE) crew to designated neighborhoods to install energy-saving products which will help lower their utility bills, as well as give tips on how to manage electric and water usage.
The NEE crew will install the following products in designated homes to help improve energy and water efficiency and lower utility bills.
LED night lights
Low flow shower head(s)
Faucet aerators
Toilet flapper(s)
AC filters
Exterior door weather stripping
Caulking
In some cases, the Neighborhood Energy Efficiency Program may also install attic insulation free of charge. For a home to qualify for attic insulation, it must have less than three inches of insulation. In addition, JEA will review the customer’s consumption history to see if it meets a high winter peak criteria.
NEE Eligibility
Eligible homes are automatically identified. Once a neighborhood has been identified, all residents will receive postcards explaining the NEE program and when to expect NEE crews in their neighborhood. Customer Advisors can confirm if a customer lives in an eligible neighborhood by referencing the CensusTract map.
Click the map image to access the expanded map.
When the map opens, type the customer’s address in the upper right-hand corner.
If the address is in an eligible neighborhood, the background will be colored. If the address is not in an eligible area, the background will be grey/have no color.
If the customer is in an eligible area, their name, address and phone number can be emailed to Cliff Ford, NEE Foreman at
cford@franklinenergy.com
. They will verify the address has not been served and then call the customer to confirm the eligibility and set up an appointment.
Customers who are not in an eligible area for the NEE program may contact the Northeast Florida Community Action Agency Weatherization Program at 904-398-7472, ext. 204. to inquire if they may be eligible for assistance.
JEA’s internal contact for the NEE program is Susan Pokorny, Program Manager, at (904)703-3289 or
pokosg@jea.com
.

Senior Day at JEA
Estimated reading: 1 minute
Senior Day at JEA was created in 2015 by community partners to point seniors in need to resources for direct utility bill assistance and indirect ways to save money.
The event made a comeback from the COVID pandemic in April 2024 and is scheduled every third Wednesday of the month from 9 am to 3 pm (excluding holidays).
JEA is host to Senior Day at JEA in the JEA Headquarter lobby, located at 225 N. Pearl St. in Downtown Jacksonville. Validated parking is available at the Duval County Courthouse Garage.
A Senior Resource Fair is open to the public. The Senior Resource Fair is made up of agency partners that offer indirect solutions in ways to save money.
Local agencies meet with seniors that have secured a pre-scheduled appointment for potential utility bill assistance. Appointments are limited, based on agency capacity and funding availability. Eligibility for assistance is determined by each agency.

Monthly Quality Assurance Most Missed Opportunities

Monthly Quality Assurance Most Missed Opportunities
Estimated reading: 9 minutes
September 2023
The most missed opportunities as observed during Quality Assurance monitoring process for June 2023 were:
Account Security Verification
Following Hold Procedures
Help Statement
Offering Alternatives/Options Where Appropriate
Call Closing
Account Security Verification
What do I need to do before verifying the account?
First, ask the caller for their name:
May I have your name please?
Access the account to determine if the caller is:
The Account Holder
An Authorized User or Spouse
or an Unknown Caller
If the caller is an Account Holder or Authorized User/Spouse, continue with the verification process.
How do I properly verify an account?
Once you access the account the following information must be asked and/or verified:
The person calling must be the account holder or an Authorized User/Spouse listed on the account in order to make changes.
If the person calling is not listed or cannot verify their information, then no changes can be made to the account. All account information can still be shared with the caller based on PII.
Some examples:
For security purposes, may I have…
For verification purposes, may I have…
For identification purposes, may I have…
MUST BE ASKED/VERIFIED:
The caller’s First and Last name
The Account Holders name, if different from the caller
The last 4 digits of the Social Security Number
Or Passport/Drivers License number if previously approved by Revenue Assurance
Date of Birth
Telephone Number
Email Address
Password (if applicable)
REMEMBER
The caller still has to be listed on the account before changes can be made to the account.
If a password is assigned to an account, the account will be considered to be verified if the caller can provide that assigned password. You will not need to also ask the caller for their DOB and SSN to satisfy the verification requirement.
If the number the customer is calling from matches the number listed on the JEA account then the ANI can be used as a secondary identifier, to replace the DOB or the last 4 of the SSN.
Following Hold Procedures
What is the 30-second hold process? (Soft Hold)
If you need to process or research something that will take 30-seconds or less, you do not need to place the caller on hold.
You need to inform the customer that you need a moment to review the account or perform the request. For example,
It will be just a moment while I review your account.
What is the hard hold process?
When it is determined that you need more than 30-seconds to complete a request, or connect with another department, you will need to place the customer on a hard hold.
Inform the customer:
I will need to place the call on hold while I review the account, connect with another department, or research their request. This will take me about 2-3 minutes. Will you mind holding for this timeframe?
You must receive an answer from the customer before proceeding. If they decline the hold, you may offer to call the customer back.
Help Statement
When should I use a Help Statement?
The
Help Statement
is provided to confirm that you can help the customer.
You must use a Help Statement:
Once the caller states the reason for their call.
What are examples of a Help Statement?
I’d be happy to help you with starting your services.
I’d be happy to help you.
I can help you with that.
Sure, I can do that for you.
Offering Alternatives/Options Where Appropriate
What is an example of when alternatives or options can be offered? (Example 1)
A customer wants to start, stop, or transfer services and is complaining about call hold times.
Solution:
Recommend that the customer access JEA.com to start, stop, or transfer thir service.
What is an example of when alternatives or options can be offered? (Example 2)
A customer did not receive their paper bill, feels that delivery is too late, or is simply inquiring about their balance.
Solution:
Recommend that the customer can view their bill on JEA.com, offer eBill, or utilizes JEA.com to sign-up for automatic bill or usage alerts.
What is an example of when alternatives or options can be offered? (Example 3)
A customer’s account is
Cash Only
.
Solution:
Inform the customer that
Cash Only
customers cannot pay with a debit card or ACH payment; aside from secured payments such as money order or cashier’s check, they can only pay via cash or with a credit card.
You can offer acceptable payment locations to the customer.
Call Closing
What is included with the Call Closing?
A complete Call Closing includes the following:
Using the caller’s name.
Offering additional assistance.
Branding JEA in the closing.
Creating a
Customer Contact
.

Verify/Update Phone Number & Email Address
When must I verify and update a customer’s phone number & email address?
You must verify the caller’s phone number and email address for every call, except if:
There is a documented Customer Contact from a residential call center Customer Advisor within the past 30-days.
The caller is not the account holder or authorized user/spouse.
Can I verify every caller’s phone number and email address, regardless of the 30-day rule?
Yes, it is perfectly acceptable to verify every caller’s phone and email address, regardless of the timeframe.

Took the Correct Action to Resolve the Customer’s Issue
What are the most common incorrect/incomplete actions?
For the months of June-September 2023, the most common incorrect/incomplete actions were:
Not stopping the Deposit Service Agreement when stopping all services.
Not using the script to start, stop, transfer service, or update account information; also, not using the script to add an authorized/user or spouse, which includes request the full social security number from the person.
Inform the customer that you took an action on the account, but did not; for example, informed the customer that you were creating a Water Smart Check, but failed to create the FA.

Account Name Change (BSC)
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
Account Name Change Overview
There are times when the name on a commercial account has to be changed. It could be due to a Legal Name Change or Corporate Merger. It also may be due to the name being spelled incorrectly. When changing a name on an account, documentation of the change is required. Legal Name Changes and Corporate Mergers can usually be verified on Sunbiz.org. If unable to verify the name change, the customer will need to send us a copy of the legal documents related to the change or merger. If you question whether or not the change can be made, please reach out to BSC Assist.
NOTE
When you change a name on an account, email BSC Assist (
bscassist@jea.com
) to advise.

Account Creation (BSC)
Estimated reading: 5 minutes
New Commercial Account Creation in a Business Name
The Script can be used to create a new commercial account, but there may be times when you need to manually create the account using CCB.
NOTE
If the business is filed as a
Fictitious Name
the account should be established under the person’s name.
Using the Script to Create the Account
Use the following steps to use the Script to create an account:
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
Step 4

Click the
Start Process
link from the CCB Dashboard.
Enter the Business Name. Check to make sure there is not already an account established for the entity by hitting Inside Enter. Click NEW ACCOUNT.
Click Go to Sunbiz.org to search for the entity. A new tab for sunbiz will populate. Click on the name of the entity.
Verify that the entity is
Active.
Proceed with creating the account via the Script by clicking the
Control Central
tab in your browser.
Enter the FEI/EIN.
In the W9 or SS4 IS required field select NO if you were able to verify the Tax Id number on sunbiz.
Select YES if the customer needs to submit a W9 or copy of the SS4 IRS Letter.
Click on the Pencil Icon to add Agent of Record.
Enter the names, click the arrow, then click Done.
Enter the rest of the required account information. The Password on a commercial account is Optional. Click Continue.
Click Continue on the New Account Review Screen.
The next screen in the Script pertains to Tax Exemptions. It is not necessary to read through each of the lines to the customer. You can ask the customer if they have any Tax Exemptions and based on their answer you would select the appropriate box and click Continue. This will notify the JEA Tax Department to contact the customer via email regarding the exemptions. The most common that we encounter is for Religious Entity. If the customer has no Tax Exemptions make no selection and click continue.
Procced to the Premise Validation Screen. Quote the deposit. Schedule the start (If applicable), Continue to the end of the Script, enter your comments and complete the account creation.
IMPORTANT
Do not use Scheduled Start for customers starting more than one premise.
Do not use Scheduled Start for any premise that has flags on it.

Follow the same steps as above for account creation using the Person’s Name, Social Security Number and Date of Birth.
Remember to read the Florida Statute.
Conduct the Identity Check in Experian.

Commercial Deposits (BSC)
Estimated reading: 8 minutes
Commercial Account Deposits
Commercial Account Deposits are rounded up to the next 10th. Ex: If deposit calculates at $247.33 the correct deposit amount will be $250.00. On new accounts, Deposits should be paid in advance prior to the start of service.
Government Accounts
New Commercial Account
Residential Service Points
Commercial Service Points
Existing Government Accounts
Existing Commercial Account
No Deposit is required
Deposit is required.
Property Management Starting Service: If the property will be vacant while in the company’s name, the minimum deposit applies. If tenant occupied while in the company’s name the deposit is calculated using Premise Validator or Deposit Lock. When using the Premise Validator to calculate the deposit, click the “Check Deposit” button to view the monthly billing history and ensure that all SPs to quote are selected.
Tenant Starting Service:
When using the Premise Validator to calculate the deposit, click the “Check Deposit” button to view the monthly billing history and ensure that all SPs to quote are selected.
Owner Starting Service:
The deposit amounts will vary on Commercial SPs depending on the size of service. It is best to use the Premise Validator to calculate the deposit or manually calculate it based on 2 times the average bill for the service(s). If a deposit is large and the owner states that it will be vacant while under their account, check with BSC Assist (Beth, Jamie or Nikki) to see if the amount can be lowered.
No Deposit is required.
Deposit Requirements:
Property Management/ Landlord/ CAB Accounts Starting Residential Service:
Most existing CAB accounts such as apartment complexes have sufficient deposit on hand or a bond on file to reactivate a residential SP under their account. It is still a good practice to verify the deposit on hand or bond amount prior to start. If the deposit is not sufficient to cover two times their average bill, then a deposit increase will apply when starting service. If a deposit increase is required, the minimum deposit will apply for a vacant residential property. If tenant occupied while in company name use Premise Validator or Deposit Lock to calculate. If the ICS on the account is 850 or higher and there has been at least 1 bill and 1 bill payment on the account, the deposit increase can be billed. If the ICS is below 850, the deposit will need to be paid in advance prior to activation.
**For start requests under existing accounts for Builders such as DR Horton, Lennar Homes, ICI, Weekley Homes etc, no deposit increases are assessed. See existing commercial account with no deposit below.
CBS Account -Landlord Starting Commercial Service:
Most existing CBS accounts have sufficient deposit or bond to re-activate a commercial SP under their account. It is a good practice to verify the deposit on hand or bond amount prior to start. If the deposit is not sufficient to cover two times their average bill, then a deposit increase will apply when starting additional commercial service. If the ICS on the account is 850 or higher, the increase can be billed if it is less than $1000.00. If the ICS on the account is lower than 850 the deposit will need to be paid prior to the start.
Existing Commercial Accounts With No Deposit:
Some older commercial accounts do not have a deposit on them. If a commercial account has an ICS of 850 or higher and the account has been active for 10 years or more, the customer can start Residential SPs on the account with no deposit increase. If wanting to start a Commercial SP, a deposit will be required even for accounts with ICS of 850 or higher. If the account qualifies, we can offer the Auto Pay Pilot as an option for the deposit to be waived. If the account has an ICS below 850 a deposit increase will be required to start residential and/or commercial SPs. If the account qualifies, we can offer the Auto Pay Pilot as an option for the deposit to be waived.
Short Comment Tips
Check for Short Comments on Control Central Main Screen when you pull up an account. Most of the Property Management accounts will have a Short Comment that indicates what two times the bill is and how much deposit is on hand. In the screenshot below, the account has sufficient deposit for adding additional services.
Click the image to enlarge.
Adding a Deposit Increase On An Account
To add a Deposit Increase on an account, go to the Deposit SA. The quickest way to get there is click on the deposit link in the Alerts section of the Dashboard in CCB.
Click the image to enlarge.
In the
Total Amount To Bill
field, add the deposit increase to the amount shown and click Save in the upper right-hand corner of CCB. In this example, if we were adding a $300.00 Deposit Increase to the account, we would change the amount from $4,960.00 to $5,260.00.
Click the image to enlarge.
Deposit Tracking
Many of the Property Management customers request a breakdown of Deposit Increases billed to their account. While JEA does not attach a separate deposit to each address, as a courtesy we keep a log (on some accounts) of the Premise(s) started and the increase amount. This is found in the Refer Only Case. If you have added a deposit increase to one of these accounts, from the CCB Dashboard, click the REFER CUST ONLY T link to go to the case. Click on the pencil by the Comment section. Update the case with the required details and click OK. Click Save in the upper right-hand corner of CCB. When the Comments section is full, to add a new entry put it in the Contact Instructions field at the bottom of the case. If that is full, email BSC Assist and they will move the entries to the Case Log.
Accounts with a Residential and Commercial Deposit
If a Commercial Account with Residential Service points has an ICS below 850, CC&B will create a Residential Deposit SA on the account and the customer will be billed a Deposit Increase. In the event that you need to add a Deposit Increase to one of these accounts, the increase should be added to the Residential Deposit SA if the ICS is below 850.
Manually Calculating a Deposit
There are times when Deposit Quotes will need to be calculated manually. This is usually due to a Premise that has been vacant for several months and the Premise Validator will calculate a deposit lower than what it should be. To calculate a deposit manually, pull up the address in CC&B. From the Control Central Main Screen, click on the Premise Tree. Go to the Historical Service Agreements and find the last tenant. Left click on the SA icon and go to SA Billing History. Add 12 months of billing history. Divide by 12 and multiply by 2.
The Deposit to quote in this example is $260.00.
New Construction Quotes – General Service
Deposits on electric for new construction General Service are calculated using the size of service and hours of operation. The service size of service can be found on the electrical permit or in Master Premise.
To find the service size on COJ’s permit search. Search for Inspections Scheduled and Address. Once on the permit, go to the Spec 1 Tab to see the service size.
To check the Service Size on Master Premise, from The Grid, click on
Applications
, click on
Master Premise and Service Point
. Enter the address and click
Search
. Click on
FMS PERMIT
.
The Permit Summary will appear. Scroll down towards the middle of the screen. On the left-hand side is the Service Size.
Use the following steps to calculate the total Deposit requested:
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
Step 4
Step 5
Step 6
Get Service Size (Amps, Volts, and Phases) by viewing electrical permit on COJ or GIS
Get Number of Hours in a week customers will be operating business. Multiply the hours in a week x 4 weeks in a month = Total Hours Open.
Follow Phase Chart below, using the Amps and follow across chart to Volts.
Multiply Total number of Hours in a month by the number of Volts equal Total KWH’s.
Take Total KWH’s, multiply .09 per KWH x 2 =Deposit.
Round your answer to the nearest ten dollars and you’ll have the customer’s deposit!
Example: 100 Amps, 220 Volts, Single Phase, 40 hours a week
160 Hours x 7.480 = 1,196.80 x .09 = $107.71
$107.71 x 2 = $215.42
Total Deposit Requested $220.00

Business Entity Verification (BSC)
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
Verifying a Business Entity
A commercial account is established in either a business name or in a person’s name. All Commercial Accounts require a deposit.
Verify the business entity and Federal Tax ID (FEI/EIN) – this usually can be done on the State’s Business Search website. If the FEI/EIN cannot be verified on line the customer must provide a copy of the SS4 Welcome Letter from the IRS or a W9 for their company. Most of the business entities can be verified on sunbiz.org. Note: The Entity must be Active in order to proceed with the account creation. If it is not an active entity, the account can be created in the Person’s Name with their Social Security Number and Date of Birth.
https://dos.myflorida.com/sunbiz/search/
NOTE ABOUT BUSINESS NAME
If the business is filed as a Fictitious Name the account should be established under the person’s name with their Social Security Number and Date of Birth. A fictitious business name is a name used by a natural person or entity for conducting business under such a name, which is different from its legal name. In the case of entities, such as corporations, a fictitious business name is any name different from that used in the articles of incorporation.
Ways to Search
There are several ways to Search for a business.

Click the image to enlarge.
Click the image to enlarge.
In the event that the entity is not found on sunbiz and cannot be verified on another State’s Business Search, the customer should send us a copy of their Articles of Organization or Incorporation and a W9 or copy of the SS4.

Click the image to enlarge.
SS4 and W9 Example
The SS4 is the document that the IRS sends to the customer when the FEI/EIN is assigned to their business entity. Sometimes the IRS sends an Electronic SS4 (2nd image). If we are unable to verify the Federal Tax ID# for the business online the customer should send us either the SS4 or a W9 for their Company (3rd image). The W9 is a form that they can download off the IRS website and fill out.

Apartment Complex Takeover (BSC)
Estimated reading: 4 minutes
Change of Ownership
Below are the basic steps for handling a complex takeover.
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
Step 4
Step 5
Step 6
Step 7
Step 8
Step 9
Step 10
Step 11
Create the New Account.
Go to Account Panel and change Customer Class from Commercial to Consolidated CAB.
Verify Entity name and FEI/EIN. Most of our customers can be found on sunbiz.org. If the entity is registered in a different state, go to that State’s Business Search Website. If unable to verify the entity, please have the customer submit a copy of their Articles of Incorporation or Articles of Organization. If the FEI/EIN cannot be verified on-line the customer should also submit a copy of the SS4 Welcome Letter from the IRS or a W9
Ask for the Closing Date.
ADD A SHORT COMMENT TO THE OLD ACCOUNT TO NOTE THERE IS A COMPLEX TAKOVER, INCLUDE THE CLOSING DATE. Ex: “COMPLEX TAKEOVER, NEW ACCT 9999999999 ABC APTS LLC, CLOSING DATE 12-24-19”. On the new account, add a similar short comment with the old account number and closing date. (**this is not mandatory but it is helpful and will alert other Call Takers that the complex is changing ownership.)
CALCULATE DEPSOSIT. Go to the billing history of the old account. Add up the last 12 bills. Divide by 12 and multiply 2 to get 2 times the average bill. The customer will have 10 business days from the closing date to submit a deposit, bond or letter of credit.
SEND DEPOSIT QUOTE/WELCOME LETTER TO THE CUSTOMER. Include the Indemnity Bond Form in the event that the customer chooses to do a Bond in lieu of Cash Deposit. The customer will have 10 business days from closing date to secure the deposit, bond of bank letter of credit.
IS CUSTOMER INTERESTED IN THE LANDLORD AGREEMENT? If yes, email BSC Assist. Provide them with the new account number, the customer contact name and email and ask that they send the application for the agreement to the customer.
CREATE COM APT COMPLEX TAKEOVER CASE ON THE NEW ACCOUNT. In the Comments section, note the customer contact information, the deposit amount, address of the complex and the old owner’s account number and closing date.
CONFIRM CLOSING DATE. Closing dates can change, so it is a good idea to check with the customer contact the day before closing just to confirm. If the closing is confirmed for the next business day, proceed with entering the start requests for that date.
ENTER THE STARTS. Note: Before entering the starts on the new account, if the old owner’s account is on the Landlord Agreement, email BSC Assist to have the agreement stopped. The house meters, multifamily water/sewer are entered using the regular Stop/Start Screen. Use Premise Management to start the vacant units that are currently active under the old account.
Start Deposit SA.
CHECK ALL FA’S AND SA’s. Start the Deposit SA
***In addition to checking all FA’s and SA’s on the new account, make sure that all SA’s on the old account are stopped. Remove the list of Authorized Agents on the old account and move them to the Comment Section on the Account Panel, Main tab.
Premise Management
Go to Control Center, Main Screen. Left Click on Main Menu Bar. Hold the cursor over Customer Information and click on Premise Management.
Click the image to enlarge.
On the Premise Management Screen, use Premise Filter “Located At this Address”. Enter the address. A list of apartments will be displayed. The Account Information Column will show whether the apartment is in the complex name or tenant name. Select the apartments that you wish to start. Click Start button. It can be very easy to select the wrong apartment if there are pending stop/starts for tenants and complex for an apartment. Pending starts/stops also will appear in the Account Information Section. It is recommended to print or copy a list of the Active SA’s listed in the account tree of the old account and use that as a guide.
Click the image to enlarge.
The Start SA Groups Confirmation Screen will appear. Enter the Start Date. Click “Show SA Groups”. Select Start Option and click Start. It may take several minutes for the starts to process because multiple requests are being submitted at one time. It is best when selecting the apartments to start in Premise Management to only do no more than 20 apartments at one time.
Click the image to enlarge.

The caller is identified as an Agent of Record or is the account holder. We can access the account by any of the following means:  Account number, SS#, FEI/EIN or address and as long as they verify the password the account is fully verified.
If the Account is in a Person’s name and the account holder or Agent of Record is unable to verify the password, the caller must verify the last 4 of the SS# and DOB to verify the account.
If the account is in the Business Name and the Agent of Record does not know the password, they must verify either the account number, FEI/EIN or the telephone number on the account.
The caller is identified as an Agent of Record. Body of the Call
Assist the customer.
Summarize the Call
Closing
Always ask:
Is there anything else that I can help you with?
End the call with:
Thank you for calling JEA.

Using the Script for Commercial Services (BSC)
Estimated reading: 4 minutes
Commercial Accounts & Using the Scripts
The scripts are a great tool, however for Commercial Accounts, we are not able to use the scripts for everything. The commercial department does use the following Scripts:
Start Process
Premise Validation
Adjustment Cancellation
When to Use the Start Process Script
Use the Start Process script for:
New account creation
Do not use the Schedule Start Option if the customer is starting more than 1 Premise or if the Premise that the customer is wanting to start has any flags on it.
Most account updates
Adjustment cancellation
Deposit quotes
IMPORTANT
DO NOT USE THE START PROCESS SCRIPT FOR ADDING ADDITIONAL SERVICES TO AN EXISTING ACCOUNT OR STARTING MULTIPLE PREMISES ON A NEW OR EXISTING ACCOUNT. This will result in the Deposit SA for the account to be changed incorrectly.
DO NOT USE THE SCRIPT FOR STOPPING SERVICES ON A COMMERCIAL ACCOUNT
Using the Premise Validation Script for Deposit Quotes
When using the Premise Validation Script for Deposit Quotes, after you pull up the address, click the button for “Check Deposit” and open up the SA Billing History. If it appears too low, check the billing history in CC&B. In this example, the electric deposit is shown as $200.00 in Premise Validation because this premise has been vacant for over a year and is active under the landlord’s account. When you check the billing history of the electric for when this premise was occupied, the correct deposit amount for the electric should be $640.00.
Billing History While Vacant:
Click the image to enlarge.
Billing History While Occupied:
Click the image to enlarge.
Using the Premise Validation Script for a New Building Deposit
If a customer is wanting to start electric service for a brand new location that has never had service, we calculate the deposit based on the hours of operation and size of service. The service size can be found on the electrical permit or in the JEA Master Premise Web. The Premise Validation Script has a “New Building Deposit” calculator. Note: There may be times when the calculator cannot be used and the deposit will need to be calculated manually.
Use the following steps:
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
Enter the address in the Premise Validation Script and click on
New Building Deposit
.
Populate the Phase, Volts, AMPS and hours of operation per week. Click
Calculate
and
Submit
to get the deposit amount to quote for the electric service.
Get the deposit amount to quote for the electric service.
Using the Script for Commercial Account Updates
Use the following steps:
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
Click
Start Process
in the Dashboard. Enter the account number on the Person/Account Search screen and access account.
Select
Offline Update
and click
Update Info
.
Procced with the update on the Account Entry Screen. Continue to the end of the Script.
NOTE
DO NOT USE THE SCRIPT TO UPDATE AGENTS OF RECORD ON ACCOUNTS THAT HAVE A LONG LIST OF NAMES.
The script can only support so many characters in the Agent Of Record section. If the list of agents on the account in CC&B exceeds the character limit in the script, names will be deleted from CC&B that should not be removed.
If there is only one Agent of Record line with a long list of names, using the script to add or remove an agent will delete agents that should not be deleted.
If the account has multiple lines for Agent of Record, using the script to add or remove an agent will cause all of the additional Agent of Records lines leaving only one line of agents in CC&B. This deletes numerous agents that should not have been deleted.

Agency Voucher Department (Contacts List)
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
A voucher pay plan is a courtesy hold JEA places on a customer’s account by the customer assistance team (
vouchers@jea.com
), when an approved agency agrees to pay a portion or all of the utility bill. A voucher pay plan arrangement allows the payment to be made within 30-days (NFCAA is granted 45-days, per signed agreement with JEA). A voucher pay plan is an arrangement between the customer and the agency. In the event a customer has questions about the voucher:
refer first to the customer contacts which may contain information on the purpose of the voucher (i.e. the contact and notes on the account may indicate the voucher is for electric only and the customer is responsible for the water portion of the bill) and
you may also refer the customer to reach out directly to the agency, in the event they are awaiting a voucher to be placed on the account or if payment is pending.
Regardless of the voucher amount, the account balance remains the primary responsibility of the customer.
Agencies interested in becoming JEA voucher partners should be directed to speak with the customer assistance team. Send the agency information in question to
vouchers@jea.com
and they will research the agency and reach out with an voucher partner application.
Agency vouchers are never accepted when walked into the Customer Solutions Center (CSC) or faxed/emailed to the Call Center. Each agency voucher must be submitted and approved by the customer assistance team via
vouchers@jea.com
.

As a reminder, when emailing the Electric Services internal inbox, please follow these guidelines:
Include the customer’s name, address, and the reason for the email.
Please state what information you have reviewed prior to emailing.
REMEMBER:
Advise the customer of additional flags or alerts that may be on the premise, and state in the email that you’ve done so.
New electric services can be started with an active permit and will stay in held status until the permit process is complete.
Other non-permit related flags will need to be reviewed and procedures followed.
If you need immediate assistance, please contact the Assist Line or your manager.

Electric Services Engineers (Contacts List)
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
Engineers Overview
It is important that the Customer Advisor does their part to ensure the customer is fully helped before providing the caller with the phone number for an Engineer.
JEA Engineers are assigned to a Zip code. Each Engineer is responsible for the permit related electric service work in their assigned area.
When there is a permit, the permit process must be completed before service will be started. (You may put in a pending start if the permit is active or final, it just will not start until the permit process is complete).
JEA Engineers are electric only, no water inquiries should be forwarded to them.
If the customer has asked for the Engineers number, you can provide the customer with the assigned engineer’s number. The customer should be advised the call back time is 1-2 business days and calling the engineer will not expedite the standard timelines.
Always remember that after you have reviewed the permit and exceptions you can email Electric Services if you have questions, then contact the caller back with the information provided. Please advise the customer that it may take up to 24 hours to hear back from them.
After the CA provides the Engineer’s number to the caller, you must email Electric Services (
electricservices@jea.com
) the following information.
Email Subject Line: Engineer’s Phone Number Provided
The caller’s name and contact information
The address they are calling about
The Engineer’s name provided
The reason for the call

if a customer is requesting a paper copy of a form or letter such as Water/Pool Adjustment forms, Medical Life Alert forms, etc.
This process should
ONLY
be used if the customer cannot (a) receive a .pdf copy via email or (b) access the form via JEA.com. Alternatively, you may fill out an Adjustment form with a customer over the phone, unless a leak has yet to be fixed; remind the customer that they are on a recorded line and YOU must read the form in its entirety to the customer so that they are aware of the terms of an adjustment.

.
Enter your case

. If the delivery address is different, ensure you specify the address.

select the

On the Case

field.

icon to add a new row. Paste your comment into the
Details
field.
Click the
Save
button again to save the changes that you made to the
Log
.
The case is now created. A downtown correspondence Customer Advisor will complete the request and send the requested form/letter to the customer.

Pool Fill Adjustment
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
Adjustments to a Residential customer’s Wastewater charges may apply the first time they fill a swimming pool with permit or after a non-permitted repair/refill. To determine if their charges may be adjusted, the customer should complete the request form on JEA.com.
Upon receipt of their request, CART will review the documentation, confirm the permit was issued by the Building and Zoning Department for a new pool or verify the repair was related to the structure of the pool or pool equipment. JEA will also assess the meter readings prior to and after the pool was filled. If additional information is needed, a JEA representative will contact the customer.
IMPORTANT
Not all the Wastewater charges will be removed. Customers are still responsible for their normal Wastewater usage.
Pool Fill Adjustment Requirements
JEA will approve one adjustment within a 12-month period.
To qualify for a Swimming Pool Fill adjustment the customer will need the following information:
Submit the request within 30 days of the pool fill or repair
Capacity of pool (in gallons) as noted on the permit issued by the Building and Zoning Department;
Date the pool was filled;
Active Permit Number
for a new pool installation;
Name of Builder/Contractor/Person completing the repair; and,
State Certification or Registration Number of Builder/Contractor.
The customer must have a Wastewater Service Point to qualify. If they do not have a Wastewater Service Point, an adjustment cannot be approved.
Submitting a Pool Fill Adjustment Request
It is preferred that customer’s submit their request by completing the
Pool Fill Affidavit
via JEA.com
.
If the customer is unable to complete the request via JEA.com, the Customer Advisor can complete the form on behalf of the customer; you must read all verbiage to the customer.
Alternatively, the customer can complete the paper form found in the
Forms Library
. The completed form should be emailed to
wateradjustment@jea.com
.
Repair documents should also be emailed when possible. Alternatively, they may send them by mail or Fax.
Mailing Address:
JEA Customer Advocacy and Resolution Team
225 N. Pearl Street, FL 3
Jacksonville, FL 32202
Fax:
(904) 665-7990
Reviewing a Completed Pool Fill Adjustment
CART will hold the request if the consumption has not billed. Click the
ToDo
in the Dashboard to see if adjustment must wait until after next Bill Date.
When a Pool Fill adjustment is made to an account, the adjustment is always applied to the current charges; never the previous balance.

Water, Wastewater & Irrigation Adjustment
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
In situations such as a leak or excessive water loss, JEA may adjust a customer’s Water and/or Wastewater bill. Upon a customer’s request, JEA will evaluate the circumstances surrounding the excessive usage and determine the appropriate adjustment amount. If approved, the amount of the adjustment may be granted for up to two consecutive billing periods.
Water/Wastewater/Irrigation Adjustment Requirements
Residential customers can have up to 2 Water/Wastewater Adjustments within a 36-month period, per residence.
To qualify for a Water, Wastewater, or Irrigation adjustment the customer will need the following information:
Submit the request within 90 days of the billing period in question
Date Leak Occurred and Date Leak Repaired;
Type of Leak;
Description of the leak the actions that were taken to complete the repairs;
Submit repair documents with JEA account number on all documents sent to
wateradjustment@jea.com
.
Examples of repair documents include a plumbers statement/invoice, repair or supplies receipt, or a detailed photo in the event of a self-repair.
IMPORTANT
Water usage must have normalized before an adjustment can be requested. If the leak in question has not been repaired, the customer must wait to submit the request.
Submitting a Water/Wastewater/Irrigation Adjustment Request
It is preferred that customers submit their request by completing the
Water, Wastewater, and Irrigation form.
If the customer is unable to complete the request via JEA.com, the Customer Advisor can complete the form on behalf of the customer; you must read all verbiage to the customer.
Alternatively, the customer can complete the paper form found in the
Forms Library
. The completed form should be emailed to
wateradjustment@jea.com
.
Repair documents should also be emailed when possible. Alternatively, they may send them by mail or Fax.
Mailing Address:
JEA Customer Advocacy and Resolution Team
225 N. Pearl Street, FL 3
Jacksonville, FL 32202
Fax:
(904) 665-7990
Reviewing a Completed Water/Wastewater/Irrigation Adjustment
