Pool Fill & Water/Wastewater Adjustments (B)
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
A Pool or Water/Wastewater adjustment request is a very common request from JEA customers. Customers can request an adjustment for these issues via JEA.com or they can complete a paper form. Customer Advisors should become familiar with these two adjustment requests so that they can assist customers with the following:
Informing customers if they are eligible for an adjustment and when to request
Directing customers to the request form via JEA.com (preferred)
Answering billing questions after an adjustments has been completed or denied
The Customer Advocacy Resolution Team (CART) does back office support for JEA’s Call Center including:
Account research
Escalation Assist Line
Complete Pool Fill & Water/Wastewater adjustment requests to customer accounts
This section will cover the most common adjustments that customers request through the CART Team, Pool Fill Adjustments and Water/Wastewater Adjustments.
CART Adjustment Types
All Pool Fill & Water/Wastewater Adjustments fall into two adjustment types,
Extreme High Use
and a
Plumbers Statement
adjustment.
Plumbers Statement
Extreme High Use
A Plumbers Statement adjustment includes the following issues:
Underground leaks
Slab leaks
Broken pipes
These examples are concealed leaks only where water was not discharged into the sewer system, i.e. a water pipe broke and flooded a room in a house, the water did not go down the drain.
The customer is asked to provide a repair statement or receipts of the parts needed to make the repairs.
Sewer bill corrections are made to normalize the consumption.
An Extreme High Use adjustment includes the following issues:
Toliet leak
An outside hose was left running
Malfunctioning irrigation timer
Watering new sod
Extreme High Use adjustments are for issues that do not meet the requirements of a Plumbers Statement adjustment.
The customer may qualify for a sewer tier reduction if their average is less than 6000 gallons.
You do not need to explain the difference between these two types of adjustments to a customer, however it is important to know that there are limitations in how CART makes adjustments, depending on the adjustment type used.
NOTE
An adjustment can take up to 3 days to appear on the account.

Estimated reading: 1 minute

Your Payment Arrangement in the amount of $XXX.XX has been broken up into XX monthly installments. The amount of each installment is $XX.XX. This amount along with your monthly usage will appear on your next bill, XXXX-XX-XX.
It is very important that you pay each month’s bill amount in full by the due date.

While on a Payment Arrangement, your account is not eligible for any other payment extensions offered at JEA.

Scheduled Payments
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
Scheduling a payment is an option where customers can pre-schedule a payment via JEA.com to apply to their account for a date in the future.
Information About Scheduled Payments
The following is information that Customer Advisors need to know regarding scheduled payments.
These can be scheduled up to 90 days in advance, excluding weekends and holidays.
The customer will receive confirmation emails when creating a scheduled payment and when canceling a scheduled payment.
Regardless of a scheduled payment, if the customer has signed up for Bill Reminders and the balance has not been paid three days prior to the due date, a reminder email is sent out to the customer three days prior to the payment due date.
Additionally, when an ACH or Credit Card scheduled payment is created or canceled, a customer contact will be added to their JEA account in CCB.
Scheduled payments will post to CCB on the next scheduled business date.
The customer can cancel a pending scheduled payment. The customer has up until the day before the scheduled payment date to cancel the payment via JEA.com. If it is the day of the scheduled payment and prior to 1pm, the customer will need to call JEA at 665-6000 and the CA should follow the
Cancel Payment Request procedure
. If it is after 2pm, it is too late to cancel the payment.
Scheduled payments are not used to cancel disconnects or reconnect service if the scheduled payment date is after the expected disconnection (due date).
If the account is in severance, the scheduled payment should be canceled and the pay now option should be used.
If a customer’s service is disconnected due to a scheduled payment, do not send a JEA error FA. If it is at least the day before the scheduled payment date, the scheduled payment should be canceled by the customer via JEA.com and the pay now option should be used. If it is the day of the scheduled payment date and prior to 1pm, the customer will need to call JEA at 665-6000 and the CA should create a
Cancel Payment Request
. The reconnect FA will generate after the customer’s payment posts. If it is after 2pm, the reconnect will not happen until the next business date.

FISERV (Bill-to-Bank)
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
FISERV Bill-to-Bank allows our Postal customer to choose to have their bill delivered directly to their bank as an electronic bill.
Customers cannot use JEA eBill and FISERV Bill-to-Bank at the same time. Customers utilizing FISERV Bill-to-Bank will not receive a paper bill from JEA; they will still receive all other correspondence directly from JEA.
This product is referenced by a few different names, depending on the customer’s banking institution:
FISERV
FISERV Bill-to-Bank
Bill-to-Bank
eBill to Bank
MyCheckFree
FISERV MyCheckFree
JEA Residential and Life-Support customers who receive their bills in the mail (USPS) have the option to receive their bill electronically, directly through their bank.
To determine if a customer’s bank participates in FISERV Bill-to-Bank, the customer should contact their banking institution.
Starting, Identifying, & Stopping FISERV
Starting/Activating the FISERV Bill-to-Bank Service
The customer can only sign up for this bill delivery option through their banking website, they are not able to sign-up directly through JEA.
The requirements to qualify:
The customer must be a Residential or Life-Support customer.
The customer must currently receive their JEA bill through the mail (USPS).
They will need the
Account number
Billing Zip Code (32232-5047)
Once the customer is signed up, there will be a Characteristic on the account to let you know that they will receive their bill through their bank using the FISERV electronic billing service.
Identifying the FISERV Bill-to-Bank Account Status
To verify that a customer is signed up for FISERV, follow the steps below:
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
Access the customer’s account in CCB.
Click on the
Account Context Menu
button and select
Go To Account
.
Click on the
Characteristics
tab.
Active accounts using the FISERV service will have the “A-Active” Characteristic.
Along with a Customer Contact that includes
FISERV Activation
.
Once FISERV is activated you can see the Characteristic in the
Account and Person Characteristics
zone.
The account will have an alert stating
Account registered in FISERV service
.
Stopping/Deactivating the FISERV Bill-to-Bank Service
If the customer wants to stop receiving an electronic bill to their bank and wants to return to receiving their bill in the mail via USPS, the customer must go to their banking website and stop the electronic bill delivery through their bank.
If the customer wants to stop receiving an electronic bill to their bank and wants to start receiving their bill electronically directly from JEA (standard JEA eBill) then the Customer Advisor should direct them to go to JEA.com and change their bill delivery preference there. If the customer is unable to go to JEA.com, the Customer Advisor can move them to JEA eBill as a courtesy.
Once the customer is no longer signed up for the FISERV Bill-to-Bank, there will be a Characteristic on the account to let you know that they have been deactivated and will no longer receive their bill through their bank using the FISERV service.
Deactivated accounts no longer using the FISERV service will have the “D-Deactivated” Characteristic, along with a Customer Contact that states
FISERV deactivation
.

Fast Pay (KUBRA Recurring Credit Card Payments)
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
Fast Pay is a KUBRA product for Credit and Debit Card users that allows them to automatically schedule a payment when the bill is generated and an amount is due. After signing into JEA.com, the customer must specify a Credit or Debit Card to be used for the recurring payments within KUBRA. This card is authorized real-time. When the bill is ready, the customer is emailed, requesting they approve the scheduled payment. The customer’s Credit or Debit Card is then processed on the Due Date.
Note that any customer who has a past record of AutoPay on their account is currently unable to sign up for Fast Pay.
Fast Pay is similar to AutoPay, however it requires the customer to acknowledge/approve scheduling of the payment first.

A customer may make a payment at the Customer Solution Center’s payment kiosk and then later realize that they used the incorrect debit/credit card or otherwise need to make a change to their payment.
To cancel a debit/credit kiosk payment on the day that a payment is made,
the customer should contact JEA by 5pm on the same day as the payment
. Otherwise, JEA must send the payment cancellation request to Adcomp Systems for processing.

Agency Voucher Payment Redistribution or Agency Credit Refund Review
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
For customers with agency assistance, the
Payment Updates
case can be created for the following two reasons:
Request Reason
What Happens
To request the redistribution of a customer’s payment when they have agency assistance that pays for electric-only.
This request will determine if the customer’s payment(s) can be reapplied to water charges, allowing agency assistance to be applied to electric charges. The Customer Assistance Programs (CAP) department will work with RCS to complete this request.
To request the redistribution of an agency payment for a MyWay customer with a Deferred (Unpaid) Balance.
This request will ask the CAP department to apply a credit (from an agency payment) to all or some of a MyWay customer’s Unpaid Balance.
To request a review of an account for a credit refund when they previously received agency assistance and they are stopping all services with JEA.
Submitting this request will allow the CAP department to research how much of the available credit should be returned to the customer. The CAP department will then forward the request to RCS to research and determine what amount will be returned to the agency and if any remaining, what amount to the customer. Customer payment reimbursements will be based on previous payments and a review of any deposit on the account.

Re-Working a Payment Arrangement
Estimated reading: 1 minute
Payment Arrangements can be reworked one time BUT no extra debt can be added to the PA. The PA must be 90 days old or greater prior to a rework to ensure that the customer has made at least 2 good payments.
In other words, if the customer has a current bill and is on a PA. They must pay the current bill first, and then the Assist Line can rework the remaining amount of the PA.
Re-Working Example
Example
Total bill due: $352.74
Balance on Payment Arrangement: $450
Installments left on Payment Arrangement: 4
Once the customer pays the $352.74 by the due date, the $450.00 can be reworked into a PA for up to nine months.
IMPORTANT
Always remind the customer we will only rework a PA once.
Re-Working and Adding Additional Debt
It is possible to re-work a Payment Arrangement AND add additional debt to the re-worked PA, but only the Assist Line or a Manger can approve the request, and only for certain reasons.
Reasons that we can re-work and add debt include the following:
Deposit Increases
Water Leaks
Extremely High Electric Usage (HVAC heat strip issue, hot water leak, etc.)

Video Bill Pilot
Estimated reading: 7 minutes
Video Bills are customized summaries of the monthly bill. Customers will receive a video link with timely and useful information about their statement. JEA has pre-selected 20,000 accounts to participate in the pilot.
Customers will receive an email before the start of the pilot advising them, they have been selected to participate in the pilot and given the option to opt out at that time if they so choose.
Identifying Accounts in the Pilot
A customer contact will be added to accounts that are enrolled in the Video Bill pilot.
The email with the video bill will go out 4 days after each customer’s bill date. It is only sent to customers whose bill has increased or decreased by $20 or more from the previous month. It is unlikely that the video bills will increase the call center’s call volume. Each email is sent based on the customer’s specific bill date. This means the videos will be staggered throughout the month.
What is in the Video Bill?
The video explains why the customer’s bill has increased (or decreased) using actual usage from last month based on:
The weather
Number of days in their billing cycle
Any price change
Other factors (these include behavioral changes like changing thermostat settings, etc.)
The video is created by a home’s utility usage based on actual usage, weather patterns and bill data.
Accessing the Video Bill
There is a link to the CSR tool that customer advisors can utilize to look up a customer’s video. The CSR tool shows much of the data that is in the video, but it will only show the most recent month-to-month comparison.
The link is located in the Customer Service favorites folder in Edge. Once the link is clicked the landing page will appear. After entering the customers account number and clicking search, access to the video bill will available to view.
The link is located in the Customer Service favorites folder in Edge. Once the link is clicked the landing page will appear. After entering the customers account number and clicking search, access to the video bill will available to view.
Click the image to enlarge
Video Bill Sample
Comparison Data
The video bill takes the current months data and compares it to previous months. The video above used data from the February and March bills for comparison purposes.
Click the image to enlarge
Weather
The calculation for the Weather increase/decrease is based on the time of year, Warmer Temps = AC and Cooler Temps = Heat.
The temperature is based on what is recorded at the Jacksonville International Airport.
Bill Period
JEA billing cycles range from 28-34 days, each month. The length of the cycle is adjusted to account for weekends and holidays.
The number of days billed can be found on the monthly billing statement.
Days Billed
Click the image to enlarge
Irrigation/Reclaimed Usage
Irrigation/Reclaimed usage will be used when the home has a separate meter for Irrigation or Reclaimed water.
The Irrigation/Reclaimed usage can be found on the monthly billing statement.
Water/Sewer Usage
The water and sewer usage will be based on the amount of water used to calculate the water and sewer consumption.
The usage can be found on the monthly billing statement.
Click the image to enlarge
Customer FAQs
Can I unsubscribe from this service?
There is an unsubscribe link at the bottom of the email. This will direct them to JEA’s unsubscribe link and follow that process.
What is a water service line?
A water service line is the small pipe that carries water into your home or business from JEA’s water main located in the City’s right-of-way and easements. These lines can be made of plastic, brass, copper, cast iron, flexible iron, lead, or galvanized steel (which could contain lead).
I accidentally unsubscribed, can I sign back up?
Please let your Apogee contact Gerald Butler at
butlgl@jea.com
know the email address and/or Account ID of the customer. We will then manually reactivate them.
My Neighbor is getting video bills, can I get them too?
Unfortunately, we are not able to add additional customers to this pilot, but with future pilot projects customers may be eligible for subsequent pilots.  If the pilot does become a part of JEA’s communication strategy moving forward, customers will have the chance to receive these video bills via email.
I received an email regarding a pilot, did this email come from JEA?
Yes, the email you received was an invitation to participate in a pilot that will provide additional information regarding the breakdown of your bill and how to help manage your bill more efficiently each month.
How was I chosen for this video bill pilot?
We randomly chose customers that have active accounts with us here at JEA to participate in the pilot.
How do you know so much about my bill?
The information provided comes from the usage at the JEA meter.  We use that information and examine weather patterns and other factors to provide additional information to assist in helping you understand the bill.
The video mentioned other charges, what is that and did I have any?
An example of other charges would be if you started services at a new address and had a start service fees or if you had charges other than electric, water, and sewer usage.
I received a video bill email last month, but not this month. Why is that?
The video bill email only goes out if your total bill is more or less than $20 from the previous month.
There is a link at the end, is it safe to click on that link?
Yes, it is safe to click on that link. The link will take you to our website on ways to help lower your utility bill at jea.com/savings.

Rates & Fees
Estimated reading: 7 minutes
Our rates are designed to cover the cost of operating your electric, water and sewer utilities and to pay down the debt for money borrowed to expand and improve our infrastructure. Our rates also cover current state and federal regulations. Utility service is a complicated and costly business. We work hard to be responsible stewards of your business and the environment, while bringing you the most reliable service possible.
The basic components of a customers bill are made of the following items:
Basic Monthly Charge (aka Customer Charge)
Rates
Fees
Taxes
Click here for ALL utility service rates information via JEA.com
Electric Rate Overview
The rate in which electric is consumed is measured in kilowatts (KW). The amount of electricity used is measured in kilowatt hours (KWH).
This rate is designed for all residential customers. There is no demand charge, as it is incorporated into the energy charge. Customers in this class include single family homes, individually metered apartments, and some common areas at apartment complexes and home owner associations.
IMPORTANT
JEA has to be able to read a customer’s meter for billing. If the meter is inaccessible, JEA is unable to properly charge and maintain the customer’s meter.
In cases where a customer renders JEA incapable of accessing a meter, damages a meter, requests a special reconnection order, or if there is anything that encumbers JEAs’ ability to provide maintenance or proper service, an additional $25.00 fee will be assessed.
Electric Rates Definitions
Here’s a glossary of terms which are referenced on the customer’s bill for you to better understand the charges.
Rate Class –
Group of customers that have similar usage characteristics.
Residential –
Single family homes and individually metered apartments and some common areas in apartment and home owner association common areas.
General Service –
Small commercial customers with demand less than 75 kW per billing period.
General Service Demand –
Large commercial customers with demand greater than 75 kW but less than 1,000 kW per billing period.
General Service Large Demand –
Very large commercial and Industrial customers with demands greater than 1,000 kW per billing period.
Time of Day (TOD) –
The rate reflects the different costs of providing electric service at different times of the day, different days of the week, and different seasons.
Billing Period –
Time period of a utility bill generally 1 month. Period can be longer or shorter. This is generally caused by either stopping or starting service.
kilo-Watt (kW) –
Measurement of Demand which represents the highest amount of energy used within a single 15-minute intervals during a billing period.
kilo-Watt hour (kWh) –
Measurement of the flow of electric charge through a conductor or demand integrated over time.
Load Factor –
Ratio of all energy used in a billing period to the peak demand measured in that same billing period…Formula (kWh / (kW X 730 hours) {730 hours is the average number of hours in a month}
Excess Reactive Demand (kVar) –
Reactive power, measured in kilovolt-amperes (kVar), results from equipment that draws more current from the electrical system than usual.
Customer Charge –
Even if you use no energy during the month this charge is for each electric service and pays some of the costs associated with meters, meter reading, billing, and customer service.
Demand Charge –
Through the demand charge, each business pays its share of the utility’s investment in generation, transmission and distribution equipment standing by to serve.
Energy Charge –
The energy charge recovers variable costs related to electric service, utility operation and maintenance expenses, debt service, city contribution, and other costs.
Fuel Charge –
The fuel charge recovers variable costs related to purchasing fuel burned in JEA’s power plants or purchased through power markets.
Franchise Fee –
Fee levied on JEA by a municipality to provide service to the residents of that municipality (Levied by and remitted to the municipality levying the fee).
Gross Receipts Tax –
Tax levied on JEA by the State of Florida for providing electrical service to residents and businesses of the State (Levied by and remitted to the State of Florida).
Public Service Tax –
Tax charged by a municipality on the customers of JEA (A portion of the fuel charge is exempt from the Public Service Tax).
Florida State Sales Tax –
Sales tax charged by the State of Florida on the commercial electric customers of JEA. The State tax rate for electric service is 7% but may be increased by any local option sales tax on the first $5,000 of the taxable charges on an electric bill. Customers on residential rates are exempt from sales tax.
Water, Wastewater & Irrigation Rate Overview
JEA water and wastewater customers pay for operations, maintenance, and replacement of the system through monthly user charges. The fixed rate only pertains to the charge of the physical meter located at the premise. There is a monthly charge for the meter unit based on its size.
NOTE
The most common sized meters used by residential customers are 5/8” and 3/4”.
In addition to being charged base fees associated with meter and wastewater use, JEA charges customers for the amount of water they consume on a monthly basis. The meter measures water in either cubic feet or gallons.
Water meters were initially measured in cubic feet and JEA has recently moved to the gallon as the unit of measure.
Until the transition is complete some customers still retain the meters that measure in the cubic feet metric. Although there are different units of measure, the cost computes the same. (1ccf =748 gallons)
The services expended by JEA are associated with different costs depending on whether it is used for residential, commercial, or in the case of water, irrigation (sprinkler system used to water lawn) and/or reclaimed water (highly treated, filtered, disinfected water used for irrigation of lawns, golf courses, etc.)
Wastewater is charged based on the amount of water that is consumed by a customer. There is a 20,000 gallon cap on wastewater charges.
Water and Wastewater Rates Definitions
Here’s a glossary of terms which are referenced on the customer’s bill for you to better understand the charges.
kGal
– kilo gallon – 1,000 gallons of water.
CCF –
100 cf – 100 cubic feet of water (1 cubic foot of water is equal to 7.48 gallons).
Billing Period –
Time period of a utility bill generally 1 month. Period can be longer or shorter. This is generally caused by either stopping or starting service.
Residential Service –
Single family homes and individually metered apartments.
Commercial Service –
All business uses of the water and sewer system.
Multi-Family Service –
Residential apartment type complexes that are serviced by 1 water meter to multiple residences.
Sprinkler Service –
Water service that is connected directly to a buildings fire suppression system.
Irrigation Service –
Potable water that is separately metered and connected directly to a lawn sprinkler system.
Reclaimed Water Service –
Reclaimed or recycled water, is former wastewater that is treated to remove solids and certain impurities, and used in sustainable landscaping irrigation.
Service Availability Charge –
Monthly charge designed to recover costs associated with meters, meter reading, billing, customer service, and a portion of the costs associated with operating and maintaining the water or sewer system.
Consumption Charge –
Charge for water used during a billing period. Residential and Irrigation usage is broken into conservation tiers as consumption increases. Commercial consumption is a levelized charge for all consumption.
Usage Charge –
Charge for usage of the sewer system during a billing period. Residential usage is broken into tiers as water use increases. Residential sewer usage is based on 100% of water used up to 20 kGal. Commercial sewer usage is based on 100% of water used.
Franchise Fee –
Fee levied on JEA by a municipality to provide service to the residents of that municipality (Levied by and remitted to the municipality levying the fee).
Public Service Tax –
Tax charged by a municipality on the customers of JEA.

FAQs Regarding a Cancel Payment Request
Are pin-less debit payments also eligible to be canceled?
No.
If there are multiple payments that need to be canceled, can they all be in 1 case?
No, create a separate case for each cancel payment request.
How do you know if the payment is an American Express payment outside of the CA asking the customer?
You have to security rights to view the Tenders within the Payment Event. Also; when you drill into the Kubra Payment.
Do holidays count like a weekend meaning the payments are eligible to be canceled by the next day before 8pm?
No. Payments paid on a Holiday will process like a normal weekday.
Are payments processed on the weekend?
No, if a payment is made after the 8pm file is sent on Friday, you would have until 7:59pm on Monday to cancel a payment.
Will the customer get a confirmation (from KUBRA, etc.) after the payment has been successfully canceled?
Yes, they should get an email.

Payment Arrangement (B)
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
A Payment Arrangement (PA) allows a customer to pay their balance over an extended period beyond their due date. As with a Payment Plan, the amount owed beyond the customer’s due date is referred to as a past due balance. The past due balance will be divided into incremental amounts and billed over a series of installments. While on a Payment Arrangement, the customer continues to be responsible for the ongoing monthly-billed consumption of commodity services. The amount of the Payment Arrangement coupled with consumption, will appear on the account holder’s monthly bill.
The terms and conditions of a PA are based on the current and prior history of the customer’s account. JEA offers a Payment Arrangement to assist these customers with making affordable payments. This agreement allows the customer to maintain their services and JEA to receive payments for services already delivered.
Payment Arrangement Facts
The following are important facts about Payment Arrangement.
A Payment Arrangement is used to pay off a debt over a pre-defined period of time.
A bill with a Payment Arrangement MUST be paid by the due date; no extensions are allowed.
An account may not have both a Pay Plan and a Payment Arrangement at the same time.
The debt on a Payment Arrangement DOES re-age.
If the customer is on MyBudget, they will have to unenroll from MyBudget before a PA can be granted.
To pay off a Payment Arrangement, customers must pay the account balance to $0, not just the PA balance.

Pay Plan (A)
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
There are times when customers need more time to pay their JEA bills. In keeping with our creed of being a community oriented organization, JEA recognizes that an additional option is needed to address our customer’s financial needs and offer assistance. Hence, the Pay Plan option was created.
A Pay Plan (PP) is a short term agreement that provides terms and conditions mutually agreed upon by the customer and JEA to pay a past due debt.
The current balance, or if account is past due the previous balance on the can be extended no later than the 51st day of the bill date.
This Pay Plan is defined as a Default Pay Plan.
Pay Plan Types
Voucher
Default
When an agency submits a voucher on behalf of a customer, a
Voucher Pay Plan
is created, placing a hold on the account until payment is received.
All other Pay Plans fall under the Default Pay Plan category or type.
Pay Plan Facts
The following are important facts about Pay Plans.
Only one Pay Plan of each type is permitted on an Account.
An account may not have both a Pay Plan and a Payment Arrangement at the same time.
A Pay Plan is used to shield the debt from the Collection Process.
The debt on a Pay Plan does not re-age.
A Pay Plan must be paid off entirely by the PP due date. Once a Pay Plan is created it cannot be canceled to create a Payment Agreement. The Pay Plan must be paid as agreed.
If there is an amount over 51 days but less than $25 it will be added to the remaining past due balance.
IMPORTANT
Always review the Alerts to ensure no previous Pay Plans or Payment Arrangements have been Broken or Denied.

MyBudget & Budget Billing (B)
Estimated reading: 1 minute
JEA MyBudget is a levelized payment plan that evens out the customer’s monthly utility bill by taking a rolling average of their last 12 bills. The rolling average makes their utility bill payment about the same amount each month, making budgeting for it a little easier. JEA MyBudget is an option for customers who live on a fixed income, don’t like seasonal bill fluctuations, or want a more predictable utility bill from month-to-month.
Options to Enroll
Customers can enroll in the MyBudget program on JEA.com or over the phone with a CA. When a customer calls with questions or to enroll in MyBudget, Residential CAs use the MyBudget Validator to verify if the account qualifies for the program. Residential CAs will also use the MyBudget Validator to remove the account from MyBudget.

Payment Processing FAQs
What payment methods are fee-free?
JEA AutoPay (checking or savings account)
JEA.com or JEA Guest Pay with a checking or savings account
Pay via phone (IVR) with a checking or savings account
Pay in-person at an authorized payment locations who accept cash, check or money order.
Pay in-person using a debit card with pin at Publix, Walgreens, Walmart, Winn-Dixie, or Harveys.
Pay by mail
If a customer wants to pay by credit or debit card, should I tell them about the payment processing fee?
Yes. When transferring a customer to the
Pay by Phone
service, it is important to advise the caller of the fees to pay with credit or debit cards.
Should I advise the caller that using a banking account incurs no fee?
Yes. Always offer the fee-free option of paying with a bank account (using a routing and account number) before you transfer the call.
Why does JEA charge payment processing fees for credit and debit card payments?
The fees are not generated by JEA. These are pass-through charges that the payment vendor KUBRA charges. The fee will be charged as a separate amount/charge on the customers card statement.
What should I say to customers regarding payment processing fees?
Appropriate Customer Advisor Responses:
When the customer says,
“Can you transfer me to make a payment?”
Customer Advisor: “
Sure, payments made with a credit or debit card will be charged a processing fee, however paying with a check is fee free.”
Customer:
“How much is the fee?”
Customer Advisor:
“The max fee for a payment up-to $1,000 is $8.95. Once I transfer you to the vendors system, it will provide you the exact fee based on your payment amount.”
When the customer says,
“I want pay with my credit and/or debit card.”
Customer Advisor:
“Please be aware our payment processing vendor charges a non-refundable service fee when using a credit or debit card, the max fee for a payment up-to $1,000 is $8.95. Once I transfer you to the vendors system, it will provide you the exact fee based on your payment amount.”

Refund Eligibility for DEO Homeowner Assistance Fund (HAF) Payments
Estimated reading: 1 minute
DEO Homeowner Assistance Fund (HAF) payments cannot be returned to customers. If the customer has active service, the money must stay on the account. If the account is closed, payments from HAF must be applied to remaining balance and difference returned to the FL DEO.
This same process must be followed with all agency customer assistance.
EXAMPLE
A customer called wanting the credit (due to regular FL DEO Homeowner Assistance Fund payments) returned to her.
After researching Customer Contacts, you would find multiple Customer Service/Payment Posting Verification contacts on this account.
This is an indicator that the credit was due to agency assistance from the FL DEO HAF. Reviewing one of the contacts will confirm that the payment is agency assistance.
When a Customer Advisor encounters this situation, advise the customer that credit on an account due to agency assistance is ONLY for use in paying utilities.
The credit must be researched to determine if any of the credit is due to customer payments and not agency payments.
In this example, this customer’s request for the refund must be denied. The credit must either remain on the account or be returned to the agency.

AutoPay
Estimated reading: 7 minutes
AutoPay is a convenient payment option that the customer may select to pay their monthly JEA bill.
When an account is on AutoPay, the payment is “automatically” deducted from their selected bank account on the due date each month. The date that the payment is deducted from the customer’s bank account will vary month to month, because JEA bills in one of twenty cycles, so the due date can fluctuate a few days each month.
Customers who sign up for AutoPay will fill out a form online via JEA.com or on a paper form and submit it to JEA.
Once the account has been set up the customer will see a notice on their bill that states “Do not pay. Auto-Pay will process your payment on xx/xx/xx.” When viewing an account in CCB that is set up on Auto-Pay, you will notice the account will always have a $0 balance.
When an account on AutoPay bills each month CCB will post date a payment for the future due date of the customer’s bill.
To be eligible for AutoPay, JEA customer’s must not have an outstanding balance or be in a payment extension plan.
NOTE
AutoPay is for checking/savings accounts. If a customer wants to use a credit/debit card to automatically schedule their bill payment, they should use KUBRA Fast Pay instead.
Changing the Scheduled Draft Amount
JEA’s Receivables and Collections Services (RCS) department will be notified in CC&B to change the scheduled draft amount, even after the AutoPay amount is scheduled, if a credit is posted to the account prior to the due date.
The credit could be from an overpayment, adjustment, deposit refund, or other reason.
RCS can reduce the AutoPay draft amount by the amount of credit on the customer’s account, saving both time and inconvenience for the customer.
After an AutoPay amount is scheduled, if a credit is placed onto the customer’s account, a ToDo will be automatically created.
You can click on the ToDo alert to see that it is for the account credit.
If the ToDo is created
at least 8-days prior to the bill due date
, RCS will work the ToDo, changing the amount to be drafted from the customer’s checking or savings account. Generally, these ToDos are worked within 1-business day.
AutoPay Inquiries
If a Customer Advisor has a question about AutoPay or an AutoPay account, please refer to the contact(s) below.
Primary AutoPay Contact
:
Angie Bishop
bishaj@jea.com
Cell: (904) 496-9238
Secondary AutoPay Contact:
Christy Martin
martcm@jea.com
Cell: (904) 544-2145
Emailed AutoPay inquiries should go to Angie Bishop first with a copy to Christy Martin.
How AutoPay Works
Automatic payments will help the customer pay their bill on time. We still read the customer’s meter, calculate their bill, and send them a bill each month. The only difference is that JEA will automatically withdraw their balance due from the customer’s bank account so that they don’t have to.
AutoPay will begin on the next billing cycle after the customer signs up. The one-time authorization will continue to allow JEA to automatically withdraw the Balance Due from their bank account each month.
Once the bill is calculated, their Balance Due will be scheduled to withdraw from their account on the Due Date. When JEA prepares the customer’s bill, their Account Balance will reflect the payment has been made, although it will not withdraw from their bank account until the bill’s Due Date.
When the customer receives their bill, it will look slightly different. Instead of
Please Pay By
, we’ll show the date on which JEA will process the customer’s payment.
Click the image to enlarge.

Payment Arrangement Criteria and Creating a Payment Arrangement
Estimated reading: 7 minutes
The Pay Arrangement Validator (PAV) is a system enhancement which accesses all needed criteria within a customer’s account to systematically determine the following.
Determine an account’s Payment Arrangement eligibility
Create customer contacts based on an account’s eligibility
Create the eligible Payment Arrangement
The PAV can be accessed via the
CCB Dashboard
.
Pay Arrangement Validator (PAV) Criteria
Because Payment Agreements re-age the debt, it should be the last thing offered to a customer. When offering a payment agreement, a full account review is needed to verify that the account history supports that a customer will be able to pay the bill plus an additional installment successfully.
Below is the Payment Arrangement validation criteria used to determine if an account qualifies for a Payment Arrangement:
Payment Arrangement Eligibility Requirements
Acceptable Values
Maximum Payment Arrangement Amount
$750.00
Maximum Payment Arrangement Length
9 Months
Customer Class
RES, LIFESUPP, COMM
Internal Credit Rating Score
350 or Greater
Minimum Payment Required
Equal to or greater than 1/3 of the last billed amount; all payments since last billed are considered
Current Balance
$100 or greater after the down payment is paid
Commodity Service Agreement Age
Older than 90 days
Existing Pay Plan
No active Pay Plan exist
Existing Payment Arrangement
No active Payment Arrangement exist
Broken Payment Arrangement
Not within the past 90 days
Bankruptcy Dismissal
Not within the past 90 days
Dishonored (Returned) Payments
No returned payment in the past 30 days
Service Hold Flags
No Service Hold flags exist
Existing MyBudget
Account is not on MyBudget
Payment Arrangement Criteria
IMPORTANT
If the customer broke a Pay Plan, before granting the customer a Payment Arrangement, they must fulfill the terms and agreement of the Pay Plan by paying the full account balance.
Otherwise, the general rule to follow is if the validator will pass, you may grant the customer the arrangement.
If a PA is broken, the entire account balance will need to be paid to avoid disconnection or to restore service if it has been disconnected, unless the validator will again pass. This is a part of the terms and conditions the customer agrees to at the time the PA is created.
It is ok to remind the customer of the terms and conditions they agreed to at the time the PA was created. The IVR or collections/severance process may quote a lesser amount than the account balance. It is not a JEA error if a customer pays anything less than the entire account balance. This includes making a payment for less to stop disconnection or to TBO the service after disconnection.
Calculating the Minimum Payment Due
The Payment Arrangement Validator will specify the minimum payment due, if required. The minimum payment is calculated by 1/3 of the balance owed since the last billed date. All payments since the last billed date are considered. The customer must pay the required amount BEFORE the Payment Arrangement can be created.
Example
$372.85 recent charges
$428.79 past due amount
Total amount of the last bill balance is $801.64
$801.64 divided by 3 = $267.21
A minimum payment of $268 must be paid to meet the down payment requirement.
Never tell the customer “1/3 of the bill will need to be paid before the Pay Arrangement can be given.”
The minimum amount to be paid upfront in order to receive a Payment Arrangement is $$$. Once the down payment is made, you will need to call back so that we can create the payment arrangement for you.
Payment Arrangement Maximum Amount and Length
The maximum amount the PA can be created for is $750. In the event that the down payment amount paid does not leave the remaining balance at $750 or less, the customer will need to make a larger payment to reach the $750 threshold.
Example
$338.99 recent charges
$1266.13 past due amount
Total amount of the last bill balance is $1605.12
$1605.12 divided by 3 = $535.04
$1605.12 – $535.04 = $1070.08 balance (this is over the $750 threshold)
A minimum payment of $855.12 must be paid to meet the down payment requirement.
Customer Advisors can use the Payment Arrangement Validator to create a PA for up-to 9 months.
NOTE
JEA can grant a PA for longer than 9 months in length, however this can only be approved and created by the Assist Line or a Manager due to extreme circumstances.
Creating a Payment Arrangement Via the Validator
Once you have verified that a customer both needs a Payment Arrangement and is eligible for one, you will need to run the Payment Arrangement Validator to create the Payment Arrangement.

Billing Cycle
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
After a customer has received their initial bill they can expect to receive future bills every 28-32 days.
If payment is not received by the bill due date a 1.5% late payment charge is assessed to the owed amount four (4) days after the bill due date.
Billing Cycle Timeline
Each customer account is assigned to one of twenty billing cycles and bills are prepared for one cycle each work night (Monday –Friday).
The customer’s billing cycle is determined by their geographical location (zip code).
The exact number of days between bills, and the exact day an account is subject to severance for non-payment, may vary from month to month depending upon:
When weekends and holidays occur during the month
If there is a billing cycle reassignment
Changes in the bill processing schedule that occur whenever there is inclement weather and equipment problems
Below is the JEA Billing and Collections/Severance Timeline.

The bill is due on this day.

IMPORTANT
After starting service for a customer, CAs must provide the customer with their JEA account number and the billing zip code as part of the call closing.
NOTE
When paying with a debit/credit card, the caller will also need the zip code for the billing address to the card. This zip code may not be the same as the one that JEA is providing to them. Kubra also requires that the bank account (checking, savings, credit, or debit) the customer is using to make the payment is a US bank account.
Determine the Billing Zip Code for New Accounts
When creating an account using the Start Process script a
mailing address
is required for all customers.
If the customer elects for his/her mailing address as the premise they are starting …
Then the billing zip code needed to make a Deposit payment with Kubra is the premise zip code.
If the customer elects for his/her mailing address to be an address different from the premise …
Then the billing zip code needed to make a Deposit payment with Kubra is the zip code for the inputted mailing address.
IMPORTANT
When paying a Deposit for a New account, Kubra will advise the customer that they have a $0 balance or a credit. Then it will prompt the caller to press 2 to make a payment anyway. It is important to advise the caller to wait for the prompt to press 2 and continue in the process of making the payment.

Payment Refunds
Estimated reading: 6 minutes
Customer Advisors can process and request that available credits on a customer’s account be refunded. The method by which the refund is requested and processed is determined by several factors:
The type of payment which made the credit
The age of the credit
The amount of the credit
IMPORTANT
In order to receive a refund from JEA the account must have a credit balance.
If a customer pays more than their desired amount, but not enough to generate a credit on the account, no refund can be issued.
Review the table below to learn more about what you can and cannot refund.
Payment Type
Refundable
Responsibility
Cash
Yes, Immediately
Less than $100: Customer Advisors
$100+: Credit Refund Case
Check/ACH
Yes, After 10 Business Days
Less than $100: Customer Advisors
$100+: Credit Refund Case
Credit Card
Verify via CART
OR
90 Days via Check
CART or Manager Only
Debit Card
Verify via CART
OR
45 Days via Check
CART or Manager Only
Check/ACH Refunds: At JEA’s discretion documentation on the customers’ bank letter head providing details that the payment has in fact cleared the customers bank account may be accepted to waive the 10 business day waiting period.
Credit/Debit Refunds: The customer does have the option to contact the bank who issued the card and request the payment be canceled. This will cause the JEA account to be accessed an infraction and a $20 returned payment fee.

Voucher credits must either stay on a customer’s account (active customer) or be returned to the issuing agency (stopping services).

IF THE CUSTOMER IS STOPPING SERVICES, INFORM THE CUSTOMER THAT ANY LEFTOVER AGENCY FUNDS WILL BE RETURNED TO THE AGENCY; WE CANNOT ISSUE AGENCY FUNDS TO A CUSTOMER.

Broken Payment Arrangement
Estimated reading: 1 minute
Once a Payment Arrangement breaks, the only amount stated to the caller should be the entire account balance. Anything less than the entire account balance is not enough to keep service active. CCB may quote a lesser amount on the IVR or in the collections and severance process for the customer to restore their service. It is NOT a JEA error if a customer pays anything less than the entire account balance, this includes making a payment for less to stop disconnection, or to TBO the service after disconnection.
CAs can view Historical Broken Pay Arrangements in the
Control Central
panel,
Pay Plan Tree
tab.
Pay Plan Tree Tab
Expand Zone Button
End Date
NOTE
In the event that an arrangement is going to break, but has yet to break, it will not be visible in
Historical Broken Pay Arrangements
until it physically breaks. In this situation, you should inform the customer that it is possible that the PA will break, but that you cannot see that it has broken in the system as of yet. This is especially common when a customer has missed their bill due date.

Budget Billing
Estimated reading: 1 minute
Budget Billing
is a retired JEA Program similar to MyBudget. The primary difference between the two programs is that with Budget Billing the payment is the same, every month for 12 consecutive months, whereas the payment changes from month-to-month with MyBudget.
Identifying a Budget Billing Customer
You can identify a Budget Billing customer by noticing that their monthly payment is the same every month until it changes on an annual basis:
Budget Bill Amount
Budget Billing True Up
You can manage a customer’s Budget Billing account using the MyBudget Validator.
IMPORTANT
If you remove a customer from Budget Billing, or if they leave the program via JEA.com, they will be UNABLE to rejoin the now-retired program. However, they can re-enroll with MyBudget.

Bill Cycle Change
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
From time to time you may receive requests from customers to change the due date of their JEA bills.
This is something that should not be offered to customers, but
MUST
be initiated by the customer.
Customers can change the due date of the bill by changing the billing cycle; when the bill prints within a different cycle, it may also change the due date to their liking. There are two billing cycles that have been established to accept these requests.
Available Bill Cycles
There are only two cycles that you can offer to a customer when they are questing to change the due date of their JEA bills:
Cycle 6:
for any customer requesting a due date between the
15th and the 31st
Cycle 11:
for any customer requesting a due date between the
31st and 15th
Qualifications for a Bill Cycle Change
CAs should use the following criteria to qualify the account for a bill cycle change request:
Customer must request the cycle change
Credit score must be 300 or above
Customer can change the cycle 1 time in the life of the account
The account has to be current with no past due amount
If a customer has requested a bill cycle change you will find a Customer Contact acknowledging the change. If the change was systematic you may not see a Customer Contact; refer to the customers bill to see the change.
NOTE
If the customers existing bill due date is within two weeks, advise the customer to first pay the bill before submitting the bill cycle change request.

Intro to CCB (A)
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
JEA serves approximately 500,000(+) customers in various capacities. To ensure that we provide accurate billing and store customer information in a secure location that protects their confidentiality, we use the Customer Care and Billing system (CCB). CCB is a customer management system that allows us to maintain customer information and track the history of customer accounts.

Creating a Customer Contact & Required Info
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
Customer Contacts are created to capture key information and detail conversations between the JEA Representative and the customer.
A Customer Contact MUST be created anytime you access the customer’s account.
The contact should be high level of what the call was about with important details that will help the next CA, should the customer need to call back. Think about what you would want to know if you were the next CA the customer spoke with.
REMEMBER
If it’s not documented, it didn’t happen!
Required Information for a Customer Contact
It is required to capture the following information, at a minimum, in every Customer Contact record.
The caller’s name
The reason for the call; a high level overview
Details such as addresses, balances quoted, dates, deposits quoted, start option fees charged, pay plan or pay arrangement details, etc.
The reason for the call; a high level overview
Your 4+2
Your phone extension

Start Process Link

Search Options
The following tabs provide more information on each Search Option.
Search by Name
Search by Address
Search by Account ID
Search by Phone Number
Search by ID Type
Wild Card
The Name field is used to search for an account entering all or part of the person’s name. The name search is not case sensitive, however all information documented in CCB should be entered in all CAPS for example:
LASTNAME,FIRSTNAME MI
Notice no spaces exist between the last name and the first name, just a comma. When searching by name, it is best to search by first and last name only.
If the customer’s name consists of Sr. Jr., or III, the suffix must be positioned at the end of the name. To do this, enter the suffix in the suffix box once you are on the Account Entry page.
EXAMPLE:
SMITH,RYAN JR
or
JOHNSON,BRIAN III
The Address field is used to search for a Premise or Account using the first line of a service address. You can enter all or part of the first line of the address. Keep in mind; sometimes less is more when it comes to searching.
For example, if you’re looking for
10960 Beach Blvd Lot 10
, you can enter
10960%10
rather than the entire address.
The Account ID field is used to locate information using an account number.
NOTE: The Account ID cannot be combined with other search fields.
You can enter all or part of the account number in the Account ID field and press Enter or the Search Button.
EXAMPLE: If you’re looking for account
1929119291
; you can enter that number-
“192 911 9291”
and the account will display.
If your search criteria results in a single or multiple customer account being retrieved, click the desired account by name or address and the Account Entry page will be displayed.
When using the Phone Number field to search for an account using one of the telephone numbers linked to the account.
Enter 10 digit numbers as a continuous string of numbers. The system will format the phone number for you.
The ID Type field is used to search for an account using one of the Person’s IDs listed in the account.
When you enter a Person’s ID type to do a search you must enter both an identifier type and value (number).
An Identifier Type is the type of ID used
A value for the Identifier Type is the number listed on the form of ID.
Enter the Person’s ID type in the format dictated by the identifier type (if applicable) and press
Enter
or the
Search Button
.
The system displays every person with the input ID in the search results.
ID Types include:
Alien ID
Drivers License
Federal Employer #
Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN)
Military ID
Passport
Social Security Number
State ID
Web User Name
A Wild Card search allows you to locate account information in CC&B when you do not have all the information needed to locate the record.
The wild card character is the % symbol and represents any number or character.
Using Wild Card
The system automatically “wild cards” the end of all searches.
For example, if you enter 21 W CH in the address field you would get the same result as if you typed 21 W CH%. Both searches will populate 21 W CHURCH ST.
Wild Card With Apartments, Lot Numbers, or Suites
The most common wild card search will be used with apartment complex addresses.
For example, if you enter 3875%101 in the Address Search Field, the system will find all addresses that start with 3875 [with something in-between, like a street name] and then 101.
Therefore, an example like 3875 San Pablo Rd S Apt 101 would populate.
If you enter 3875%San in the Address Search Field, the system will find all addresses that start with 3875 [with something in-between] and then San. In this example you wild carded a space; therefore the system will retrieve EVERY apartment number at 3875 San Pablo Rd.
When searching for a customer you will use one or more of the available search options as needed to best assist you in locating the correct account.
For a New or Returning Customer the best results will be displayed by searching by Name and Social Security Number.
For an Existing Customer (someone who has active service agreements with JEA) the best results could be displayed by searching by Address or Phone number.
Search Results

Premise Info
column that will help you identify your customer type.
Has Premise Information
No Premise Information
Blank Premise Information

Cases (A)
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
Cases are created when additional offline work is needed to complete a customer’s request.
Cases are sent to various departments such as CART (Customer Advocacy Resolution Team), Billing Support, and Receivables & Collection Service (RCS) to be completed.
Cases are primarily created the same way. The only differences in creating cases are based on the tasks they are meant to communicate and the information required, such as the following.
Characteristic Types
Characteristic Values
Comments you enter into the Comments and Log fields
Characteristic Types and Values
Each Case has specific
Characteristics Types
and
Characteristic Values
.
You will enter the Characteristic Value for each Characteristic Type on every case. This is the additional information needed to complete the case.
Some case Characteristic Values have
Search For
buttons and some are free form.
No matter what the Characteristic Type is you never change them. For example, you may need to add additional characteristic types on the
Deposit Review
case, but other than that, you do not change the types, you only enter the Characteristic Value for each Characteristic Type listed on the case.
The only case without Characteristics is the
Misc Case
. This case has no characteristics because it is just that, miscellaneous. The
Misc Case
requires
Comments
so that the CART team member understands the action that you are requesting.
Comments for the Log
The comments you enter assist the department who will be completing the case. They will be different on each case to reflect the situation.
Instructions are NOT required to be entered into the Comments field; they just give the person working the case a quicker look at what you are asking them to complete, without having to go to the Log tab.
Comments Field vs. Log:
The instructions in the comments field can be changed at any time, even after the case is completed.
Instructions are required to be entered into the Log; the Log cannot be changed once saved.

Other Cases
Other cases that Customer Advisors may create are referenced below. The process/steps for creating each of these cases is the same as other cases; the Case Type, Characteristics, and ToDos will vary.
Credit Bureau Modification
Exceptional Request
No Bill
Stored Bank Account Removal Request
Case Type:
CREDITBUREAU
This case is created when a JEA error has occurred (final mailing address invalid, misapplied payment from JEA error, etc.) you can request for the customer’s external credit with Experian be updated or the reported write-off be removed.
IMPORTANT
Full account balance payment is required before this case can be created.
This case is NOT used to remove a negative reporting from a customer’s credit history just because they have now paid their debt in full. Negative credit reporting will generally stay on a credit history for 7 years.
When speaking with a customer who is requesting to modify their credit after they have paid the account balance in full, please review the items below BEFORE submitting a Credit Modification case:
Allow 30-60 days after the paid date for the account to update with the credit bureau; this will also improve account accuracy.
Advise the customer that their credit score will be updated by the credit bureau to show PAID-CHARGE OFF or PAID-COLLECTION.
Paid-Charge Off means the company has written off debt because it does not believe that it will receive the money that it was owed.
Paid-Collection means that a balance was paid within 30-60 days after referral; it will be reported by the credit bureau as paid.
JEA will only remove the paid collection or paid charge off if it’s a JEA error; for example, the final bill was mailed to the wrong address, or the final bill was reported to a collection agency after the customer paid in-full.
Only at management discretion, the account may be reviewed to determine if/if not the credit could be removed.
Case Type:
RSH_EXCEPTNL
Exceptional Requests are non-account related issues relating to JEA which are considered to be complicated and require time to research and/or technical knowledge of the subject matter.
Examples of Exceptional Request are:
Facility/Easement maintenance (complaint about landscaping at a lift station)
Poles (laying on the ground and not removed)
JEA vehicles – Customer unsure but thinks a JEA vehicle turned around in their driveway cracking it (need truck or tag# and description)
IMPORTANT
Rehab issues and barricades are not exceptional requests. Refer the customer directly to 665-8431.
Rehab takes 10 to 14 business days for completion.
Concrete and landscape work is done by different contractors; therefore one may be done before the other.
Barricades are normally not removed until all rehab is complete.
When JEA has replaced a pole, we cannot remove the old pole until AT&T and/or Comcast has moved their lines to the new pole.
Billing related issues are not exceptional requests and will be returned to the Customer Advisor for handling and the case will be closed.
Case Type:
RSH_NOBILL
The No Bill case can be created by a Customer Advisors when an account has multiple premises and one or more of the addresses did not yet bill because it is not on the same billing cycle.
The No Bill case will notify CART to have the bill cycle changed so that all of addresses are on the same billing cycle. After the billing cycle has been updated and all of the addresses bill under the same billing cycle, the bill may contain a “catch-up” for the cycle which was changed.
NOTE
If we align the customer’s bill cycles with the case, it DOES count as their “1 bill cycle change” request limit.
Case Type:
REMSTRBKACCT
This case is to be used when requesting to remove stored banking account saved via the IVR.
If customer is requesting to update, they can enter new checking info which will remove the existing one.
Generally, this is to be used in cases where a third party (friend, family, etc) accidentally saved their info and wants it removed.

Collection, Severance & Reconnection (B)
Estimated reading: 1 minute
The process of disconnecting a customer because of non-pay is followed through by the
Collection
and
Severance
processes.
Collection
Severance
When an account is not paid by the bill due date the Collection process will start. This process occurs at day 29 of the billing cycle timeline.
At this point in the billing cycle late fees have ben assessed and the customer is at risk for disconnection due to non-pay.
Once the number of days for the Collection process has expired and no payment or agreement to pay has been established the Severance process is triggered. This process occurs on (or after) day 43 of the billing cycle timeline.
It is possible to “stop” the Severance process from completing if a payment is made before the disconnection is triggered.
The options that a customer has will vary, depending on where they are within the processes. For example, customers in
Collection
may be eligible for a Pay Plan, but if the
Severance
process has completed, they are NOT eligible.
The account and age of the debt will have to be evaluated to determine the available options for the customer.

Intro to Severance Process
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
Once the number of days for the Collection process has expired and no payment or agreement to pay has been established the Severance process is triggered. This occurs on day 42 of the bill cycle timeline.
The system will automatically send an disconnection activity for non-pay. The account is now in
Severance
.
Severance Alert
The Severance process is shown as an Alert on the Customer Validation page when using the Start Process script.
If the account qualifies, there will be an option to create a Pay Plan for the delinquent balance and avoid further severance actions.
Severance Process Active Alert
Pay Plan Eligibility
Field Notification
Under extraordinary circumstances, JEA personnel at their discretion may provide a Field Notification in lieu of Severance.
In this instance the Field Technician will advise the customer of an impending request for severance.
A charge of $5.00 is assessed for this service and the customer is given an opportunity to pay the delinquent balance before actual severance takes place.
IMPORTANT
Never advise a customer that the disconnection is at the discretion of the Field Technician, as this is an internal process
High Risk Customers
Customers are considered “High Risk” when their credit score drops to 700 or below.
JEA will attempt to provide the customer or account agent/occupant a notice via letter, email, and automated telephone call.
If the customer calls the call center, a CA will inform them of the severance process on their account, monthly statement, or forty-eight (48) hour notice prior to expedited severance request for all scenarios except for the following.
Broken Pay Plans
Broken Payment Arrangements
Theft and other unauthorized or violation situations on their account
With all customers, any Payment Arrangement or Pay Plan not honored will result in expedited severance with no additional notice.

Collection Process
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
The Collection process involves the following stages:
A late notice on the next bill that prints (Normally 2-3 days after the Collection process begins).
Disconnection Notice letter is issued to the customer by mail.
Phone Master Trigger will contact the phone # on the account to advise that a payment has still not been received and the service will be scheduled for disconnection.
Customer Advisors can observe that an account is in an active Collection process by following the steps below.
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
From CCB, click on the
Collections Process Active
link in the
Dashboard
.
Look for the date to pay-by as:
Event – Pending, Start Severance Process, XX-XX-XXXX
Quote to the customer the DAY BEFORE the provided date.
Look for the amount to pay listed as:
Debt Class – E/W/S, Dep, PymtArg,Products,Current Balance: $XXX, Delinquent Debt: $XXX
The
Delinquent Debt
amount is the amount you quote the customer to pay to avoid disconnection.
Review the customer’s Bill/Letters; if there is a different due-date on the bill or letter, quote that date instead as the pay-by date.
IMPORTANT
When talking to the customer about the account being past due, never use the internal JEA lingo of “Collection Balance”.
Saying “Collection Balance” to the customer may lead them to believe that we have sent their account to a collection agency, which we have not in this scenario.

Reconnection, Fees & RCD Lag
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
JEA will reconnect service on an account severed for non-payment if the customer satisfies the arrears amount with payment.
If the customer makes sufficient payment by 6:00 p.m., JEA will schedule the meter reconnection the same day.
Any payments received after 6:00 p.m. will be reconnected within 24 hours of receipt of payment.
There are fees associated with every reconnection.
Meter Reconnection Fee:
$14 per meter
Electric can be remote or at the meter; water is only at meter.
Pole Reconnection Fee:
$25
NOTE
If the customer was disconnected at the utility pole, the reconnection process can take 24-48 hours to complete.
RCD Lag Timeframes
Customers may contact JEA with the status of their reconnection; we call this a
reconnection inquiry
. A reconnection inquiry refers specifically to customers who have been disconnected RCD for non-pay and contact us to tell us their services have yet to be restored. As always, RCD service restorations will take place on the same-day as long as the required payment was made by 6:00PM.
If the customer calls to inquiry on the reconnection status during the 11:30AM – 05:00PM timeframe …
You should verify that the customer has made the required payment to restore services, or that they have made other satisfactory payment options on the account such as a Payment Arrangement.
Verify that the TBO (Turn Back On) FA (Field Activity) was created and/or completed.
If the TBO FA was created and completed, have the customer check their breakers.
If the TBO FA was not created or is in a pending or cancelled status, kindly ask the customer to follow back up with us after 5:00PM if they are not yet restored.
If the customer calls to inquiry on the reconnection status before 11:30AM or after 05:00PM …
You should
still
verify that the customer has made the required payment to restore services, or that they have made other satisfactory payment options on the account such as a Payment Arrangement.
At least 15 minutes need to have elapsed from the time of the payment.
Verify that the TBO Field Activity was created and/or completed.
If the TBO FA was created and completed, have the customer check their breakers.
If the TBO FA was created and is in a pending or cancelled status, you may see a “Time-to-live” or “Please investigate” in the Instructions box (see examples below). C&D will work these errors to have the customer restored.
IMPORTANT
Do not create another FA
. Reassure the customer that the restoration order is in process.
Only if the TBO FA was NOT created, contact the Assist Line or a Manager to create an M-RECONN (Traditional customer) or M-RECEPP (MyWay customer) FA.
Example pending FA with “Time-to-live” in the Instructions box:
Click the image to enlarge.
Example cancelled FA with “Please investigate” in the Instructions box:
Click the image to enlarge.
Reconnection After a Returned Payment
JEA will reconnect service to an account severed for a dishonored payment if the customer satisfies the past due amount with payment by cash or certified funds.
If the Severance is due to a second returned check in a nine (9) month period, the customer will be required to make all payments by cash or certified funds for a minimum of nine (9) months, or by debit or credit card online or by phone.

Intro to Collections Process
Estimated reading: 1 minute
When an account is not paid by the due date, the Collection process will start. This process occurs at day 29 of the billing cycle time line.
The Collection process involves the following stages.
A late notice on the next bill that prints (normally 2-3 days after the collection process begins).
Disconnection notice letter is the
Delinquency Letter
.
Phone Master Trigger will contact the phone # on the account to advise that a payment has still not been received and the service will be scheduled for disconnection at any time.
Start Severance process will close the Collection process and trigger the Severance.
Collection Alert
The Collection process is shown as an Alert on the
Customer Validation
page when using the Start Process script.
If the account qualifies, there will be an option to create a Pay Plan for the delinquent balance and avoid further collection actions.
Collections Process Active Alert
Pay Plan Enroll Button

Severance Process
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
When an account goes into Severance an order has been sent to disconnect the service points. The Severance alert will show in the customer’s Dashboard. The customer must make a payment or a Pay Plan can be offered if qualified. Once the service is off the account no longer qualifies for the a Pay Plan, however they may be eligible for a Payment Arrangement.
The Severance link in the
Dashboard
will give the amount that is needed to restore the customer’s service or cancel the disconnection.
Customer Advisors can observe that an account is in an active Severance process by following the steps below.
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
From CCB, click on the
Severance Process Active
link in the
Dashboard
.
Look for the amount to pay listed as:
Debt Class – E/W/S, Dep, PymtArg,Products,Current Balance: $xxx, Delinquent Debt: $xxx
The
Delinquent Debt
amount is the amount you quote the customer to pay to avoid disconnection.
There is no “date” because the customer is already up-for disconnection, the payment needs to be made as soon as possible to cancel the disconnection process.
Review the
Account Panel – Financial Balance
tab to see the age and debt of the Service Agreements to give the customer an accurate break down of the past due balance.
NOTE
If there is a broken Pay Plan or Payment Arrangement on the account, the customer can pay the amount in severance to restore the service, however, the full balance is still needed to ensure a new Severance process will not trigger tomorrow.

If the customer is at risk for disconnection, and the customer informs you that they have filed Bankruptcy, creating the case will automatically place a Pay Plan with a due date of 7 calendar days on the customer’s account, even if they are not eligible for a Pay Plan using the validator.
The JEA RCS team will be notified when the case is created; they will attempt to confirm the Bankruptcy filing.

Deceased Customer (B)
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
In the event of the death of an account holder, a customer may call proactively after the loss of a loved one and request an account name change or to stop service.
In this scenario, you will need to complete several steps to insure service is put in the responsible party’s name or service is stopped to prevent possible loss of revenue for JEA.
Verification of death is not a part of this process; JEA does not require “proof” or documentation to complete the deceased customer processes.

Name Change
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
A name change may be needed on an account. A customer may change their name due to the following reasons:
Marriage
Divorce
Death (In-Full)
Legal Name Change
When a customer requests us to update their name, before you request documentation, first contact the Assist Line or your Manager to verify their identity in Accurint. If the name change is verifiable via Accurint, then we do not need any documentation. You may change the name and note the customer contact.
If Documentation is Needed
If the name is not updated in Accurint, then request the customer to email you the legal documentation i.e., marriage license, divorce paper, court records. Remind the customer that for their protection, we CANNOT accept confidential and/or sensitive information such as:
Social Security Card
Any State or Government Issued ID Card such as a Driver’s License, State Issue ID, or U.S. Alien ID (aka Green Card)
US Passport or Foreign Passport
Federal or State Tax Forms
If you have any questions about delivering a document to JEA that contains PII, please contact Revenue Assurance at extension 6330 for guidance.

Power of Attorney (POA)
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
A power of attorney (POA) is a legal document giving one person (the agent or attorney-in-fact) the power to act for another person (the principal). The agent can have broad legal authority or limited authority to make legal decisions about the principal’s property, finances or medical care. The power of attorney is frequently used in the event of a principal’s illness or disability, or when the principal can’t be present to sign necessary legal documents for financial transactions.
A power of attorney can end for a number of reasons, such as when the principal dies, the principal revokes it, a court invalidates it, the principal divorces his/her spouse who happens to be the agent or the agent can no longer carry out the outlined responsibilities.
If a caller states that they have a POA for an existing JEA customer, the POA and JEA account information should be sent to the CART team.
Emailing a POA
Mailing a POA
Faxing a POA

YOUR
email address, then you can forward it to:
jeacrm@jea.com
(do NOT give email address to customer)
The POA and JEA account information can be mailed to:

Jacksonville, FL 32202
The POA and JEA account information can be faxed to:
(904) 665-7990

caller
:

Agrees to send legal documentation via Fax or Email
The
Customer Advisor
:
Verifies the PoA’s information using Knowledge IQ
Requests the PoA send the legal documents via Fax or Email to the Correspondence team
Searches CCB to identify whether the customer has an existing account, is returning or new to JEA
Conducts a credit and identity check and verifies that the customer is not deceased
If the customer is deceased, the PoA is null and void
Adheres to Deposits requirements
The
Correspondence Team
:
Receives and reviews the legal documentation
Verifies the power of attorney documents allow for financial matters
*
Verifies the PoA’s information noted in the contact notes matches the paperwork
Conducts a credit and identity check and verifies that the customer is not deceased
*
*Note
PoA documents that only address healthcare matters do not qualify for financial responsibilities
If the Request is Handled In-Person …
The
person
:
Presents legal documentation indicating their role as PoA
*
Provides valid identification
*Note
Legal documentation will include the customer’s name and date of birth information. If the customer’s social security number is not included, the PoA will provide.
The
Customer Advisor
:
Reviews the legal document(s)
Verifies the power of attorney documents allow for financial matters
*
Verifies the identification and PoA’s name match on the paperwork
Searches CCB to identify whether the customer has an existing account, is returning or new to JEA
Conducts a credit and identity check and verifies that the customer is not deceased
*
Adheres to deposits requirements
*Note
PoA documents that only address healthcare matters do not qualify for financial responsibilities
*Note
If the customer is deceased, the PoA is null and void
