48-Hour Notice
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
The 48-hour notice is the process of a Customer Advisor requesting that a JEA field notification be delivered to the address(‘s) of the deceased customer. This will give the person(‘s) at the addresses time to contact JEA to place service in their name, if they wish to do so. Creating the activity for the 48-hour notice does not stop service, it only gets the process started of potentially stopping services, preventing additional revenue loss to JEA.
The Instructions box must contain specific verbiage so that the technician is aware that the request is for the deceased process.
OPTION 2- CUSTOMER TO CALL 665-6000, 7:00AM-6:00PM PER DECEASED PROCESS
Activity Type
Service Date/Time
Instructions Box
48-Hour Notice Door Hanger and Completion
After creating the field activity a notice will be left at the address(‘s).
A Door Hanger is used by JEA to communicate there is a need to contact JEA and allow a responsible party time to apply for service prior to JEA disconnecting service.
Option 2
After the 48-hour notice activity has been delivered the activity is “completed” by the technician.
In the event JEA is not contacted by a
Responsible Party
to apply for service, the following steps will then be taken by JEA:
Revenue Assurance (RA) will review to determine if services have been placed into another persons name or account.
If no one has applied for service after one week, RA will submit a request for all active service agreements on the account to be stopped.
RA will flag the address(‘s) once the service is off.

Account & Customer Types
Estimated reading: 4 minutes
The
Start Process
script is used to create new accounts and maintain existing accounts.
An account is the entity in which a bill is created. Account information controls when bills are created and the manner in which they are formatted. The account holds financial information including balances, deposits, and budget amounts.
NOTE
Residential customers should only have one account number. There are a few exceptions in which a customer may have more than one account number.
Every account must reference at least one main person, and may reference an Authorized User.
Most customers are linked to at least one account; however, there are instances where an individual could be linked to many accounts. For example, a landlord who has a personal account as well as one tied to their properties.
Account Types
Use the following steps to review infractions and demerits on an account.
There are two account types.
Residential
Commercial
The services being rendered are billed to a private individual or household. There are some customers who have more than one personally owned residence and others that own a small quantity of less than ten (10) residences that they utilize as rental properties; if all of the services are consolidated on one bill along with their personal residence the account can still retain the status of Residential.
A non-residential account (i.e. schools, apartment complexes, government agencies, etc.) that purchases utility services from JEA. The relationship with these entities is managed differently than our residential accounts due to their need for greater consumption of electric and/or water.
Customer Types
There are three types of customers that you either create or maintain.
New Customer
Established Customer
Deceased Customer
A person or entity purchasing electric and/or water from JEA for the first time.
A person or entity that currently has or previously had an account with JEA.
There are two types of Established Customers.
Good Customer
High Risk Customer
Established Good Customer
Established High Risk Customer
To be qualified as an established customer with good customer characteristics, the customer must fulfill the following requirements:
Must have has continuous residential service with JEA for a minimum of 6 months on an active account
Must have a JEA internal credit score greater than 700
The established high risk customer is characterized by the following:
Excessive non-sufficient funds
Disconnection for Non-Pay
Broken Payment Arrangements
Bankruptcy
Write-Offs
Utilization of Utility services without the appropriate service agreements
Failure to fully meet JEA security deposit requirements
An internal credit score that is 700 or below
A Deceased Customer is a customer who has passed away.
In the event of the death of a customer the account will be transferred to the individual seeking to assume responsibility for the account.
The customer may be calling proactively after the loss of a loved one, or they may be calling because they received a letter for JEA about the deceased person’s account status.
At times you will learn throughout conversation with the customer that their loved one has passed. When we have identified that the account holder is deceased the account must be changed into a living person’s name.
Calls received on a deceased customers account should be transferred to Full Service (Billing).
If an established customer is either voluntarily or involuntarily terminated and wishes to return for new or reactivated service with JEA, they will be reassigned the account number initially created for their use by JEA. There are a few exceptions:
Home/Rental accounts
Bankruptcy
Fraud
MyWay Accounts

Individual Taxpayer Identification Number
An Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN)/ Tax ID Number is a tax processing number issued by the Internal Revenue Service. The IRS issues ITINs to individuals who are required to have a U.S. taxpayer identification number but who do not have, and are not eligible to obtain, a Social Security number (SSN) from the Social Security Administration (SSA).
People who do not have a citizenship in the United States may obtain an ITIN. These people are lawfully in the country and must pay taxes but may not be eligible for a SSN so they obtain an ITIN.
The ITIN/Tax Number has nine (9) digits just like the Social Security Number (SSN) does.
IMPORTANT
Individual Taxpayer Identification numbers/Tax numbers are not Social Security numbers.
The ITIN is a nine-digit number that ALWAYS begins with the number 9 and has a 7 or 8 in the fourth digit, for example 9XX-7X-XXXX.
You can create an account over the phone if the caller is providing you with an ITIN. You must contact Revenue Assurance (ext. 6330) to validate the customer’s identity. Be prepared to provide RA with the ITIN and a valid passport number.
If Revenue Assurance was not able to verify the customer’s identity, you will click Deposit Quote Only. RA will provide you instructions about how to proceed with service activation.

Account Without an SSN (Passport Process)
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
The call center cannot create an account without a valid Social Security Number (SSN). Fortunately, other departments can.
Revenue Assurance (RA) can verify a customer’s identity with a valid Passport and create an account on behalf of the Customer Advisor (CA).
Collecting the Required Information
When the customer requesting service does not have SSN, the CA will collect:
Customer’s name
DOB
Passport Number
Passport Country of Issuance
IMPORTANT
This information needs to be obtained prior to contacting RA.
Revenue Assurance Creates the Account
With the provided information from the CA, RA will create the account and attempt to verify the passport information provided.
If RA is unable to validate the passport information, a 2 forms of ID alert will be placed on the account and the customer will be instructed to present two forms of valid ID in person.
Acceptable Forms of ID
If the customer does not have a passport or RA cannot verify the information provided, advise them to visit the CSC with two forms of valid ID.
Forms of ID accepted:
I-94
I-551
Parole Stamp/document
ITIN (original) document
Any U.S. Department of Homeland Security documentation that is valid
US Customs & Immigration Order of Recognizance
USCIS document issued by ICE (Immigration & Customs Enforcement) to be reviewed for validity.
SSN card
Student visa document(s)
Temporary visas issued for employment
IMPORTANT
U.S. Visa by itself is a primary form of ID (if NOT expired).
After RA Creates the Account
After the caller is verified, RA will create the account. The account number will be provided to the CA. The CA will then quote the required deposit and proceed with a Deposit Quote Only Process or the Scheduled Pending Start Process.

The caller is a

processes.

Bankruptcy (A)
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
Bankruptcy is a legal process which allows a person (a “Debtor”), who owes more money than he or she can currently repay, to either (1) repay a portion of the money over time under Chapter 11, 12, or 13, or (2) have the entire debt forgiven (“discharged”) under chapter 7. Under chapter 7, a Debtor may be required to surrender assets to a trustee. Bankruptcy is also available to businesses, corporations, and partnerships. Even municipal governments can file bankruptcy (under Chapter 9).
After a Debtor has filed a case (i.e., “petition”), creditors must stop all collection efforts against the Debtor for a period of time, unless they get permission from the bankruptcy court to continue. This protection from collection efforts is referred to as the “automatic stay.”
The Bankruptcy Code and Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure determine which chapter one is eligible to file, which debts can be eliminated, how long repayment must continue, which possessions can be kept, etc. A Debtor must abide by these federal laws and rules.
This page defines the different types of bankruptcy and how JEA accounts are managed in these scenarios.
Customer Informs JEA of Bankruptcy Filed
If a caller is informing you that they have filed Bankruptcy, you will create the
Bankruptcy Filed
case in CCB.
If the customer is at risk for disconnection, and the customer informs you that they have filed Bankruptcy, creating the xase will automatically place a Pay Plan with a due date of 7 calendar days on the customer’s account, even if they are not eligible for a Pay Plan using the validator.
The JEA RCS Collections Team will be notified when the case is created; they will attempt to confirm the Bankruptcy filing.

RCS Bankruptcy Processing Procedures and Definitions
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
JEA will receive “Notice of Bankruptcy Filings” from the US Bankruptcy Courts. The notice advises JEA that the customer will not be responsible for paying amounts owed to JEA prior to the filing date. JEA files a claim with the bankruptcy court in an attempt to recover any amounts owed to JEA if there are available assets to allocate. JEA then closes the “Pre-petition” account to prevent any additional charges to the account in bankruptcy. Then JEA opens a
post-petition
account to record consumption of utilities, billings, and payments received in the future. The Post-petition account includes DIP (Debtor in Possession) in the account title for Chapter 13 bankruptcy filings.
Bankruptcy Term
Definition
Petition-Date
Date in which bankruptcy was filed.
Pre-Petition Account
Account created before customer filed bankruptcy.
Post-Petition Account
Account created after customer filed bankruptcy.

Bankruptcy & Starting Service
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
If a customer needs to start service and their account is in a bankruptcy status, follow the guidelines below.
Status:
Pending
Chapter 7 or 13
Chapter 11
Create a new account
Determine the deposit amount. The deposit amount should be the greater of the deposit or the minimum deposit amount.
Quote the customer the deposit amount and advise of payment options.
Email appropriate RCS contact the post-petition account numbers.
Start the service on the new account.
Create a detailed Customer Contact.
Refer the account to the appropriate RCS contact for review.
Status:
Dismissed
Locate the customer’s account in CCB and verify that no other active account exists. Start service on the account with dismissed bankruptcy characteristics.
If the customer has more than one outstanding account, all debt must be transferred to the account where service will be started (regardless of the 4 year rule).
Create a Recovery Transfer Req – RCS Case to have the balance transferred from the Dismissed Bankruptcy Account to the other account. Be sure to state the case is based on a Dismissed Bankruptcy.
Use the account the money is transferred to as the one to start the new service (or the active account).
Quote the customer the deposit amount plus the outstanding balance and advise of payment options.
Start the service on the existing account once the amount is paid in full and the recovery case has been successfully entered.
Remove all bankruptcy characteristics and dismissed bankruptcy alerts.
Status:
Discharged
A new account must be created in order to start service.
Quote the customer the deposit amount and advise of payment options.
Start the service on the new account once the deposit is paid in full.
Create a detailed Customer Contact.

Spouse or Authorized User Add-On
Once added, the Spouse and Authorized User have the same access and authority as the primary account holder. The Spouse or Authorized User will have full access to make changes to the service; up to and including starting or stopping service.
The Spouse and/or Authorized User do not have authority to request Experian or Knowledge IQ to be ran on the account holder, nor do they have authorization to add or update SSN/DOB information; this applies to their own SSN/DOB and the account holder’s SSN/DOB.
IMPORTANT
If searching in CCB, you must search by Name and Full SSN. The Script will automatically do this for you. If a balance is found while searching for the Spouse or Authorized user in you will need to determine if it is a collectible balance. Once verified it is collectible you will need to inform the customer and provide this information to the Assist Line.
Also, the current account holder must be verified as a “beneficial user” at the time the debt was accumulated.
If it is deemed that the balance should be transferred from the Spouse or Authorized User to the Active Account Holder, advise the customer of this. Payment options may be provided at that time.

The Spouse or Authorized User can remove themselves from an account as long as they are able to verify their own information (Name, Last 4 SSN, and DOB).

JEA eBill Add-On
All accounts with active Service Agreements will bill monthly. Customers can choose to receive their bill in the mail on a monthly basis, or they can choose to receive an email alert that their bill is ready to be viewed at jea.com.
When a customer elects to receive their bill via eBill it is still important to also have a valid mailing address. When an account is on eBill only the monthly bill is sent online. All other correspondence is mailed. Examples that will still be sent by traditional mail service include collection process letters, infraction notices, deposit refunds, and collection agency notices.
Electing eBill
Removing eBill
During the process of creating a new JEA account, or when updating a customers information, the account can be enrolled into eBill through the Script. Check the box for
The customer accepts electronic bill
and the customer will be enrolled into JEA eBill.
When updating a customers information the account can be removed from eBill through the Script. Uncheck the box for
The customer accepts electronic bill
and the customer will be removed from JEA eBill.
Always verify the
Mailing Address
when removing a customer from eBill.
The Script will confirm that eBill has been removed.
NOTE
Customers can also setup and remove themselves from eBill on jea.com.
Password Add-On
A password should be added when the customer requests one or states that they are concerned that the security of their personal information may have been compromised.
Passwords are not required on accounts and should not be offered when creating an account.
Once a password is added it becomes a part of the verification process and must be verified before a change can be made on an account. All account information is still subject for release per the public records law even if the password cannot be verified.
Once the account has been properly verified, a spouse or authorized user can add or remove a password.
IMPORTANT
If a customer cannot verify their password, KIQ can be used to verify their identity. Once the caller’s identity has been verified, the password may be removed or updated. If the caller’s identity is not verified, contact Revenue Assurance (x6330) to determine next steps.

Deceased Process Using an Existing Account

If the Responsible Party has an existing account with JEA, that account can be used to backdate the service. Do not create a new account.
If there is a write-off on the existing account, all current credit policies still apply.
If the credit score for the existing account is 700 or below and the debt is collectible, a deposit is required for that customer to have service in their name.
No Backdate & a Debt Exists on the Deceased Account

Revenue Assurance Investigates Case (Debt Recovery)
so that the balance will be transferred to the responsible party’s active account.

Service Agreements
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
The type of account a person has – what utility services JEA will provide, and how much a customer will pay for the services rendered – are all governed by what is called a Service Agreement. A service agreement is a contract between a customer and JEA defining the services (electric, water, sewer, irrigation) that will be provided and billed by JEA.
A Service Agreement exists for every service furnished to the customer; therefore, a customer may have one or several service agreements with JEA.
Types of Service Agreements
There are two types of Service Agreements.
Commodity
Non-Commodity
Commodity Service Agreements are premise based; they belong to the Premise.
Area Light
Electric
Irrigation (Including reclaimed)
Multifamily Water
Water
Sewer
Photovoltaic (solar panels)
NOTE: Multifamily water means that it services two or more households. It is very important to verify with a caller if they are supposed to take over a multifamily water service point. Many times a multifamily water service point will remain in a landlord or leasing office’s name.
Non-Commodity Service Agreements are Non-Premise based; they belong to the Account.
Deposit
Neighbor to Neighbor
Over Payment
Payment Arrangement
Prosperity Fund
Write-Off

Determining Deceased Account In-Full Eligibility
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
After it has been determined that the caller
wants
to be the Responsible Party, Customer Advisors must next determine
if
the account can converted into the caller’s name or if another account must be used.
If the deceased account DOES NOT have a deposit …
Proceed with in-fulling the account into the caller’s name. Changing the name and all personal account identifiers on an account from one person to another is the process of in-fulling an account.
A credit/identity check is required; if the deposit is not waived, a credit score reduction (-250) is require for a period of 9-months.
If the deceased account DOES have a deposit and the caller is an authorized user or spouse …
Proceed with in-fulling the account into the caller’s name. Changing the name and all personal account identifiers on an account from one person to another is the process of in-fulling an account.
If the deceased account DOES have a deposit and the caller is NOT an authorized user or spouse …
You cannot in-full the account. A new account must be made for the caller (or use an existing account). The new account will not require that a deposit is paid, however, a credit score reduction of- 250 is required for a period of 9-months.
The 48-Hour field notification activity must be created on the deceased account if the services are not started, along with a
Revenue Assurance Investigates
case (Debt Recovery).
When services are stopped, the deposit will refund to the account; any remaining balance can be the responsibility of the Responsible Party.
NOTE
After the deposit refunds to the deceased account, if a credit balance is leftover, the Responsible Party may call back because they are not being able to cash the received refund check; the check is in the deceased customer’s name. The Responsible Party will need to provide proof of their rights to funds; for example, Executor of Estate or Next of Kin (on the death certificate).

Masked Account
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
A masked account is a residential account where the customer information is not displayed and they are exempt from public records. The customer is identified by a JEA assigned number.
Some common examples of when this process is used would be for a court judge, law enforcement personnel and victims of domestic violence.
Other examples of those that may qualify for a masked account include …
A customer may have a Masked account if they fall under certain classifications as determined by the State Legislature. Examples include, but are not limited to:
Active or former law enforcement personnel: Including correctional officers, probation officers, DCF, DOH, and DOR investigators and enforcement personnel.
Certified Firefighters
Judges: Including Supreme Court, District Court, Circuit Court, County Court, administrative law judges, general magistrates, special magistrates, judges of compensation claims, and child support enforcement officers.
Current or former prosecutors
Current and former public defenders: Assistant public defenders, criminal conflict and civil regional counsel, assistant criminal conflict and civil regional counsel.
Current or former HR, Labor Relations: Employment relations directors, assistant directors, manager or assistant managers of any local government agency or water management district (includes those who duties include hiring and firing employees, labor contract negotiators, administration or other personnel-related duties).
Current or former Code Enforcement Officers
Current or former Guardian or Litem: The person appointed by the court to look out for the best interests of the child during the course of legal proceedings.
Current or former juvenile probation officers: Juvenile probation supervisors, detention superintendents, assistant detention superintendents, senior juvenile detention officers, juvenile detention officer supervisors, juvenile detention officers, house parents I and II, house parent supervisors, group treatment leaders, group treatment leader supervisors, rehabilitation therapists, and social services counselors of the Department of Juvenile Justice.
Spouses and Children: Under 18 years of age of the above-listed individuals are also entitled to the exemption of their personal information.
Victims of sexual battery: Victims of sexual battery, aggravated child abuse aggravated stalking, harassment, aggravated battery, or domestic violence, Exemption expires five (5) years after receipt of request, including Participants in the Address Confidentiality Program for Victims of Domestic Violence held by the Office of the Attorney General.
Active Duty Service members and Families: This legislation provides exemption from public records requirements for certain identification & location information of current or former service members of United States Armed Forces, Reserve Forces, or National Guard, & spouses & children; provides applicability; provides for future review & repeal of exemption; provides statement of public necessity.
Masked Account Qualifications
The customer must fall under certain classifications determined by the State Legislature.
The customer must submit a request in writing stating he or she is entitled to exemption status and provide official verification that a crime has occurred.
Victim exemption expires five years after the request for exemption.
Written Request (with active account number) with confirmation that the requester qualifies for the exemption
Crime victims must submit official verification that a crime has occurred.
Verifying/Making Changes to a Masked Account
There is no information to verify. You may not give out any information over the phone on these accounts. Advise the caller they can access basic information through the IVR, with their account number.
In order to make changes, transfer, stop, or add additional service,
the customer must visit the CSC
and
present a picture ID
.

Knowledge IQ Identity Validation
Estimated reading: 5 minutes
At times Experian is not able to validate that the information provided by the customer actually belongs to the person on the phone. When this happens, Knowledge IQ is used for further authentication. Knowledge IQ is an Experian product that is used to verify consumers quickly and easily.
Knowledge IQ uses analytics to authenticate a customer based on fraud scores and the customer’s performance on verifying questions. This allows JEA to approve more good consumers while eliminating fraudulent activities.
When to Use Knowledge IQ
Any time the Experian results come back that the caller must present 2 forms of ID, Knowledge IQ should be used to attempt to validate the caller’s identity.
When Experian is not able to validate the authenticity of the customer on the phone, it is possible one or more of the following occurred:
The information was entered incorrectly.
One or more of the required fields for the credit check was not completed.
The customer doesn’t have enough credit history to validate.
The person on the phone may be attempting to commit fraud.
After you determine that the information provided was entered correctly and the customer’s credit check results require they present two forms of ID, provide the following disclaimer:
In order to further verify your identity, may I ask you a few identifying questions?
If the customer answers “Yes,” use Knowledge IQ to validate the customer’s identity.
If the customer refuses, we need to determine if Revenue Assurance can verify the customer’s ID. Call Revenue Assurance at extension 6330.
Validating a Customer’s Identity
After the customer agrees to answer some identifying questions, you will use Knowledge IQ to guide you through the questions to ask the customer for validation.

Responding to Identity Verification Questions
Occasionally, a customer may become irritated with verification questions. Below are examples of what they may ask as well as a response to share with the customer.
“Why are you having trouble verifying my identity? I gave you my correct information!”
Mr. /Mrs. Customer, there are many contributing factors that may cause difficulty when verifying your identity. I do not have access to any specific information regarding your situation but some of these factors include fraud alerts, someone else using your SSN in error, or there simply not being enough history in the report to verify an identity.
“Why are you asking me that?”
Mr. /Mrs. Customer, we have contracted with Experian in order to gain access to a tool that helps us verify our customer’s identity. Experian uses numerous data sources to compile a list of questions that only you would know the answers to. If you would prefer not to proceed with this process you may always visit our Customer Solutions Center downtown with two forms of valid, government issued ID in order to verify your identity. Would you like me to proceed with the questions to see if we can verify your identity over the phone?
“I don’t know the answer to that—it was a long time ago!”
Mr. /Mrs. Customer, please answer to the best of your ability. If you are not able to correctly answer the first three questions we are able to generate an additional set of questions. I do not have access to the specifics regarding correct or incorrect answers; however, the system will provide a decision after this part of the process is complete. May I proceed?
IMPORTANT
The CA should NOT guess for them and should be able to encourage the caller to provide an answer and continue through the process
“Will this impact my credit bureau score (cause an inquiry)?”
No, this is considered a “soft hit” which is only viewable by you, not other companies. It will not impact your credit score as a credit inquiry would.

Returned Checks & NSF3
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
Payments processed by phone or online may be returned for various reasons. You should not assume a returned payment means insufficient funds.
The reason code is noted in the Customer Contacts under the
Return Payment
Customer Contact type.
IMPORTANT
ONLY R03, R04, and R13 reasons can be waived and restored, after a good payment has been made on the account.
The Returned Check Codes Matrix
Returned Check Code
Description
Details
R01
Insufficient Funds
Available balance is insufficient.
R02
Account Closed
Previous active account has been closed.
R03
No Account
Unable to locate account.
R04
Invalid Account
Invalid account number.
R06
Returned per ODFI
We as the Originating Depository Financial Institution request item to be returned.
R07
Revoked Authorization
Consumer has revoked their authorization. PDD files only.
R08
Payment Stopped
Consumer places stop pay on item at their receiving financial institution.
R09
Uncollected Funds
While the balance covers the amount of the item, the available balance in the account does not.
R10
Not Authorized
Consumer never authorized the item. PPD files only.
R12
Branch Sold
Account now at branch sold to another financial institution.
R13
Invalid Routing #
Routing number of the financial institution is invalid.
R14
Representative Payee Deceased
Account representative is deceased.
R15
Account Holder Deceased
Actual account holder at financial institution is deceased.
R16
Account Frozen
Funds unavailable due to legal action.
R20
Non-transaction
Account governed by regulations which do not allow ACH items to post against it.
R22
Invalid ID Number
ID number used to identify the account is incorrect. Used only for CIE transactions.
R23
Credit Entry Refused
Receiving financial institution refuses a Credit entry due to an invalid amount or restrictions on the account.
R24
Duplicate Entry
Receiving financial institution receives what appears to be a duplicate.
R29
Corporate Entry
Unauthorized debit to a corporate client.
NSF3
If an account has been identified as having a NSF3 (returned payment on the deposit or initial payment) the process is different from the normal collections and severance process.
The NSF3 process is as follows:
A letter is sent to the customer notifying them of the returned payment.
After seven (7) days have passed since the NSF3 letter was mailed, and no payment has been received, the new service will be placed into manual disconnection, which will initiate the stop of service and the account closing.
NOTE:
Always review the customer contacts. If the service has been disconnected by RCS they will notate the account.
A
REQ-OFF
FA will be created manually and completed. This will stop the service at the premise.
As a result of this manual disconnection, the customer will need to reapply for service and pay the new deposit amount and any balance owed on the account in cash. In order to reapply for service the Customer Advisor (CA) will have to restart the actual account using the
Start Process Script
after the payment has been received in cash.
Payment only will not reconnect services automatically.
After the payment and reprocessing the start, always verify your Field Activity (FA) to make sure it is directed to the correct Dispatch Group. The Dispatch Group should be FMS or RCD. If not you will need to send a
REQ-ON
Field Activity to make sure the service is reconnected.

Returned Checks:
1st Returned Check

Initial dishonored payment from a financial institution with exception of initial deposit or first payment. The deduction will expire after nine (9) months on the anniversary date of the infraction occurrence and restore the points to the account credit score.

A $20 returned payment fee
Minus 100 points from ICS
Plus one cash point

Minus 200 points from ICS
Plus two cash points

Possible disconnection for non-payment

Minus 300 points from ICS
Plus three cash points
Possible deposit (if not originally required)

If it has been determined that a customer has tampered with a service point, the customer will receive an infraction of 750 points; and the deduction will expire after eighty-four (84) on the anniversary date of the infraction occurrence and restore the points to the account credit score.

Minus 750 points from ICS

Minus 750 points from ICS

Minus 750 points from ICS
Duration:
48 Months

Internal Credit Score (ICS)
Estimated reading: 1 minute
JEA uses an internal credit score as an indicator of a customer’s payment pattern.
A new customer starts service with a JEA internal credit score (ICS) of 1000. Below are some of the reasons that we deduct points from a customer’s ICS.
Returned payments (100 to 300 point reduction)
Disconnected for non-pay (100 point reduction)
Tampered with their service (750 point reduction)
A bankruptcy (300 point reduction)
A write-off on their account (750 point reduction)
Committed theft on a JEA account (750 point reduction)
No PII on their account (300 point reduction)
A set amount of points is deducted from their credit score for each infraction. If the customer has a returned payment, “cash only” points are added to the credit score, and the account can eventually become a “cash only” account.
Only returned payments accrue cash only points.

Start Date

JEA does pay interest to a customer on their Deposit. The interest rate paid on a customer’s Deposit is based upon the 52-week Treasury Bill Yield. The most current published six 52-week T-Bill interest rate will be reviewed by JEA at the beginning of each fiscal year and at mid-year (October 1 & April 1) with the practice of changing the interest rate to be posted to customer accounts on each October 1 (or within the following ten (10) day business days).
The interest on a Deposit will be refunded after the account is closed and processed for final billing. The current Interest Rate effective 01/01/23 is 3.99%; the rate fluctuates, for example the rate was 1.59% in April 2022.

Deposit Increase
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
If a Residential customer’s credit score is 700 or below, they become identified as a “high risk”, are subject to a deposit review, and could result in a deposit being added to the account or an active deposit being increased.
Once the internal credit score is 700 or below, CCB reviews the account every month to ensure the account has a sufficient amount of deposit on hand.
The sufficient amount is two (2) times the average consumption at the premise(s) over the last twelve (12) months.
IMPORTANT
A deposit increase will occur if a customer’s credit score is 700 or below, and the consumption has increased by 25% or $75, whichever is higher, over the last 12 month.
The system will automatically increase their deposit to cover two times the average consumption over the last 12 months at the premise(s).
Reasons For Deposit Increases
There are a number of potential reasons for a deposit increase. An account exhibiting risk indicators is subject to a deposit review.
Upon review, JEA may rescind a waived deposit or adjust the required deposit amount based off the the following occurrences.
The account has received more than one returned payment in a 9 month period.
A non-cash deposit expired and their credit score is 700 or below.
They have three meter disconnections for non-pay within one year.
They filed for bankruptcy.
Risk indicators for Residential customers include the following indicators.
Dishonored Payments
Broken Payment Arrangements
Disconnection for Non-payment
Missing Personally Identifiable Information
Evidence of Tampering
Evidence of Fraud and/or
Uncollected Debt
EXCEPTIONS
Although there are set deposit requirements in most instances, JEA waives all deposit requirements for agencies of the City, County, State, and Federal Governments.

Standard Deposit Amounts
Estimated reading: 1 minute
There are minimum deposit requirements for all service agreements. A standard deposit amount is the least amount required to start a service agreement.
Standard Deposit Amounts
All customers are required to pay a deposit to start service with JEA unless the deposit has been waived by the credit check process.
The standard deposit amounts are as follows:
200.00 for electric
100.00 for water and sewer
75.00 for sewer only
50.00 for water only
50.00 for irrigation/reclaimed water
If the Premise Verification screen does not populate a Deposit, please advise the customer the standard amounts. If there has never been service at the location you are starting, the system doesn’t have the required information to quote a correct Deposit amount.
IMPORTANT
A deposit quote will be honored for 30 days. The deposit quote should be run again after the 30 days have expired.
Below are possible service point combinations and the standard deposit amount that should be charged.

Deposit Vouchers
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
A voucher is a hold (Promise to Pay) placed on the JEA account to prevent the dollar amount on the voucher from being reviewed for collection.
When a customer needs assistance to pay their bill and it is outside of the scope of what JEA can provide, JEA will advise the customer to seek the help of outside agencies. JEA has no affiliation with these agencies with the exception of providing their names and numbers to the customer.
The agencies work within budget constraints and may provide assistance on a first come, first serve basis to applicants that meet the agency’s qualifications. If the agency decides that they can help the customer, they will issue JEA a check (voucher) for the payment.
Receiving a Voucher
Vouchers will be granted to the customer to pay the deposit in order to start service. When a voucher is used to pay the deposit JEA must wait for the voucher to be received before the start can be processed.
Once the voucher has been received there will be a Customer Contact from the voucher department with instructions for the next steps needed to start the service.
IMPORTANT
When starting service, the Deposit SA must also be started.
Voucher Payments
The check may cover the whole amount or a partial amount of which the customer will be responsible for the remaining balance.
Vouchers received from Government Agencies such as North East Florida Community Action Agency (NEFCCA), Emmitt Reed, and Kennedy Center; only pay the electric portion of the deposit required. The customer will be responsible to pay the water portion before service can be started.
Once JEA receives the check it will be applied to the account and will show as a Frozen Payment. The CA will notate the account and the service will continue.
IMPORTANT
Payments from Family Support Services (FSS), Beaches Emergency Assistance Ministry (BEAM) and St. Vincent’s DePaul (SVDP) will show as an adjustment, not as a payment.
Voucher Timelines for Payment
Agencies are given 30 days to provide JEA with a payment.
The exceptions are government funded agencies such as North East Florida Community Action Agency (NFCAA) which includes its subsidiaries Emmitt Reed and Kennedy Center. They may be given 45 days to make the payment.
Verifying a Voucher
When a voucher is received for a deposit you will only see a customer contact that states the voucher was received. The service will not be started. You will create the start.
Start the Deposit SA
Once you have processed the start request email the Voucher Department (
vouchers@jea.com
) that the service has been started.

Deposit Refund
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
A Residential Deposit will refund to an active account 12 months from the day it was paid in-full with an account having a 1000 credit score. The system reviews the account at the end of each month to determine if the account is eligible for a deposit refund. For example, if the deposit was paid 3-14-2017, system will review on 3-29-2018.
Determine the Deposit Paid In-Full Date
Use the following steps to determine when a Deposit was paid in-full:
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
Step 4
Click on the
Residential Deposit
alert in the Dashboard.
Click on the
SA ID
dropdown context menu button.
Click
Go to SA Financial History
.
Review the
Current Balance
column. The date that the Deposit was paid in-full is when the
Current Balance
equals $0.00.
Deposit Refunding to the Account
After the deposit refunds to the account, there will be a credit on the Deposit SA. The funds will not distribute to the remaining SA’s with balances until AFTER the next bill prints.
The best option is that a customer leaves the credit on the account to apply towards current and future usage charges. The customer is eligible for a Deposit refund check
only
if there is truly a credit on the account.
For credits above $100, a Credit Refund case can be created to request a check be issued to a customer.

Experian Credit Check
Estimated reading: 5 minutes
JEA requires all residential customers to pay a deposit. Experian is used to evaluate a customer’s credit worthiness to determine:
If the deposit can be waived.
and
To validate the customer’s identity.
Experian results are drafted from the
TEC (Telecommunications, Energy and Cable)
score, or additional data points collected from Experian Lift.
The TEC score is based on a risk model that Experian developed to be specific to telecom and energy accounts. The Experian results are used to determine a customer’s credit worthiness. For JEA, the TEC score would give a result of waived or not waived deposit.
An Experian credit check is a “soft” inquiry on a customer’s credit and will not impact their overall Experian score.
Experian Lift
Experian uses multiple data points to evaluate a consumer’s credit score.
Experian Lift
is used when a consumer doesn’t have a TEC score, either because they don’t have enough credit, or they have no credit. Lift uses multiple data sets to identify and locate information on the customer. Lift looks at traditional credit along with Experian’s alternative data bureau, in-addition to public records data.
Experian Lift allows many customers with little to no credit the opportunity to get a waived deposit result when applying for service with JEA.
Declining or Agreeing to a Credit Check
Once the account is created the customer has the option to agree or disagree to have a credit check run to verify their deposit requirements.
Read the statement at the bottom of the
New Account Review
page to the customer.
Whether or not the customer agrees to the credit check will determine the next steps.
If the customer Declines the Credit Check
If the customer Agrees to the Credit Check
KIQ can be performed to validate the identity. If the customer declines the KIQ, we need to determine if Revenue Assurance can verify the customer’s ID. Instead of sending the customer to the CSC, you will call Revenue Assurance at extension 6330.
A deposit is required.
Click the button and run the Credit/Identity check in Experian.

Other Possible Experian Results
Experian has universal codes used to identify the credit results provided. Below is a list of the
Credit Code Provided (CCP) Match Codes

Match Code
Meaning
Deposit Requirement
A – Deceased or Non-Issued SSN
An invalid number indicates possible fraud.
Deposit required. Contact Revenue Assurance (ext. 6330).
B – No Record
No information resides in Experian Database, unable to confirm the applicant.

Deposit required, may be paid online or through IVR.

Consumer was a victim of ID theft and/or placed a consumer statement on their file.

1)
contact Experian to have the fraud alert lifted or
2)
come into the CSC with valid picture ID.
D – ID Match to other, Meets Credit Score Cut
The information provided shows a discrepancy in the Experian database.
Deposit required. Contact Revenue Assurance (ext. 6330).
D – ID Match to Other, Does not Meet Credit Score Cut
The information provided shows a discrepancy in the Experian database.
Deposit required. Contact Revenue Assurance (ext. 6330).
D – ID Match to Other, Fraud Alert Present
Consumer was a victim of ID theft and/or placed a consumer statement on their file.
Deposit required. Contact Revenue Assurance (ext. 6330).
E – ID No Match
No matching file. SSN identified with other consumer.
Deposit required. Contact Revenue Assurance (ext. 6330).
Credit Report Suppressed
Consumer has frozen their credit file.
Deposit required. Contact Revenue Assurance (ext. 6330).
When your results come back anything other than “C,” it is important that you edit your inquiry and double check the information entered. We want to make sure that we have accurate information for the customer.
Presenting 2 Forms of ID

Knowledge IQ
should be used to attempt to validate the caller’s identity.
If the customer refuses Knowledge IQ or it does not PASS, instead of sending the customer to the CSC, you will call Revenue Assurance at extension 6330 for further directions.

My JEA Utility Tracker
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
My JEA Utility Tracker is an online tool that allows customers to track daily electric and water consumption and find energy saving tips specific to their homes.
With My JEA Utility Tracker, customers have the ability to know what uses the most energy in their homes allowing them to conserve where needed and better manage their utility costs.
My JEA Utility Tracker is unavailable to Commercial customers, customers who have photovoltaic (solar) systems installed, or customers with Demand meters of any type including Residential 1-Way Demand.
First-time Tracker users will be asked to confirm their information for the
Energy Profile
.
IMPORTANT
The
Temperature
and
Usage
graph will become available for NEW My JEA Utility Tracker accounts after 30 days, or one billing cycle. This also applies to customers who have had their meter changed or customers who transfer addresses.
For example, if a customer’s meter is changed out on 05/27 and they bill on 06/03, they would not have Tracker information again until the 07/03 bill. They must have 30 days of meter reads, then after the next bill, tracker information will be available
Accessing My Utility Tracker

Daily & Non-Daily Reads
Most addresses in JEA’s service territory are read daily. However, outlying areas that we service may not have daily reads because of the distance of the home to JEA’s system. The transmitters on the meters must be within range for JEA to receive daily reads, otherwise these meters are read monthly.
A JEA meter reader will visit these addresses to take a manual read within the billing window.
As of 2024, JEA started a project to update these meter transmitters so that we would receive daily reads. This project is called the
Water Meter AMI Upgrade Project
.
Outlying areas include:
Clay County
St Johns County
Yulee
Baldwin
Atlantic Beach
Not a Good Read / Historical Estimate Reads
The
Read Origin
column will be blank and the
Reading Flag
column will show
Historical Estimate
or
Regular
when we are not receiving a good daily read. This does not mean that something is “wrong” with the meter, it just means that we did not receive good daily reads. If required, we will manually read these meters during the billing window.
NOTE:
Historical Estimates
are NOT billed estimates and are NOT used for any billing purposes, they are just estimates provided by MDM.

Identifying a 1-Way versus a 2-Way Meter
There will be two timeframes that show in the MDM Viewer. Electric meters can be 1-way or 2-way; all water meters are 1-way and cannot be remotely disconnected.
If the reading is near 11:59pm daily …
Then the meter is a 1-way meter.
If the reading is at 12:00am daily …
Then the meter is a 2-way meter.
IMPORTANT
When reading MDM data and sharing the information with the customer, remember, if the reading is from a 2-way meter it is the consumption from the previous day.
EXAMPLE
05/25/2022 reading of 92 kWh at 12:00am would be the consumption used on 05/24/2022.

Reviewing Water Usage & Trends
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
Reviewing water meter data in the MDM Viewer can help CAs identify trends and leak issues that a customer may be experiencing.
Water Example:
Days
Year-to-Year Comparison
Year-to-Year Comparison
Irrigation Example:
Days
Billed Amount
Billed Amount
Below are scenarios in which the customer contacted JEA with concerns about the total bill amount and had high water usage.
Water Leak
Slab Leak
Running Toilet
Irrigation Issue
A water leak could be from a broken pipe, a hose that was left running, or other excess use of water. High water usage could even be from a broken sprinkler head or pipe if the customer does not have  separate irrigation meter.
Leaks can happen anywhere between the meter to the house; even under the house, this is called a slab leak. The pipes that leak under the concrete slab are the supply pipes which supply water to various rooms/fixtures throughout the house.
It may seem hard to believe, but you may see usage of 3000-6000 gallons per day from a slab leak; and the customer may have never noticed the leak because the leak is “concealed” underneath the concrete. Unfortunately, this is very common.
When there is a running toilet at a home the customer may not be aware, except for hearing the toilet filling with water, even when it has not recently been used.
Toilets can leak until someone moves the handle again. Therefore, toilet leaks show very intermittent usage.
Normally there is no pattern in the high usage.
High irrigation usage is normally the result of an improperly set irrigation timer or a broken sprinkler pipe/head.
NOTE
Wastewater “usage” is based off of water usage; there are no
wastewater meters
. Therefore, if a customers water usage is higher than normal due to water related issue, the customer’s wastewater charges will also be higher than normal. The exceptions to this rule are if the customer has a separate irrigation meter or has a septic system, wastewater charges will be unaffected or not applicable.
Irrigation Pattern
Customer Advisors can identify irrigation watering patterns of customers who water their lawn, either with their potable water or a separate irrigation meter. The customer’s usage will be higher on specific days of the week, i.e. only Tuesday/Thursday or only Monday/Wednesday/Saturday.
It’s not uncommon for their lawn watering days to be several thousands gallons higher than their non-watering days.
Irrigation Meter Pattern
Water Meter Pattern
A meter for irrigation purposes only will typically have usage on some days and no usage on other days. The days with usage can contain thousands of gallons of usage.
Click the image to expand.
This customer does not water on Sunday or Tuesday.
A water meter for potable (drinking) water which is also used for watering a lawn will typically have usage on all days; however lawn watering days will have substantially more usage than non-watering days.

Daily Consumption Alerts Pilot
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
To help customers realize their daily consumption and help them better manage their usage to lower their bills, JEA launched a pilot program in April 2024 for Traditional (post pay) customers. Emails were sent to 4,000 randomly identified customers to notify them that they have been selected to receive
Daily Consumption Alerts
. The first round of alerts were sent on 04/18.
Email Sent: 4/15/2024 – Text Start: 4/18/2024
Email Sent: 4/22/2024 – Text Start: 4/25/2024
Email Sent: 4/29/2024 – Text Start: 5/02/2024
Email Sent: 5/06/2024 – Text Start: 5/09/2024
The customers will have a minimum of 3 days to opt out of the pilot. Customers that remain in the pilot will receive the alerts via text messages.
Important Information:
Customers can opt out of the pilot at any time before it starts or after receiving the daily alerts.
Alerts will only be sent Monday – Friday.
Consumption will be for the previous day’s usage.
Customers participating in the pilot will have an alert added to their account in CCB.
If a Customer Advisors receives a call from a pilot customer, they should handle the call just like any other call.
Example Customer Contact
Pilot participants will have a Customer Contact added to their account to designate that they are in the pilot:
Example SMS Alert
FAQs for Customers in the Pilot
I received an email regarding a pilot that will send me a text message regarding my usage, is this real?
Yes, the email you received was an invitation to participate in a pilot that will provide information to help manage your bill more efficiently than just a monthly bill.
How was I chosen for this alert pilot?
We randomly chose customers with active accounts with us here at JEA to participate pilots used.
How often will I receive these alerts?
Monday through Friday you will receive an alert from the previous day’s usage.
Can someone be added to the pilot that was not originally selected?
Unfortunately, we are not able to add additional customers to this pilot, but with future pilot projects customers may be eligible for subsequent pilots.
How do I stop these alerts from coming to me?
In the text alert, reply with the number
1
and you will be removed from receiving the alerts.
Do these alerts include just electricity?
The alerts received include all the services JEA provides to your home.
I mistakenly unsubscribed to the alerts; how can I turn them back on?
Customer Advisors need to send an email to Gerald Butler (
butlgl@jea.com
) with the customer information. Please inform the customer that it may take one business day until the alerts startup again.

Watering Restrictions / Irrigation Schedules
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
The St. Johns River Water Management District’s (SJWMD) watering restrictions are designed to ensure the efficient use of water for landscape irrigation. The restrictions allow enough water to maintain healthy landscapes year-round. The mandatory restrictions specify the time when watering may occur, the amount of water that may be applied, and the days when watering may occur for residential and nonresidential locations. These days depend on whether the address ends in an odd or even number, and on the time of year.
“Landscape irrigation” means the outside watering of plants in a landscape such as shrubbery, trees, lawns, grass, ground covers, plants, vines, gardens and other such flora that are situated in such diverse locations as residential areas, public, commercial and industrial establishments, and public medians and rights-of way.
Watering restrictions apply to both potable and reclaimed water sources.
Click here for complete water restriction information via SJWMD
Time of Year
Odd Numbered Homes
Even Numbered Homes
Non-Residential Properties
Daylight Savings Time
Wednesday/Saturday
Thursday/Sunday
Tuesday/Friday
Eastern Standard Time
Saturday
Sunday
Tuesady
Daylight saving time: Second Sunday in March until the first Sunday in November
Eastern Standard Time: First Sunday in November until the second Sunday in March
An odd numbered address is one that ends in 1, 3, 5, 7 or 9.
An even numbered address is one that ends in 0, 2, 4, 6 or 8.
Water only when needed and not between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m.
Water for no more than one hour per zone.
Restrictions apply to private wells and pumps, ground or surface water and water from public and private utilities.
Some exceptions apply.
Summary of Restrictions
Irrigation is prohibited between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m.
During daylight saving time (second Sunday in March until the first Sunday in November) irrigation is limited to no more than two days per week on scheduled days.
Residential irrigation is allowed on Wednesday and Saturday at addresses that end in an odd number or have no address.
Residential irrigation is allowed on Thursday and Sunday at addresses that end in an even number.
Nonresidential irrigation is allowed on Tuesday and Friday.
During Eastern Standard Time (first Sunday in November until the second Sunday in March) irrigation is limited to no more than one day per week on scheduled days.
Residential irrigation is allowed on Saturday at addresses that end in an odd number or have no address.
Residential irrigation is allowed on Sunday at addresses that end in an even number.
Nonresidential irrigation is allowed on Tuesday.
Irrigation is limited to no more than ¾ inch of water per zone per irrigation day.
Irrigation is limited to no more than one hour per irrigation zone per irrigation day.
Irrigation is limited to only that amount necessary to meet landscape needs.
When reclaimed water is available for irrigation use, the use of private irrigation wells is not authorized.
Irrigation limitations apply to water withdrawn from ground or surface water, from a private well or pump, or from a public or private utility.
Irrigation limitations apply to all landscape irrigation not currently regulated by a consumptive use permit. Typically, this includes residential, commercial and industrial establishments.
Persons irrigating with an automatic lawn irrigation system installed after May 1991 shall install, maintain and operate a rain sensor device or switch that overrides the system when adequate rainfall has occurred.
Additional Information Contact Information
For additional information about the watering restrictions, customers can call (800) 232‑0904 or send an email to
waterrestriction@sjrwmd.com
.

Consumption & Bill Increases
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
Managing energy and water consumption (aka
usage
) is the first step for customers lowering their utility bill. In order to better manage consumption, they need to know what areas in the home are affecting their utility bill most.
The type of Service Point dictates the education that CAs should provide to a customer, whether it be electric or water, or both. Customer Advisors can help customers determine the reason for increased consumption by using the data available to them and the customer.

Water Smart Check
Estimated reading: 4 minutes
A Water Smart Check is a free service offered to Residential JEA customers to diagnose a high-water consumption issue that is actively occurring and does not mirror the previous year’s consumption.
The customer’s usage history should be reviewed prior to creating a Water Smart Check. The general criteria are that the consumption must be significantly higher than the previous month and the same period of time for the previous year.
A Smart Check can be requested by an account holder, authorized user/spouse, or an unauthorized caller. The resident does not need to be home to have the smart check completed.
ALL IRRIGATION system checks (including timer help) should go under efficiency appointments.
What occurs during a Water Smart Check?
A Water Smart Check is generally completed in 2-3 business days; the length of the visit will depend on if the customer is home.
We will knock on the door to see if anyone is available and obtain permission to come in to check for a leak.
If no one is available, we evaluate the meter to verify the reading and determine if there is a leak is identified. A door hanger is left if leak is/is not detected.
Do not create a Water SmartCheck and an Efficiency Assessment appointment for the same premise. Doing so will cause two technicians from different areas to be dispatched to the same premise.

The Impact of Fuel Rates
Estimated reading: 1 minute
The fuel charge on a customer’s bill is a variable rate. The rate adjusts month-to-month based on what it costs for JEA to purchase fuel. We determine the customer’s charge based on the amount of fuel that they use, based on their kilowatt-hour consumption.
The fuel rate is a passthrough rate, meaning JEA does not profit from the fuel rate. The customer pays what JEA pays.
A month-after-month fuel rate increase can considerably increase a customer’s bill.

Days

Below are scenarios in which the customer contacted JEA with concerns about the total bill amount and had high electric usage.
HVAC Thermostat
HVAC Fan & Thermostat
JEA recommends that customers set their HVAC thermostat to 78F during the summer and 68F during the winter.
It’s completely acceptable for a customer to set their thermostat lower than 78F or higher than 68F, however, the customer will use more energy to maintain temperature, resulting in more energy charges.
An HVAC fan that runs all the time will increase energy usage. In addition, a thermostat that is set to be lower than the recommended 78F (during summer months) or 68F (during winter months) will need to run for longer to keep the property cool.
This customer had their HVAC fan set to run
all the time
rather than on “Auto” and had the thermostat set to
72
F. In addition, these days in June 2021 were especially hot.
Click on the image to expand.
After adjusting the thermostat to a higher value, i.e. the recommended 78F, and setting the HVAC fan to auto, the customers daily usage was reduced.

Water Quality Complaint & Water Information Request (B)
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
The Water Quality case is used at the request of a customer to have their water checked for Taste, Appearance, or Feel, or to obtain information to provide to the customer.
There are four different areas of focus when it comes to Water Quality:
The initial complaint
A second complaint within 60 days
Hardness or iron levels
The annual water quality report
All water complaints or information requests require a customer contact and a case.
Complaints (not information-only requests) also require a ticket created in FMS.
Facts About JEA Water Quality
JEA extensively monitors and tests water according to state and federal regulations on a regular basis to ensure high quality and safe drinking (potable) water is delivered to all customers.
JEA’s water source is the Floridan aquifer, located 800 to 1,000 feet below land surface, and highly protected from chemical contamination by a thick layer of clay that prevents chemicals from entering the aquifer. The water is clean and fresh, and requires minimal treatment
The water from the aquifer is simply pumped from the wells, aerated to remove sulfur compounds, chlorinated for disinfection, and distributed to our customers.
JEA conducts a comprehensive monitoring program by collecting and analyzing water samples from various locations throughout our treatment area. This program is regulated by the state.
These samples are tested for more than 100 bacteriological and chemical components. In a typical year, JEA collects and tests more than 45,000 water samples.
Most of the elements and minerals present in our drinking water occur naturally in the aquifer at very low levels.
Per federal and state regulations, drinking water utilities must maintain adequate chlorine residual to ensure the water is free of pathogens.
JEA provides an annual
Water Quality Report
to all of our customers in June and this publication presents the results of our water quality testing. Manmade synthetic chemicals are not present in our drinking water supply.
JEA maintains an email at
waterquality@jea.com
for customers to inquire about water quality or report a water quality concern.
Articles
Water Quality Complaint
Water Quality Information Only Request

Efficiency Assessment
Estimated reading: 4 minutes
Efficiency Assessments for Residential service points are services we offer to active JEA customers to educate on conservation and potentially diagnose problems. The appointment is a free service.
Any caller over 18 can request an appointment and doesn’t have to be on the account. Even a Landlord or maintenance person can schedule an appointment. The individual that will be there for the appointment should be listed in the Field Activity
Instructions
box with a valid contact number.
Only a single Efficiency Assessment is required for all services and a customer may only have one EA in a 6 month period.
ALL IRRIGATION system checks (including timer help) should go under efficiency appointments.
What occurs during an Efficiency Assessment?
The appointment takes place on the date scheduled and the duration may vary depending on the customers’ needs and the number of service points being checked.
Appointments typically take about 90 minutes.
The JEA technician will check all available service points (Electric, Water, and Irrigation).
The representative will conduct a walk-through inspection (no diagnostic equipment is used) of the home to determine where improvements can be made both in behavior and in new equipment.
Efficiency Assessments do not replace verbal customer education; Customer Advisors should make every attempt to educate customers during their phone interactions, avoiding the need for an in-person appointment. Regardless of education covered, Efficiency Assessments are available for in-person tips.
Do not create a Water SmartCheck and an Efficiency Assessment appointment for the same premise. Doing so will cause two technicians from different areas to be dispatched to the same premise.
How to Schedule an Efficiency Assessment
A Customer Advisors communication to the field is vital when scheduling an appointment. Please remember to keep these important factors in-mind during the scheduling process:
It is vital that you communicate to the Technician in the
Instructions
field:
The request, issue, or concern of the customer.
If the customer is upset or escalated, add
High Bill Complaint
verbiage to the
Instructions
field for their safety.
There must be an active Service Agreement at the address

Unpaid / Deferred Balance for Existing MyWay Customers
Estimated reading: 5 minutes
Existing MyWay customers can place a negative balance into an Unpaid Balance if they meet certain criteria. This can provide temporary financial relief to a MyWay customer, similar to how a Pay Plan provides temporary relief (by giving them more time) for Traditional customers.
Only if the customer cannot pay the full amount required should you evaluate the deferred option with the customer.
IMPORTANT
Before offering to place a debt into a deferred balance, the first step is to
ALWAYS
ask that the customer pays the full amount to bring the account current
AND
places an additional credit on the account for future usage.
Financial Relief Eligibility Requirements
An Existing MyWay customer can place a negative balance UP TO $100 into a deferred balance if they meet the following criteria:
No existing Unpaid Balance. If the customer has ANY existing amount in the Unpaid Balanace, they must pay it in-full to qualify.
The customer must agree to pay
something
towards a usage credit. A good starting point is at least half of their negative balance, plus $25 if they are off (disconnected).
If they are off (disconnected), the payment must be AT LEAST $25.
The deferred limit is $100, any amounts owed above that must be paid by the customer.
The customer must make the payment FIRST, then call back (if not making the payment while on the phone) to setup the deferred balance.
The customer agrees to the deferred balance requirements with a 35% recovery rate.
Example 1 (Balance Under $100)
Unpaid Balance
This is an example of a MyWay customer who will qualify after making a required payment. Notice that the Unpaid Balance box is blank which means they have no existing deferred balance. If they cannot pay the $42.12 plus a usage credit, you could offer the financial relief.
The customer should pay at least half of the $42.12, $21 for example, and call back (if needed) to setup the deferred balance. If the customer must call back, ensure that you document in the Customer Contact.
Example Customer Contact:
POWELL,CHARLES R CANNOT PAY ENTIRE NEGATIVE BALANCE TO AVOID DISCONNECTION. WILL PAY $21 AND CALL BACK TO PLACE $42.12 INTO DEFERRED AT 35%. BELLMD2 X7896
Example 2 (Balance Over $100)
Unpaid Balance
In an example like this, after the customer makes a payment ($60, for example), you may place UP-TO $100 into deferred. By placing $100 into deferred, the customer will have a usage credit of about $40. (-$120.10, +$60 payment, +$100 moved to deferred).
This is an example of a MyWay customer who will qualify after making a required payment. Notice that the Unpaid Balance box is blank which means they have no existing deferred balance. If they cannot pay the $120.10 plus a usage credit, you could offer the financial relief.
The customer should pay at least half of the $120.10, $60 for example, and call back (if needed) to setup the deferred balance. If the customer must call back, ensure that you document in the Customer Contact.

MyWay Reconciliation Adjustment
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
At times you will need to verify the tender type a customer used. This is most commonly used when the customer is requesting a refund check or a payment canceled.
Reconciliation Line
A Reconciliation Adjustment happens once a month if there is a billing adjustment on the account. The adjustment may be a credit or a charge. Usually this is for usage not captured between MyUsage and CCB in a one-month period.
The day of reconciliation is highlighted in orange.
Reconciliation Line
Notice in CCB the system shows a Bill Segment date of 08/09/2022. This date matches the reconciliation date highlighted above in MyUsage.
Considering that MyWay is a pay-as-you-use service, and customers do not receive a bill each month (as a Traditional customer would), there may be times when explaining reconciliation becomes challenging.
Below are two examples of suggested verbiage for explaining reconciliation to a customer.
Verbiage Example 1
We house your information in two different systems. We have the monthly billing system and the daily prepaid system. About every 30 days the accounts go through a review. Both accounts must match up. If we were billing you monthly, is it matching the same charges as we have been charging you daily? If not, then you either get a debit or credit on your account.
Verbiage Example 2
We cannot charge a MyWay customer any more or any less than if we’re billing the account each month. About every 30 days your account will go through a reconciliation process. We look at the prepaid daily billing system compared to the monthly billing system. If we see that we have not charges the prepaid account the same as if we were sending a traditional bill, then a reconciliation is done. You will see a credit or a debit for the difference.
Taxes and fees are estimated based off your previous usage. With prepaid, our system trues up about every 30 days. If you had more consumption, the system trues up and you may owe a little more. If you had less consumption, you will owe less.

Returning Customer Wants to Start MyWay

A Returning customer is a customer who has had service with JEA in the past and is now returning to start service again.
Nothing changes with a Returning customer who wants to start MyWay, the following still needs to take place:

is not checked.

If the write-off balance is less than four years old, the amount is under $750, and they are starting JEA MyWay service …
The customer is required to pay ALL the amount owed.
OR
Pay At least ½ the balance and the other half can be placed into an Unpaid Balance, and they must pay the initial starting credit of $50 plus Start Option fees.
If the write-off balance is less than four years old, the amount owed is over $750.00, and they are starting JEA MyWay service …
The customer is required to pay ALL the amount owed.
OR
Pay At least ½ the balance and the other half can be placed into an Unpaid Balance, unless it is still over $750, they will need to pay the extra to bring it down to $750. They must pay the initial starting credit of $50 plus Start Option fees.

MyWay & MyUsage Overview (C)
Estimated reading: 1 minute
JEA MyWay is a prepaid utility program which allows customers to control the frequency and amount of their payments based on their usage habits.
This program is designed to assist customers with obtaining and managing their utility services.
This program is beneficial for customers who:
Are required to pay a large deposit.
Need assistance with managing high bills.
Are looking for a more intuitive, self-service type alternative.
The Benefits of JEA MyWay
Customers of JEA MyWay will receive the following benefits:
Freedom from deposits and late fees.
No electric reconnection fees (only water and irrigation have reconnect fees).
Access to consumption information 24/7.
Alert notifications when an account balance becomes low, is pending disconnection, or is disconnected.
Ability to defer a portion of the utility payment to outstanding balances.

Unpaid / Deferred Balance for a New MyWay Customer
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
It’s common for a customer who converts to MyWay to have a leftover balance, or unpaid Deposit, from Traditional billing. When converting to MyWay, the outstanding balance can be placed into an
Unpaid Balance
(deferred billing) and paid over time.
An amount of up to $750.00 may be placed into an Unpaid Balance. If the amount the customer owes exceeds $750.00, the difference, along with the initial starting credit, must be paid prior to starting MyWay service.
After converting to MyWay, 35% (
Recovery Rate
) of the customer’s subsequent payments go towards the Unpaid Balance until it is paid-in-full, or when they convert back to traditional service. The customer can call before making a payment and state they want an entire payment to go towards their Unpaid Balance if they have sufficient credit on the usage side.
If you observe a Recovery Rate greater than 35%, such as 50%, this has been set by Revenue Assurance and should be left as is.
Unpaid Balance Minimum Amount
It is very important to accurately inform the customer of the initial starting credit amount needed to start JEA MyWay service, as well as any outstanding debt that may be deferred.
If the customer has a balance of
$30.00 or less
it must be paid with the initial $50.00 starting credit. Amounts owed over $30 may be placed into the Unpaid Balance.
NOTE
Quotes for JEA MyWay are good for
the day of the quote only
as unbilled usage is constantly accruing.

Covert an Existing Traditional Customer to MyWay
Estimated reading: 13 minutes
Once an existing customer is ready to start MyWay service, you will begin the process by converting their account to a JEA MyWay Account.
This process is for a customer that is converting their existing account/address to MyWay; not transferring to a new address.
Since this procedure is a bit complex, it has been broken down into the following parts:
Part One: Re-Verify Premise Eligibility
Part Two: Calculate the Initial Starting Credit
Part Three: After Starting Credit is Paid, Convert the Existing Account to MyWay
Part Four: Setup Alerts and Create the Customer Login for MyUsage
Part Five: Create the MyWay Start Service Request
Allowable Converting Timeframe
Traditional customers can convert to MyWay (at the same address) up-to close-of-business hours. However, if the conversion is done after 3pm, you must inform the customer that normal service start times are up-to 3pm; if it is after 3pm, any RCD issues or water-ON issues could prevent the customers services from fully starting until the next business day.
Customer Advisors should observe the meter status(es) (check
Field Activities
) to educate the customer on any potential starting issues.
Part One: Re-Verify Premise Eligibility
In order to be eligible for JEA MyWay, the Electric meter must:
be on Network Meter Reading (NMR) route.
have electric service with the following:
Amps-30
Class-200
Form-2s or 12s
Voltage-240
Must NOT be a Commercial service point
Must NOT be 3-Phase
In order to be eligible for JEA MyWay, the Water meter must:
Be on Network Meter Reading (NMR) route
Be a meter that reads in gallons (1’s, 10’s, 50’s, or 100’s).
if the meter is CCF, they cannot start MyWay
until a Damaged Meter FA is created, completed by the Field, and the customer has billed.
Good reads in MDMS for the last five consecutive days.
Read Origin: LG-USC, Reading Flag: Regular
OR
Read Origin: Badger, Reading Flag, Regular
If the Premise meets these eligibility requirements, you can proceed to
Part Two
,
Calculating the Initial Starting Credit
.
IMPORTANT
If the Water requirements are not met, the meter must be exchanged and the account must bill on the new meter before the customer can convert to MyWay.
Use the following steps to verify MyWay eligibility:

Step 2
Step 3
Step 4

button.

and click the
Continue

STOP HERE:
The customer will need to call JEA back after they receive the bill on the new meter in order to convert to MyWay. At that time they will need to pay the MyWay initial starting credit (unless they have the amount as a credit already on their account).

Start a New MyWay Customer
Estimated reading: 9 minutes
Starting MyWay for a
new
customer is completed via the CCB Script; completely independent of using MyUsage.
New MyWay starts can be started up-to 3pm, same as a Traditional start.
After the required
Start Credit
and
Start Option
fees are paid, the customer will need to call back and request service be started with MyWay.
Example
$50 Starting Credit
$20 Connection Fees (Prescheduled Electric/Water)
= $70 total to start MyWay
Misapplied Payment
If a
misapplied payment
occurred, the Script will not let you start service because the required payment is missing. You must follow
all regular misapplied payment procedures
including:
Receiving payment documentation from the customer or by locating the correct payment on another (customer’s) account
Opening the misapplied payment case BEFORE proceeding
Then, you may call the Assist Line (x2520) to have the payment moved immediately so that the customer can start services.
