MyWay Eligibility Criteria
Estimated reading: 5 minutes
A customer must meet certain criteria in order to be eligible for JEA MyWay.
The criteria to meet includes requirements for:
Account
Premise
Meters
Prior to offering the JEA MyWay service to the customer, the following must be reviewed to determine if the account may be eligible:
Account
Premise
Water Meter
Electric Meter/Service
In order to be eligible for JEA MyWay the account must:
be Residential
not have a Medical Alert or Life Support Flag
not be a Commercial Account
have at least one method of Contact Information (phone, email)
have only one premise per account
have no Account Alerts such as Service Risk or Fraud
Will no longer be eligible for Monthly Billing Programs or Plans such as:
Pay Plans
Pay Arrangements
MyBudget
Residential Budget
AutoPay
eBill
The system will automatically stop the Billing Programs such as
Pay Plans, Pay Arrangements and MyBudget
upon converting to MyWay.
SPECIAL CIRCUMSTANCES
If a customer has a voucher, they may want to wait until the voucher is paid so they won’t lose the voucher before they start MyWay. You may also suggest that they call their agency to see if they would be willing to change the voucher to a Pre-Paid voucher.
If the account is in Collections or Severance, a Pay Plan must be created to address the severance amount temporarily to cancel the m-cut for non-pay Field Activity.
In order to be eligible for JEA MyWay the premise must:
have electric service
have no Water only service
have no Water/Sewer only service
have no Electric/Sewer only service
not have PV solar
I
n order to be eligible for JEA MyWay the water meter must:
Be on Network Meter Reading (NMR) route
Existing Customers
:
Reads in gallons (1’s, 10’s, 50’s, or 100’s).
Good reads in MDMS for the last five consecutive days.
Read Origin: LG-USC, Reading Flag: Regular
OR
Read Origin: Badger, Reading Flag, Regular
If the Existing customer does NOT meet this criteria, use the Script to create a Damaged Meter FA. The customer can convert after the FA is completed by the Field and they have billed with the new meter.
Note:
This does not apply to New customers. Even if reads are not good, service can be started; the script will create a Damaged Meter FA.
New and Existing Customers
: not have a CCF meter. If they have a CCF meter, a Damaged Meter FA must be created, completed by the Field, and they must bill with the new meter. New customers will need to start on traditional (temporarily) then convert to MyWay after the address bills.
In order to be eligible for JEA My Way the electric service must:
be on Network Meter Reading (NMR) route. If it doesn’t have a 2-way meter, the Script will request a 2-way exchange meter Field Activity (FA).
have electric service with the following:
Amps-30
Class-200
Form-2s or 12s
Voltage-240
If the numbers are less than the above it is also good to start. It just cannot be higher.
Must NOT be a Commercial service point
Must NOT be 3-Phase, see images (below)

MyWay Account Information in CCB
Estimated reading: 1 minute
Basic account information can be reviewed in CCB such as the credit balance or the amount owed on the account.
For accuracy, the balance in CCB should always be confirmed with the balance that is in MyUsage before quoting the amount to the customer.
In CCB if the balance is a positive amount (debt), the account has no money left to apply towards usage, and the amount listed is what is owed.
Notice that the
Prepaid – Remaining Balance
and the
Prepaid – Request Minimum Payment
amounts are the same. If a payment of $4.38 is made, the account balance would then be zero.
On the
Account Information
tab, locate the
Account and Person Characteristics
zone.
For example, a balance showing $4.38 would indicate the amount is owed to JEA.
A balance showing -$4.38 would indicate a credit that can be applied towards usage.

Convert a Traditional Customer to MyWay With Transfer
Estimated reading: 12 minutes
When a Traditional service customer calls to Transfer service with a Stop/Start overlap, and they want to convert to JEA MyWay at the same time, the process is similar to converting an existing Traditional customer to MyWay. The only difference is if both the current and new addresses are MyWay ready, after converting the current address to MyWay, you will also complete a MyWay-to-MyWay Transfer.
Part One: Verify Current Premise & New Premise Eligibility
In order to be eligible for JEA MyWay, the Electric meter at BOTH addresses must:
be on Network Meter Reading (NMR) route.
have electric service with the following:
Amps-30
Class-200
Form-2s or 12s
Voltage-240
Must NOT be a Commercial service point
Must NOT be 3-Phase
In order to be eligible for JEA MyWay, the Water meter at BOTH addresses must:
be a meter that reads in
gallons
be on Network Meter Reading (NMR) route
have Automated Meter Read (AMR) reads showing in Meter Data Management System (MDMS) for the last five (5) consecutive days
read in 10, 50, or 100 gallons
If the current Premise and new Premise meet these eligibility requirements, you can proceed to
Part Two
,
Calculating the Initial Starting Credit
.
IMPORTANT
If the Water requirements are not met for both addresses, the customer must stay on Traditional and Transfer to the new address. The  new address meter must be exchanged (if not eligible) and the account must bill before the customer can convert to MyWay.

Required Quality Information for New MyWay Customers
Estimated reading: 4 minutes
Customer Advisor’s must review required information with all new MyWay customers. This required information will vary, depending if the customer has a deferred balance, whether they signup for text alerts, etc. Some of this information may have already been discussed with the customer during the initial MyWay inquiry. Ensure all of the required information has been covered with the customer.
Required Information Topics
Review each of the following tabs containing the required information:
Overview
Medical Needs
Starting Credit
Unpaid Balance Disclaimer
General
Alerts
Welcome Packet and Wrap-Up
The JEA MyWay service is a pay-as-you-go option for utilities. You will be pre-paying for all services. There is no monthly statement and all notifications will be received by phone, text or email to keep you aware of your account status.
Is there anyone residing in the home that will be on medical equipment powered by electricity?
If “yes”: JEA MyWay is not eligible for anyone who is medically dependent on electricity.
To start, a minimum starting credit of $50 plus any applicable fees will be required.
The account will have a starting credit of $____ to go towards future consumption after connection fees are billed.
NOTE
If the last payment on the traditional account is an NSF, at least half of the NSF amount in addition to the startup credit and fees will be required, to convert to MyWay.
We are able to place a maximum of $750 in deferred billing. Once service begins, 35% of each payment will be allocated to this debt, until the balance is paid in full.
At this time we are placing $___ into deferred billing. Starting with your next payment, 35% of the amount paid will be allocated to this debt, until the balance is paid in full.
At any time there is an option to convert to traditional services. A payment of any unpaid balances and a full deposit may be required in order to do so.
With JEA MyWay you are in control of your account and able to pay as little or as much as you like, as long as a credit balance is maintained. Your account status and history can be viewed 24 hrs a day/7 days a week at myusage.com or on the app, JEA MyWay.
All notifications will be received by phone, text, or email. How would you like to be notified? The MyWay service is run strictly on the alert system, so if you make any changes to your contact information, please log into myusage.com to update or contact JEA MyWay Customer Service to update, to ensure your alerts will continue.
Please be aware that standard text messaging rates will apply, according to your cellphone plan, for all alerts received (must say).
There are three different alert types that will be received. The first is a “Low Balance Threshold Alert.” The threshold defaults at $10, so no alerts will be received until your account credit balance is below $10. The second alert type is the “Pending Disconnection Alert.” This alert lets you know when your account has reached a 0 balance or has gone into the negative status. Once this alert is received, you have 24 hrs to make a payment, before your service is in danger of interruption. The final alert type is the “Disconnection Alert.” The disconnection alert lets you know your service has been interrupted for non-payment. Once service is interrupted, there will be a minimum payment required of $25 as a starting credit plus any unpaid usage to restore service.
With your MyWay account, you receive a Welcome Packet by email and have access to MyUsage.com and the JEA MyWay Mobile App. This website and mobile app allows you to view your account history and status. To login you will use your email address for the username. Your password will be the word PASSWORD (in ALL CAPS).
Are there any other questions you have regarding JEA MyWay service?
NOTE
If the customer does not have an email address, their name should be used with the default domain of @noemail.com. (example, John.Doe@noemail.com)

Transfer MyWay to MyWay
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
The process that you follow for Transferring MyWay service will depend if the two dates will overlap or not.
Transfer With an Overlap
To transfer from a MyWay address to a different MyWay address, the customer must have enough of a starting credit balance to cover the new connection fees. If not, they will need to make a payment in order to transfer.
Create the Transfer in CCB Script. You can have a same day start and stop.
MyUsage will systematically change the meter information when the SA’s activate. You do not need to go to MyUsage unless the customer wants to update Alerts.
If the new address does not have a 2-way meter, the script will create the 2-way meter exchange Field Activity (FA).

Transfer Without an Overlap
If the customer is stopping MyWay service before they want the new address to start MyWay, the stopped address must have final billed.
For example, a customer wants to stop on a Wednesday and not start again until Friday.

MyWay Disconnect & Reconnect
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
Disconnection Alerts
MyWay customers are provided with a 1-day disconnection notice. This means that when the prepaid funds are exhausted they are not immediately disconnected.
Depending on the day of the week, and if a weekend or holiday is involved, the disconnection order can occur as soon as the next business day.

This message is from JEA. Press 1 to Opt Out, or call 877-764-0042. Account 1234567891 will be disconnected as early as September 14th at 9AM. Please make a minimum payment of $123.23 to avoid disconnection. Representatives do not know the exact time of disconnection. Holidays or extreme weather may cause a delay. JEA Update:
Acct 1234567891 is sched. for disconnection as early as Mon 09/14 at 9AM. A min. payment of $123.23 is needed.
Making a Payment After the Disconnection is Completed
It is possible for a Customer Advisor to inform a caller of a required payment amount prior to disconnection, then the required amount changes if the customer pays after disconnection; if the disconnection completes, MyUsage will require an additional $25 starting credit payment.
Customers who call in prior to 9am should always be reminded that if they pay any time after 9am, they may be off and required to pay the balance plus the $25.
Service Agreements Have Stopped
If the customer is off for non-pay and wants to restart service, but the Service Agreements have stopped, the customer will need to restart MyWay service as a New MyWay customer. Before MyWay service can be started, the customer will have to pay:
The $50 starting credit
Connection fees
Any balance owed

Electric Transmission Lines
Estimated reading: 1 minute
Transmission lines carry electric energy from one point to another in an electric power system. They can carry alternating current, direct current, or a system can be a combination of both.
Overhead transmission lines with tree clearance
Electric current can be carried by overhead or underground lines. The main characteristics that distinguish transmission lines from distribution lines are that they are operated at relatively high voltages, they transmit large quantities of power, and they transmit the power over large distances.
Overhead AC transmission lines share one characteristic; they carry 3-phase current.

Alerts Preference Center (APC)
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
Customer Advisors can view and modify a customers voice, text, and email Alerts Preference Center (APC) via FMSWeb. These are the same alerts that a customer can setup via JEA.com. If a customer modifies their alerts, a CA will see the changes via FMSWeb and vice versa. Because a customer may not always be able to set or modify their alerts themselves, CA’s can create and modify alerts for the customer, or use the APC as an educational piece when speaking to customers.
Customers and CA’s can setup alerts for situations such as:
When their bill is ready to be viewed
When their bill due date is a few days away
When their payment has posted
When their usage has reached a certain dollar, electric (kWh) or water (gal) amount
When an electric outage they reported has an updated status such as crew assigned, estimated restoration time and cause.
When a service disconnection notice has been sent
When service is started or stopped
Customers can change their alert preferences, contact information or unsubscribe at any time by signing into their online account at
https://www.jea.com/My_Account/Alerts/
.

Electric Protective Equipment
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
Protective equipment in a distribution system consists of protective relays, cutout switches; disconnect switches, lightning arresters, and fuses.
These work individually or may work in concert to open circuits whenever there is a short circuit, lightning strike, or other disruptive event occurs.
How Protective Equipment Works
When circuit breakers open, the entire distribution circuit is de-energized since this can disrupt power to many customers; the distribution system is often designed with many layers of redundancy. Through redundancy, power can be shut off in portions of the system only, but not the entire system, or can be redirected to continue to serve customers.
Only in extreme events, or failure of redundant systems, does an entire system become de-energized, shutting off power to large numbers of customers
The redundancy consists of the many fuses and fused cutouts throughout the system that can disable parts of the system but not the entire system. Lightning arresters also act locally to drain off electrical energy from a lightning strike so that the larger circuit breakers are not actuated.
Switches
Distribution systems have switches installed at strategic locations to redirect or cut-off power flows for load balancing or sectionalizing.
Three-Phase Bypass Switch
Also, this permits repairing of damaged lines or equipment or upgrading work on the system.
Switch types include:
Circuit Breaker Switches
Single-Pole Disconnect Switches
Three-Pole Group-Operated Switches
Pad-Mounted Switchgear

Outage Troubleshooting Questions
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
Customer Advisors will try to use techniques to isolate the type of a service issue. This allows the ability to choose the correct problem code and possibly help the caller restore their services themselves.
Use the following questions to isolate the issue and troubleshoot with the customer:
Electric Outage Questions
Water Outage Questions
Wastewater Issue Questions
Street Light or Area Light Questions
Questions to ask to isolate an electric outage:
Did you reset your indoor and outdoor breakers?
Did your lights flicker?
Are your lights very bright or dim?
Do you notice a down power line?
Questions to ask to isolate a water outage:
Is the water out in the entire home?
Do you notice if the water is dirty or cloudy?
Do you notice if the water pressure is low?
Do you notice a leak inside or outside of your home?
Do you have a water softener?
Have you checked your stop/waste valve?
Questions to ask to isolate a wastewater (sewer) issue:
Is the sewage backing up in the entire home (bathroom, kitchen, etc.)?
Do you notice sewer in your yard?
Is the sewage coming from a manhole?
Questions to ask to isolate a Street Light or Area Light issue:
Is the light always on?
Is the light always off?

Wastewater / Sewer Treatment
Estimated reading: 1 minute
Sewage treatment, or domestic wastewater treatment, is the process of removing contaminants from wastewater, both runoff (effluents) and domestic. It includes physical, chemical and biological processes to remove physical, chemical and biological contaminants.
Its objective is to produce a waste stream (or treated effluent) and a solid waste or sludge suitable for discharge or reuse back into the environment. This material is often inadvertently contaminated with many toxic organic and inorganic compounds.
JEA Wastewater Treatment Facility
The sewage treatment involves three stages, called primary, secondary and tertiary treatment:
First, the solids are separated from the wastewater stream.
Dissolved biological matter is progressively converted into a solid mass by using indigenous, water-borne microorganisms.
The biological solids are neutralized then disposed of or re-used, and the treated water may be disinfected chemically or physically (for example by lagoons and micro-filtration).
The final effluent can be discharged into a stream, river, bay, lagoon or wetland, or it can be used for the irrigation of a golf course, green way or park. If it is sufficiently clean, it can also be used for groundwater recharge.

Electric Distribution System
Estimated reading: 1 minute
A distribution system originates at a distribution substation and includes the lines, poles, transformers, and other equipment needed to deliver electric power to the customer at the required voltages.
Customers are classed as:
Industrial Customers
Commercial Customers
Residential Customers
Most industries need 2,400 to 4,160 volts to run heavy machinery and usually their own substation, or substations, to reduce the voltage from the transmission line to the desired level for distribution throughout the plant area. They usually require 3-phase lines to power 3-phase motors.
Commercial customers are usually served at distribution voltages, ranging from 14.4 kV to 7.2 kV through a service drop line which leads from a transformer on or near the distribution pole to the customer’s end use structure. They may require 3-phase lines to power 3-phase motors.
The distribution of electricity is reduced to the end use voltage (120/240 volts single phase) via a pole mounted or pad-mounted transformer. Power is delivered to the residential customer through a service drop line which leads from the distribution pole transformer to the customer’s structure, for overhead lines or underground.

JEA Water Service Line Verification Project
Estimated reading: 10 minutes
Since the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) first published the Lead and Copper Rule in 1991, it has been revised multiple times to better protect children and communities at risk for lead exposure. After several years of review and analysis, the EPA released Lead and Copper Rule Revisions (LCRR) on October 16, 2021.
JEA is proactively completing the service line materials inventory to better protect customers by expediting the removal of lead service lines from the drinking water system. JEA is employing a range of methods to check service line materials, including historical record review, vacuum excavation, statistical analysis, and customer self-reporting.
Key Lead and Copper Rule Revisions (LCRR) requirements include:
Develop a materials inventory of all service lines – both public and private
Create a lead service line replacement plan based on the results of the inventory
Update/expand the compliance sampling pool based on new criteria
Prepare a sampling plan for schools and licensed daycares
Review and/or develop the corrosion control program
The project is called the
JEA Water Line Verification Project
.

If lead is found, information on how to lessen a customer’s exposure to lead will be provided along with next steps. This work should take about 2 hours total.
No water outages are expected.
Afterwards, we’ll leave information about the water service line at their door. The customer does NOT need to be home during the inspection work.

FAQs About the LCRR
What is the LCRR?
The Lead and Copper Rule Revisions (LCRR) is an addendum to the Lead and Copper Rule that the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) established in 1991. The LCRR is designed to keep people in the United States safe from the dangers of drinking water contaminated by lead and copper. The LCRR requires all public water service providers in the U.S., like JEA, to take inventory of all unknown material water lines to determine if those lines contain any lead or copper.
For more information on the Lead and Copper Rule, visit:
United States EPA Lead and Copper Rule
United States EPA Revised Lead and Copper Rule
Does JEA test its water for lead and/or copper?
Yes. When water leaves JEA’s water Treatment plants, it complies with all federal and state standards. We perform an average of 45,000 water tests each year, with the samples examined for more than 100 bacteriological and chemical components. You can view our annual water quality reports here:
https://www.jea.com/about/water_supply/water_quality_reports/
.
How does lead get into the drinking water if JEA tests for lead?
Lead gets into drinking water due to the corrosion of lead pipes or other parts made from lead, including the service line between the street and your home or building.
FAQs About the Water Service Line Verification Project
What is the Water Service Line Verification Project?
JEA’s Water Line Verification Project will take inventory of all unknown material water lines in our service territory to determine if there are any lead lines remaining in our water system so that we can take the steps needed to replace them. This project also includes JEA inspections of a randomly selected group of customer water lines as well as a future request for customers to complete a water line self-verification if their home was built prior to June 1986, when the
Safe Drinking Water Act
was passed.
What is a water service line?
A water service line is the small pipe that carries water into your home or business from JEA’s water main located in the City’s right-of-way and easements. These lines can be made of plastic, brass, copper, cast iron, flexible iron, lead, or galvanized steel (which could contain lead).
Who is responsible for water service lines?
The property owner owns the water service line between the home and the JEA meter. Therefore, this line is the responsibility of the property owner.
Why was my home’s water service line selected for verification?
In compliance with the LCRR, JEA’s Water Line Verification Project will take inventory of all unknown material water lines in our service territory which will include JEA inspections of a randomly selected group of customer water service lines.
What should I expect when my water service line is being checked?
A JEA contractor will dig small holes near the water meter box which is typically located in the City right-of way. This will allow us to determine if your water service line is made of lead, copper, galvanized steel or plastic. You do not need to be home while we check your service line and you will not experience any interruption in water service during this work. Verification should take about two hours and the area will be restored to its original appearance.
How will I know what material my water service line is made of?
Once line verification is complete, our team will leave a doorhanger at your door confirming the material of your service line. If lead is found, information on how to lessen your exposure to lead will be provided along with next steps.
FAQs for Customers With Lead Water Service Lines
If my home or business’s plumbing has a lead service line or lead solder, how can I protect myself?
If you think your service line is made of lead or contains a lead solder (a metal alloy made of lead and tin to join pipes together), take the following steps to lessen your chances of lead exposure:
Run your tap water for at least five minutes before drinking or cooking to flush out stagnant water and receive fresh water from the water main.
Use fresh, cold, running water for drinking, cooking or preparing baby formula.
Remove and clean faucet screens and aerators every six months.
Buy lead-free plumbing fixtures (faucets, valves, sinks, hose bibs, etc.) that meets the current “lead-free’ requirements.
Use a National Sanitation Foundation (NSF)-certified home water treatment device, faucet or pitcher filter that removes lead. The device must be both NSF 42- and NSF-53-certified to remove lead.
What if I would like to have my private lead service lines replaced now?
Property owners have the option to hire a licensed plumber to replace their water service line. The cost of replacing the customer-side of the service line is the responsibility of the property owner.
If you decide to replace your water service line, please contact our Water Quality team at 904-665-4521 or
waterquality@jea.com
to schedule an onsite review and assistance with any part of the service line that might be JEA’s responsibility.
JEA does not currently offer reimbursement for water service line replacements. However, we’re monitoring Federal legislation that may provide financial assistance in the future. We will inform our customers if financial assistance becomes available.
What should I do if I’m concerned about lead in my drinking water?
You may contact JEA’s Water Quality team by phone at 904-665-4521 or by email
waterquality@jea.com
and request that your water is tested.
What do I do if I suspect lead poisoning?
Contact the EPA Safe Drinking Water Hotline immediately at 1-800-424-5323 or visit the EPA website to complete an online form located at
https://www.epa.gov/lead/forms/national-lead-information-center-document-request-form
.
The EPA’s Safe Drinking Water Hotline is also available to answer your questions and concerns at 1-800-424-5323 or visit the EPA website to complete an online question form.
https://www.epa.gov/ground-water-and-drinking-water/forms/online-form-epas-office-ground-water-and-drinking-water
Where can I find more information and lead service line resources?

Current Transformers
Estimated reading: 1 minute
Current transformers can be used to supply information for measuring power flows and the electrical inputs for the operation of protective relays associated with the transmission and distribution circuits or for power transformers.
These current transformers have the primary winding connected in series with the conductor carrying the current to be measured or controlled.
The secondary winding is thus insulated from the high voltage and can then be connected to low-voltage metering circuits.
Current transformers are also used for street lighting circuits. Street lighting requires a constant current to prevent flickering lights and a current transformer is used to provide that constant current.
Current transformer utilize a moving secondary coil to vary the output so that a constant current is obtained.
Current Transformer

Loss of Power (Outage) Situations
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
When one of our customers cannot receive service we are concerned, and even more so when there are a mass number of customers throughout the city or in a localized area without power.
FMSWeb is used to launch
Emergency Outage Tickets
and to learn updates on outage situations.
When the lights go out, customers want to know why their power is out and when it will be restored. Receiving information is as important to the customer as the actual work that is performed to restore power.
JD Powers and Associates
When JEA is notified of a loss of power (either by our own system alert or via a customer) we immediately launch an investigation to identify the affected areas, conduct an analysis to determine the root cause of the outage, and provide our Customer Advisors with information to keep our customers informed of our progress in restoring their service.
JEA provides four points of information to every customer that contacts us to report an outage:
Estimated Time of Restoration (ETR)
Status of the Restoration Effort
Cause of the Outage
Number of Customers Affected
When the call is received to advise us of an outage, the Customer Advisor will thank the customer for calling to report the outage and then proceed to launch FMSWeb.
The CA will search for the affected address and then validate the account status using CCB or the field status on the
Caller Information Panel
in FMSWeb.
Address Disconnected for Non-Payment
If the CA determines that the caller’s address has been disconnected for non-payment, they will state to the customer “Our records indicate your service has been disconnected due to non-payment.”
The CA will provide the customer with the date of their last payment, the account balance, and proceed to discuss reconnection options, payment options, and hours and locations of where they can make a payment.
If the address is not scheduled for interruption then the CA will initiate a discovery process to determine why the customer is without service.
Loss of Power With Repair Needed
If it is determined that the service interruption is not caused by JEA, then the CA would inform the customer of the appropriate actions to restore service.
If the needed repair is something that the customer is unskilled in performing (such as a breaker reset), or requires a licensed electrician to make repairs, then the CA would inform the customer to contact a licensed contractor or their designated maintenance person.
Loss of Power Due to Outage
If none of the aforementioned situations apply to the customer and it is determined that they are part of an area outage problem, the CA will generate a ticket and provide the caller with JEA’s four points of outage information. The CA will offer an automated callback to notify the customer that power is restored.
To end the call, the CA will provide the customer with the following recommendation:
“Remember to unplug sensitive or expensive electronic equipment to prevent damage related to a power surge when the power is restored.”
Apologize for the inconvenience.

Water Meter
Estimated reading: 1 minute
A water meter is a device used to measure the volume of water usage.
Water Meter
Most meters in a typical water distribution system are designed for cold potable water only. Water meters are generally owned, read, and maintained by a public water provider such as a city, rural water association, or private water company.
In some instances an owner of a mobile home park, apartment complex or commercial building may be billed by a utility on one meter, and want to share the cost of the bill among the tenants. In this scenario, private meters may be purchased to separately track usage of each unit in what is called sub-metering.

Fire Hydrant
Estimated reading: 1 minute
A fire hydrant is an active fire protection measure, and a source of water provided in urban, suburban and rural areas with municipal water service to enable firefighters to tap into the municipal water supply to assist in extinguishing a fire.
Most fire hydrant valves are not designed to throttle the water flow; they are designed to be operated full-on or full-off. The valving arrangement of most dry-barrel hydrants is for the drain valve to be open at anything other than full operation.
Usage at partial-opening can consequently result in considerable flow directly into the soil surrounding the hydrant, which, over time, can cause severe scouring. A hose with a closed nozzle valve, or fire truck connection, or closed gate valve is always attached to the hydrant prior to opening the hydrant’s main valve.
Public fire hydrants are yellow; privately own fire hydrants are red.

Backflow Prevention Device
Estimated reading: 10 minutes
A backflow prevention device is used to protect water supplies from contamination or pollution.
Many types of backflow prevention devices also have test ports so that they can be tested or examined to ensure that they are functioning properly. Many states and/or local municipalities actually require annual testing of such devices. A check valve is a common form of a backflow preventer.
Backflow prevention protects the potable water system from minor, moderate, and severe hazards. There are over 10,000 reported occurrences of backflow contamination each year. Some occurrences can be fatal. Backflow devices are required by law where needed and must be installed in accordance with plumbing or building codes.
A backflow assembly has test ports and shut-off valves and must be tested each year, if relocated or repaired, and when installed. The simplest and most effective way to provide backflow prevention is to provide an air gap. An air gap is simply a space between any device that opens to a plumbing system (like a valve or faucet) and any place where water can collect or pool.
Backflow Prevention Device
In this situation, dirty water from the hillside pool will back siphon or back flow down the hosepipe and into the clean water tank.
The History of JEA’s Backflow Checkup Program
JEA’s Backflow Preventer Checkup program helps customers with JEA residential irrigation service connections comply with state environmental regulations designed to protect the quality of our drinking water.
Since 1990, the Florida Building Code has required that residential irrigation systems have a backflow preventer, a device that prevents dirt and other pollutants from entering the public water supply. The state requires that homeowners have their backflow preventers tested every two years by a certified backflow tester, and that water companies submit annual reports on the compliance status of their customers.
The State, in 2014, amended its backflow prevention rules requiring water companies to report annually on the compliance status of their customers.
Affected Customers & Timeline
Currently, only customers with an irrigation meter are affected. In total we test about 32,000 devices over a 2 year period. About 4,000 customers receive a notice per inspection period.
Every three months JEA performs a mass mailing to around 4,000 customers to explain the backflow process. Only customers with irrigation meters receive the notice. The backflow device needs to be installed and have a PASSED backflow tag on it.
If the back flow device has not been tested customers have the option to hire their own contractor to conduct the testing, they must submit the passing test report to JEA within 30 days. Upon receipt of the passing test results, JEA will notify the customer that their device is in compliance.
If the customer does nothing, then JEA’s backflow contractor will go out and test the backflow device.

and Fax: (904) 665-7378 – This email and fax number are for test results of those who “opt-out” of the JEA Backflow Prevention Testing program. This email and fax number are used almost exclusively by vendors performing the tests. It is very rare that a customer will send in his/her own results. The vendors are aware of the process and know they are responsible for returning the results.
General Backflow FAQs
What is cross-connection control?
JEA’s Cross Connection Control is mandated by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection to safeguard the drinking water supply from contamination. Cross connections occur anywhere the public water supply is connected to any other source, like a pool, pond or irrigation system. These cross connections pose a hazard if water that has been delivered from a different source enters the public water supply.
Cross connections can also occur if water delivered from the JEA line comes into contact with chemicals or other pollutants. This can occur due to accidental backflow of potentially contaminated water and it’s a big problem when that water reenters the JEA water supply.
What is backflow?
Backflow is an undesirable flow of water in the reverse direction. It occurs when there is a pressure drop that allows the pressure on the customer side to become more than the pressure on the supply side, causing water to flow in the reverse direction. A backflow preventer is a mechanical tool that prevents this from happening.
What is a backflow preventer?
Backflow preventers help prevent contaminated water, dangerous contaminants, such as microorganisms, bacteria, noxious chemicals, heavy metals, gases and other potentially threatening pollutants and substances from entering your community’s potable water system. Backflow preventers protect you, your family, your neighbors and everyone who draws from the same water supply.
What could happen if I don’t have a working backflow preventer?
Let’s say you want to mix up a bucket of fertilizer concentrate with water and decide to leave your backyard hose in the bucket as it fills up. If your water supply is suddenly shut off or the water main or supply pipe suddenly breaks, that could cause a severe shift in water pressure that, without a backflow protection system in place, could reverse flow the fertilizer into the drinking water and then contaminate the water supply from everyone nearby.
What is my responsibility in cross connection control?
Your responsibility starts at the point of delivery from the public potable water system and includes all your water systems. You are required, at your expense, to install, operate, test and maintain approved backflow prevention assemblies. Installation of backflow preventers must be installed by certified plumbers and tested by JEA-qualified vendors. The JEA-qualified vendors submit the test results to JEA on your behalf.
In the event of accidental pollution or contamination of the public’s potable water system due to backflow on or from your premises, you must promptly take steps to confine the further spread and immediately notify JEA.
Residential Backflow FAQs
What is the residential backflow testing program and how does it work?
JEA’s Backflow Preventer Checkup Program helps customers with JEA residential irrigation service connections comply with state environmental regulations designed to protect the quality our of drinking water. There are about 35,000 residential irrigation connections in the JEA service area. Each customer is assigned a quarter in which their property is tested based on their Zip code. This assignment does not change as this allows JEA to efficiently manage the program and ensure that all customers are tested within a two-year period.
Do I have to use a reduced pressure (RP) device, or can I use a double check (DC) device?
If an in-ground irrigation system was installed prior to May 4, 2014, a DC device may be used until January 2024 when every residential irrigation connection is mandated to be protected by a RP device.
Why do I need to have a backflow preventer if I don’t use my irrigation system?
If your irrigation meter is connected to the system, the backflow protection is required. If an air gap is created by physically disconnecting the system, the backflow protection is no longer required.
Do I have to use the vendor that left the doorhanger to repair or replace my backflow preventer?
No. You may use any certified plumber to install or repair your backflow preventer. However, the testing must be completed by a JEA-qualified vendor to ensure that your results are sent to JEA.
I don’t use JEA’s irrigation meter. My irrigation system is connected to a well.
If you have a well, a backflow preventer is required on your potable meter, per FAC 62-555.360. If you have a JEA irrigation meter, a backflow preventer is required for that meter.
Why are backflow preventers tested every two years?
The Florida Department of Environmental Protection requires that homeowners have their backflow preventers tested every two years to ensure they remain in good working order. The state also requires JEA to submit annual reports on their customers’ compliance with this requirement.
I received a notice to have my backflow preventer tested, but it’s been less than two years since my last test. Why?
JEA made the decision to temporarily suspend the residential testing program in 2020 for four months (March 2020-July 2020) due to COVID. Because you were tested late in 2020, you are simply being put back on track in 2022 and being tested on time, not early. You’re still only being tested twice within the four-year period. Q2, Q3 and Q4 are the quarters that were mainly affected by this suspension.
Since my schedule test date was postponed in 2020, why didn’t JEA adjust my scheduled test date to the new date?
To ensure that all residential backflow preventers are tested every two years, your backflow preventer has an anniversary date by which it should be tested. If it is tested after the anniversary date, the next test must be by the biennial anniversary date, regardless of how close it is to the last date.
Here’s an example: Your original test was performed on June 15, 2018. The next due date is June 15, 2020. However, due to the COVID suspensions, the test did not happen until Feb. 15, 2021; eight months past the required due date. The next required test is still June 15, 2022. The last two tests are closer together than we’d like, but all three were performed within the required timeframe.
On another note: JEA’s service areas includes more than 100,000 backflow preventer devices. Adjusting the test dates for those devices affected by the suspensions would be extremely difficult from a logistical perspective. In addition, this would result in all 100,000+ devices being tested over nine months instead of the usual 12 months.
Is JEA reducing the time between tests for customers to less than two years?
No.
I paid a backflow preventer testing company $50 for my last test? How much would it be if JEA performed the test?
The cost would $35 and added to your JEA bill.
When will the transition back to normal testing be completed?
All customers affected by the temporary testing suspensions in 2020 will be back to their normal testing schedule by November 2022.
How are affected customers being notified of the change back to their regular schedule?
Additional notices have been added to the testing reminders for affected customers.

Water Meter AMI Upgrade Project
Estimated reading: 9 minutes
Beginning in June 2023, every residential and commercial customer’s water meter(s) will be upgraded or replaced with a more technologically advanced version. The project should take approximately 4-years for all 400,000+ water meter customers to be upgraded. This state-of-the-art technology, Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI), will provide the customer new levels of information about their water usage and improve their service.
JEA is using a company called Envocore to install the devices. All technicians will drive a marked truck and will wear an Envocore shirt.
Customer’s can view project information via JEA.com:
https://www.jea.com/watermeter
Advanced Metering Infrastructure Benefits
Customers can monitor daily water consumption, which can positively impact monthly water bill.
Through this remote technology, readings can be done more quickly and efficiently than through current processes, eliminating manual readings in some neighborhoods.
JEA can identify water leaks and send alerts to customers.
What Customers Can Expect
A JEA contractor will their home or business to upgrade the system. They will receive an email and a post card in the mail from JEA up to two weeks prior to the upgrade.
The customer may experience a brief interruption of their water service during the upgrade. They will not need to take any precautionary steps before or after the upgrade.
Our contractor will leave a door hanger on the customer’s door with all of the details of the upgrade, including confirmation of completion or if a JEA contractor needs to return to complete the work.
Postcard Example, click the image to enlarge.
Door Hanger Example, click the image to enlarge.
FAQs
(Last Updated 06/12/2023)
What is the water meter change-out and why do customer’s need it?
Beginning in June 2023, JEA is upgrading its water meter technology to provide all water customers with more information about the water they use and improve service. The state-of-the-art AMI technology will replace an obsolete radio system to ensure JEA can continue to receive customers’ consumption data.
What are the benefits?
The benefits of the new AMI metering technology are numerous.
Customers will be able to monitor their water consumption, which can make an impact on their monthly water bill.
Through this remote technology, readings can be done more quickly and efficiently, eliminating manual readings in some neighborhoods.
We can identify water leaks early.
How many JEA customers will be impacted by this change?
JEA will be upgrading all of its 420,000 water meters across its service territory for residential and commercial customers.
When is the program starting?
The upgrades started June 5, 2023.
How long is this process going to take?
We anticipate that it will take four years to complete the change-out process across our entire service territory. For each individual household, the process should take only 30 minutes for the installation.
Will this save customers on their monthly water bill?
Because the new metering technology allows customers to monitor daily water consumption, the power to save on their monthly water bill is in their hands. Through responsible monitoring and modification of your water usage, customers may have the opportunity to save on their monthly bill. The technology alone won’t cause the savings, but customer behavior may.
Do customers have to participate in this process?
All JEA water customers will be included in this change-out process. But at no additional cost to the customer, and with considerable benefits, we hope customers will recognize the advantages this new technology.
How long will the change out take, and will the customer be without water service?
The installation process should take approximately 30 minutes. During this time the technician may need to briefly disconnect the water service. Customers will be notified at the time of arrival, so they can be prepared for the interruption should it be necessary.
How will the customer know when JEA is going to begin making this change for their household?
Within two weeks of the installation, customers will receive a postcard in the mail and an email with reminders about the upgrade and what to expect. We cannot schedule individual appointments.
Does the customer need to be present during the installation?
No, it is not necessary for the customer to be present during the change-out process. We simply ask that pets are secure, and the water meter is accessible. The technician will knock on the customer’s door upon arrival in the event the water must be turned off temporarily.
If the customer is not home at the time, how will they know the installation has been completed?
When the change out is completed, the technician will leave a door hanger informing the customer that the job is done. Should there be a problem, additional information regarding next steps will be indicated.
Is JEA doing these installations itself?
JEA is using a company called Envocore to install the devices. All technicians will drive a marked truck and will wear an Envocore shirt.
If a customer’s existing meter is damaged, can we submit for the meter to be switched out to AMI meter?
Yes, but only if the service point route number ends in “NMR.”
Will Customer Advisors receive an email when we start doing the upgrade and in what area (like the backflow process)?
No.
Within two weeks of the installation, customers will receive a postcard in the mail and an email with reminders about the upgrade and what to expect. We cannot schedule individual appointments.
If we have recently worked a damaged meter, will these need to be swapped out at a later date or will they get the new meter when the damaged meter is replaced?
The meter will be upgraded as long as the route is an NMR route.
If we find a customer that was already upgraded, was this part of a pilot or test?
Yes, there are several routes in Yulee that were used as a pilot.
Can a customer opt-out?
No, there is no opt-out option.
Will the meter upgrade show real-time usage?
Hourly reads will be made available to JEA every 6 hours. Daily reads will be available to the customer (current day will show yesterday’s consumption). After MDMS is upgraded in 2024, the hourly reads will be made visible to the customer on the next-day
Will the meter upgrade allow the water to be shut off electronically or is it just a transmittal device?
The upgrade will only allow the cellular transmission of reads.
There is a remote shutoff valve that is available. The valve and meter type are much more expensive, so this configuration is not being installed. JEA is evaluating the use of the valve for future business needs.
Will MyWay customers that need a water meter upgrade for daily reads will they automatically get the AMI meter?
Yes, MyWay customers will be getting an AMI meter if they are currently not getting daily reads.
Will the AMI upgrade improve reads if a vehicle is parked, or another object is above/blocking the meter?
The answer to this question is currently unkown.

Electric Meter
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
An electric meter or energy meter is a device that measures the amount of electrical energy supplied to or produced by a residence, business, or machine.
The most common type is more properly known as a kilowatt hour meter or a joule meter. When used in electricity retailing, JEA records the values measured by these meters to generate an invoice for the electricity. They may also record other variables including the time when the electricity was used.
About Advanced Meters
Advanced meters connect a customers home to the electric grid with two-way communication, recording usage data and sending it to JEA over a secure wireless network. These communications not only alert JEA when customers have a power outage but also allow customers to monitor their usage online. While some advanced meters communicate over electric power lines, many communicate using radio frequency (RF) – similar to those used by WiFi and laptop computers.
Advanced meter radios are idle 99 percent of the time, and during the few minutes each day they are in operation, they produce far lower levels of RF emissions than other common household items, including microwaves, laptops and cellphones.
Click here for more information via JEA.com
We have established that there are many benefits to the customer and JEA to have an Advanced Meter.
Enhance reliability by detecting power outages sooner, so JEA can restore service faster.
Enable customers to monitor their electricity usage on an hourly basis, helping them control their usage to save money.
Increase convenience, because meters are read remotely without a technician coming onto a customer’s property.
Offer quicker connection and disconnection service (performed remotely).
Reduce costs and emissions, because service trucks don’t need to come to your home.
Keep rates down by helping customers monitor and decrease their electricity usage, reducing the need for JEA to build new power plants.
Electric Meter Seal
The meter seal is a device used by JEA to prevent tampering and personal injury. In addition to safety prevention, the seal colors can represent the billing status of the customer’s service.
Cutting or removing the seal by anyone other than authorized JEA personnel is both dangerous and illegal.

Electric Substation
Estimated reading: 1 minute
A substation is a high-voltage electric system facility. It is used to switch generators, equipment, and circuits or lines in and out of a system.
It is also used to change AC voltages from one level to another, and/or change alternating current to direct current, or direct current to alternating current.
Point Meadows Substation
Substations are designed to accomplish the following functions, although not all substations have all these functions:
Change voltage from one level to another.
Regulate voltage to compensate for system voltage changes.
Switch transmission and distribution circuits into, and out of, the grid system.

Power Generation Plants
Estimated reading: 1 minute
A power generation plant is a facility designed to produce electric energy from another form of energy.
There are many different types of electric power generating plants. The major types generating electric power today are shown below.
Heat (thermal) energy generated from:
fossil fuels;
coal
petroleum
natural gas
solar thermal energy
geothermal energy
nuclear energy
Potential energy from falling water in a hydroelectric facility
Wind energy
Solar electric from solar (photovoltaic) cells
Chemical energy from:
fuel cells
batteries
The Northside Generating Station (NGS) uses natural gas, fuel oil, coal and petroleum coke in three large steam units and four small diesel-powered peaking units to produce more than 1300 MW of peak electric capacity.

Water Pipes

Water Pipes
Water pipes are pipes or tubes, frequently made of polyvinyl chloride (PVC/uPVC), ductile iron, polyethylene, or copper, that carry pressurized and treated fresh water to buildings (as part of a municipal water system), as well as inside the building.
PVC Water Pipes
For many centuries, lead was the favored material for water pipes, due to its malleability (this use was so common that the word “plumbing” derives from the Latin word for lead).
Lead water pipes were still in common use in the early 20th century and remain in many households. Lead-tin alloy solder was commonly used to join copper pipes, but modern practice uses tin-antimony alloy solder to join copper in order to eliminate lead hazards.
Wooden pipes were often used in Montreal and Boston in the 1800s. The pipes were hollowed out logs, which were tapered at the end with a small hole in which the water would pass through. The multiple pipes were then sealed together with hot animal fat.
Iron pipe was a lower cost alternative to copper, before the advent of durable plastic materials but special non-conductive fittings must be used where transitions are to be made to other metallic pipes, except for terminal fittings, in order to avoid corrosion owing to electrochemical reactions between dissimilar metals.

Landlord Agreements (Landlord Exsits)
Estimated reading: 4 minutes
Landlord Agreements are used to maintain availability of utility service(s) at all times, generally when there is no occupant or tenant at a premise. Any customer class can be set up on a Landlord agreement as long as they have five (5) active residential premises.
A Landlord Agreement flag will appear in the alert box on the account dashboard as well as on the premise itself. It is identified as
Landlord Exists
.
The following information is a summary of Landlord Agreements:
Service is not interrupted when transitioning to/from tenants.
Severance for nonpayment while under the tenant does not automatically reconnect the service back to the Landlord/Property Manager.
No connection fees are incurred when utility service(s) are resumed under the Landlord/Property Manager’s account only.
Service Agreement(s) cannot be stopped while active under the Landlord/Property Manager. The agreement must be canceled.
The Landlord/Property Manager is responsible for all active service agreements until a tenant activates and assumes responsibility for the service
1
. Because the account will have no lapse in service, there should never be a Consumption No Contact (CNC) on a landlord account.
1
Do NOT backdate service when a Landlord agreement is present. All billing disputes should be worked out between the parties unless it was due to an error by JEA.
NOTE
If a customer requests to remove an address from the Landlord Agreement, the removed address will not be eligible to be placed back on the Landlord Agreement for 12 months.
Starts and Stops
When the tenant calls to stop service, a start in the landlord’s name will automatically be issued. There is no lapse in service. As part of the landlord agreement we do not charge the landlord’s account a start option fee. The system will process a pending start with a No Charge Start option.
Consumption No Contract (CNC)
Landlord agreements are handled differently because of the relationship between the tenant and the landlord (the actual owner).
Because the account will have no lapse in service, there should never be a Consumption No Contract (CNC) on a landlord account.
In the rare chance there is a CNC verify with the landlord that they are not the responsible party for the CNC usage, if they state they are not, use the regular start service process.
Point of Contact for Landlord Agreements
If a customer is inquiring about establishing a landlord agreement, verify if the account has at least five active residential properties. If so, warm transfer the call to Commercial at 665-6250 for verification of eligibility or send the request to
bscassist@jea.com
.
See
Commercial
on the Contacts List
for the Customer Advisors which process Landlord Agreements.
FAQs Regarding Landlord Agreements
Who can participate in the Landlord agreement contract?
Residential or commercial entities that have a minimum of 5 premises.
What is the Start fee amount when service is started for the Landlord Agreement contract owner?
While an account has a Landlord agreement, there should not be a start fee billed.
Should CCB or Scripts be used to start service with Landlord Agreement contract?
When starting a Commercial Account that has a Landlord agreement attached, use CCB instead of Scripts to avoid the system from charging a deposit.
Is a Landlord Agreement attached to the Premise or Account?
The premise.
Should a Residential CA start service for a Landlord Agreement owner?
No. The Residential CA should transfer the caller to a Commercial CA.
Can a Residential customer enter into a Landlord Agreement contract?
Yes. Landlord agreements are available to Residential or Commercial entities that have a minimum of 5 residential premises.

General Information About Permits
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
An electrical permit is required for most new, remodel, and maintenance electrical work. The City of Jacksonville requires permits to be pulled for multiple kinds of work.
EXAMPLES
New construction, Renovation, Remodeling, and Electrical upgrades, etc.
Who Issues Permits?
Duval County – Public Works Building Inspection Department.
Atlantic Beach/Baldwin/Orange Park/St. Johns – County Level Governing Building Department.
How Are Permits Obtained?
A licensed electrician or the qualifying homeowner applies for the permit in the COJ Ed Ball building.
The Permit Process Steps
The permit process includes the following steps.
Step 1
Pull the Permit
The electrician, contractor, or customer pulls the permit with the COJ.
Route the Permit to JEA
The permit is routed to JEA.
Step 2
Step 3
Electrician Completes Work
Electrician completes required work, as needed
COJ Inspection
The city inspects the electricians work, it must pass.
Step 4
Step 5
JEA Receives Results
JEA receives the results within 24 hours.
JEA Engineer Inspection
A JEA engineer inspects the electricians work, it must pass.
Step 6
Step 7
(If) Inspection Passes
If the inspection passes, the FINAL flag will be released within 24 hours. Once the final is received the engineer has up to 2 business days to release the permit if no issues are found.
A Meter install requires 24-48 hours
Line work requires up to 10 business days
Once a Permit is pulled the Alerts will remain on the account until the process is complete.
NOTE
You can process the Start Service request for a customer as long as the permit is “active”, “temp final” or “final.”
IMPORTANT
Under no circumstances will you send a manual Field Activity relating to a permit.
What Requires Permits to be Processed by JEA?
Listed below are examples of when JEA is required to process permits.
New Services such as wiring a new home.
Service increases, such as upgrading to a larger electrical panel.
A home where electric service has not been used in 12 months or longer.
Modifications to an existing service such as wiring replacement.
Every repair that requires a contractor to break the seal on the meter can.
How Do We Know When a Permit is Finalized?
Duval County sends updates every three hours to Electric Service Department starting at 8:10am (8:10am, 11am, 2pm, 5pm).
St. Johns County sends an update once a day at 11:00 p.m. to Electric Services Department.
Atlantic Beach, Baldwin, and Orange Park send updates throughout the day to Electric Services Department.
Contacting Electric Services for Permit Related Questions
For questions related to Finals, Engineer Release (that are out of the timeline), Service Off 1 Year flags, and old permits, email
electricservices@jea.com
.
When you email
electricservices@jea.com
, you will receive a response within 24 hours on business days, Monday – Friday 6:00am-6:00pm.
As a reminder, when emailing the Electric Services internal inbox, please follow these guidelines:
Include the customer’s name, address, and the reason for the email.
Please state what information you have reviewed prior to emailing.
REMEMBER:
Advise the customer of additional flags or alerts that may be on the premise, and state in the email that you’ve done so.
New electric services can be started with an active permit and will stay in held status until the permit process is complete.
Other non-permit related flags will need to be reviewed and procedures followed.
If you need immediate assistance, please contact the Assist Line or your manager.

Permit Flags
Estimated reading: 5 minutes
The flags described in this section all require permits to have them cleared.
Unsafe Conditions
When there is an Unsafe Condition Flag on the account, it is the customer’s responsibility to take corrective action. This flag is placed on an account by Revenue Assurance or the field tech that went to the home.
Notice
Cause
Customer Inquiries
Multiple Flags
A door hanger is left at the Premise by JEA advising the customer of the unsafe conditions. Any repairs to the weather head, riser, or the meter can must be made by a licensed electrician. A repair permit is required for electrical work.
According to the severity of the work needed, the field tech can give additional days to the customer to have the repair fixed, or they cut off the service until the repair is completed.
An unsafe condition can range from a minor repair to a major repair. The customer is usually given a 10-day notice to have the repairs completed. If the customer receives a 10-day notice, a permit is required to do the electrical work, and a field tech will go back in 10 days to see if the work has been completed.
If a new resident calls to start service and there is an Unsafe Condition on the premise, the service cannot be started until the flag has been cleared by the permit process. The flag is there for a reason, if they are disconnected for non-pay or want to start service, then they need to fix the issue before the flag can be removed.
If the customer questions the repairs needed:
Check the 10-day notice field activity

If you or the customer needs further clarification, please send an email with the address and details of the request to the C&D mailbox:
cddispatchadmins@jea.com
.
If there is a Service Risk alert on the premise in addition to the Unsafe Conditions Repair Needed flag, the CA can call Revenue Assurance at ext. 6330 for additional information. This means Revenue Assurance left the flag.
NOTE
This number is for internal CA use only. Do not give it out to customers.
Service Off More Than 1 Year
When a premise has not had an active SA for the electric after one year, city code requires the electric be inspected to endure that it is still safe to restart power.
It is possible that a Premise will have a flag for Service Off for 1Year SP, and when a new occupant went into the home they turned on the main breaker and had power. Because there has been no active SA in the last 12 months a permit will need to be pulled and a safety inspection completed before we can start the service.
If you have any questions call the assist line or email Electric Services at
electricservices@jea.com
.
No “Person” Active on the Premise
Abolished Service Point
When you access a Premise and there is no “Person” active on the Premise, it is important to review the Last Customer at Premise information to verify when the last resident was active at the location.
Make sure to check the Master Premise Web and/or the Characteristics Tab on the Service Point to make sure a permit has not been finalized in the last 12 months. If so, start the service and provide the customer the expected time frame if additional work is needed.
There are times when there will not be a Service Off for 1Year Flag on the Premise and there should be. If this happens, inform the customer of the steps needed for an inspection and email the applicable address to Electric Services notifying them that a Service Off for 1 Year Flag is needed.
For Example:
Observe the Alerts
Observe the End Date
It is important that you do not start this service. Instead, email Electric Services at
electricservices@jea.com
to flag the premise.
Abolished Service Points occur because there was an electric service point that is no longer in use.
The Service Point can be an old area light, an old electric meter for a water pump, a garage or unit on the property that had a separate meter at one time.
When the SP is abolished it just means this SP cannot have service. All other electric service points can be started.
IMPORTANT
Always click on the Service Off1Year SP Link in the Dashboard to verify if the Service Off1Year SP flag is on an Abolished Service Point.
Needs Final Inspection or Engineer Release (Electrician Requested Repairs)
At times a customer will hire an electrician to make repairs or updates to their home. When this is done, the electrician will call JEA to stop the power going into the home while he completes his work. This account will not always be flagged by something in CCB.
This requires the permit process to be completed in order for the service to be restored.

City Flags
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
City flags are placed on a premise by the request of the City Of Jacksonville (COJ) and prohibit JEA from starting service at the location until COJ has cleared the flag from our system.
The customer is responsible to have city flags removed from the property.
The Municipal Code Compliance Division of COJ (aka Code Enforcement or Property Safety) enforces property maintenance, safety, and zoning codes, which affect the quality of life in Jacksonville.
These laws address property nuisance, unsafe structure, zoning, residential/commercial minimum building standards, and (private property) junk vehicle violations.
Drug Abatement Reponse Team (DART)
Property Safety
The Jacksonville Drug Abatement Response Team (DART) was established to combat illegal drugs in Jacksonville by supplementing the traditional approach to solving the drug problem.
This program is a partnership between the Jacksonville Sheriff’s Office and the City of Jacksonville to focus on the property where drug activity and/or other illegal activities flourishes.
By working with landlords/property owners, code enforcement strategies are developed and resources are brought to bear to reduce and eliminate crime. Actions include bringing the property up to code, as a way to deter illegal activity on the site.
The contact phone number for the customer to call about a DART Flags is (904) 630-7482.
A DART Flag requires the customer to contact the city. The city number is listed next to the alert so you can provide the caller with that information. Please do not provide any other number for the customer to call.
Property safety flags are placed on accounts because the Municipal Code Compliance Division of COJ (aka Code Enforcement) department has been notified that something is not up to city code at a property.
The following are examples of possible reasons for a property safety flag.
Window screens need replacing
Grass must be cut
Broken windows or doors
Exposed electrical wiring
This alert prohibits certain Field Activities from being dispatched until the characteristic indicates “Released”. It is okay to start service on non-flagged Service Points, such as Water/Sewer when just the Electric is flagged.
The contact phone number for the customer to call about a Property Safety flag is Code Enforcement at (904) 255-7000.
DO NOT
provide any other contact information to the customer under any circumstances.

Premise Validation Considerations
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
When verifying a premise you are looking for anything that will stop you from starting service at that address.
It is vital that this is done so that obstacles are avoided as you proceed through the start of service and the process can run smoothly so the customer receives service as quickly as possible.
The following 6 items must be verified.
If premise has an active Account
Verify the amount owed on that account (Large Balance)
Review Premise Alerts and Flags
Review the premise to verify available Service Points
If the account that is active at the Premise in Collections or Severance
If Service Points are clear to start
Current or Previous Occupant
The following are points you need to consider when viewing Current or Last Residential information.
If there is no active account there, when did the last person stop service and do they have a large write-off balance?
If the last account was cut for non-pay – is the person calling listed on that account?
Is a lease agreement needed?
Is there an NSF3 in the Alerts?
What will be the amount of the Start Options?
If the previous tenant is a MyWay customer.
Has the service been off for more than 1 year?
Has a permit been pulled within the last 12 months?
If there is a field activity within the last 45 days that could affect your start?

Premise Balance vs. Account Payoff
The Premise Balance is the amount due at the specific premise as of the date of the last bill.
The Account Payoff balance is the amount the customer owed as of the last bill date.
When there is a difference in the two amounts that means the account has one of the following:
Multiple Addresses
A Deposit
A Payment Arrangement
Neighbor to Neighbor
MyBudget or Budget Billing
The Account Payoff balance is the balance as of the last bill date. If a customer was stopping service today they would have the Account Payoff balance plus the final bill.

REQ-ON

When a physical on is requested at the meter and/or it was not turned on when it was supposed to be. (always ask the customer to check their breakers INSIDE and OUTSIDE)
Req-On should never be used if:
● A ‘connection-type’ FA pending (m-reconnect, m-on, req-on, etc)
● Account is flagged for unsafe condition, service off over a year, service risk, final inspection/eng release, etc.

Note:
*This FA type will not restore a customer’s service if they are disconnected anywhere other than at the meter (i.e. customer needs line work)*

When there is no MDMS reads. (rare for Electric)

When a customer reports someone illegally interfering with their service/meter.

M-DEAD
Dead Meter
When the reads are showing all zero’s and the premise is occupied.
MMISSING
Meter Missing
When a customer states their meter is missing and JEA did not remove it or they cannot locate their meter to turn it off. (recommend they use their stop and waste valve)
MTRLEAK
Leak at the Meter
When a customer states there is water in their meter box or in their yard. (If after 3:30pm please send a FMS/SOCC ticket.)
RATE CHK
Rate Check
When a customer states they are being charged commercial rates and they are a residential customer. (check the bill first)
REQ-OFF
Customer Request Off
When a physical off is requested at the meter by a customer. (cannot be used to evict a tenant)
REQ-ON
Customer Request On
When a physical on is requested at the meter and it was not turned on when it was supposed to be. (always have the customer check their on/off water valve[stop & waste])
Smart Ck
Water Smart Check Non-Appointment
If an unexplained spike in consumption has occurred and the customer wants us to come and check for leaks and they DO NOT request to be present.
Smart Ck Appt
Water Smart Check with Appointment
If an unexplained spike in consumption has occurred and the customer wants us to come and check for leaks and they DO request to be present.
TAMPER
Tampering
When a customer reports someone illegally interfering with their service/meter.
IMPORTANT
Manual FA’s on permitted addresses should NOT be created when an address has an active permit. This overrides the engineer, inspection process, and can cause a significant safety issue.
IMPORTANT
REQ-ON FA should never be used if:
A ‘connection-type’ FA pending (m-reconnect, m-on, req-on, etc)
Account is flagged for unsafe condition, service off over a year, service risk, final inspection/eng release, etc
There is no active service agreement for the service point

Transferring Services for a Life Support Account
Estimated reading: 1 minute
When a customer moves from one location to another the seal from the old address must be removed and a seal must be installed at the new address. A new certification is required only if the current certification has expired.
During the Transfer process the Script will indicate Life Support Service Point, if selected the life support will be transfer to the new address; see example image below.
A Field Activity will be created at the old (remove life support) and new (install life support) address. The activity type is LIFESPTG (Life Support purple tag Install/Removal).
If the customer no longer requires a medical alert for the new address, the customer should submit the Decertification Form.

Field Related Activities (A)

Field Activities (FAs) are requests or instructions created by, and sent from, the Call Center to a number of dispatch groups to complete specific activities on the customer’s behalf.
FAs are distributed to many different dispatch groups depending on the service that needs to be completed and what type of expertise is needed to do the work.
Dispatch Groups
Each FA is automatically internally routed to the appropriate dispatch group based on the FA type you enter into CCB for the customer.
Click each tab below to review common
Dispatch Groups
.
MDMS
FMS
RCD
RSH
Code:
Meter Data Management System
Definition:
Reading is taken by the system. No person physically goes to the premise to turn on or off; the system simply gets a reading.
Code:
Field Management System
Definition:
Worked by a person in the field.
Code:
Remote Connect/Disconnect
Definition:
Worked by remote connect/disconnect process.
Dispatch Group:
Research
Definition:
Worked by the CART team.
NOTE
This is the only FA that can be scheduled for a date in the past.
Field Activity Status
The current state of an FA can be identified by its
Activity Status
:
Pending –
Request is in process.
Canceled –
Request has been canceled and is no longer on the list to be worked.
Completed –
Request has been worked/completed.

or an
M-cut
for Non-Pay, the Start or Back-to-Back FA dispatch group must match the dispatch group of the last completed
M-Off
or
M-cut
for Non-Pay FA.

Estimated reading: 2 minutes
The process for a reconnection requests depends on if the request is for a non-emergency house repair or tree work, or for an emergency repair reconnection.
Non-Emergency or Tree Work Reconnection Request
Regardless of the day or time, a Reconnection request for a non-emergency house repair or tree work is always an FMSWeb ticket. The request will be completed same-day.
The Customer Advisor will complete the following:
Enter a reconnect request in FMSWeb:
Call Type: EROU – Electric Routine.
Problem Code: CSRQ – Customer Request
Enter the following information in the ticket Remarks box:
Reconnection request, House repair complete
OR
Reconnection request, Tree work complete
Emergency Repair Reconnections During Weekdays Before 3:30PM
In the event a power line was dropped or disconnected to facilitate an emergency electrical repair, the power will need to be reconnected once the work is complete. If the work is complete during normal business hours (Monday through Friday) but no later than 3:30pm, SOCC will be notified by the city once the inspection process is complete;
no FMS ticket is needed by a downtown CA
. A SOCC CA will utilize the RCPI ticket for reconnection.
Emergency Repair Reconnections During Weekdays After 3:30PM and on Weekends
IMPORTANT:
If the customer needs reconnection the request MUST be called in by the licensed electrician:
The Customer Advisor will complete the following:
Enter a reconnect request in FMSWeb:
Call Type: Electric Outage.
Power Status No Power At All/Other Elec Codes
Problem Code: OTHP – Other Priority
Enter the following information in the FMS Comments box:
Request an After Hours Electric Service Cut-On
Permit number or BID Sticker #
Electrician’s Company Name
Electrician’s Contact Name
Electrician’s Contact Number.
REQUIRED:
The electrician must stay on-site until the service is re-energized, even if a BID Sticker was obtained. If the electrician is not on site when JEA arrives, the service will not be energized.

The Service Point (SP) is the term used to designate the meter locations at the Premise (physical location where service is provided, i.e. home, business). The meter is a tool used to measure the amount of consumption of a service at a premise. The data received from the meter is one of the components used to bill customers.
