JEA Flags
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
JEA flags are applied by JEA for various reasons.
Consumption No Contract (V-CNC)
Service Risk SP
Tampering/Theft
Fraud
Premise Note Case
Affidavit
Consumption No Contract (CNC) is system generated Field Activity when a meter indicates usage with no active service agreement.
CNC Letter:
System generated letter based on CNC conditions notifying the occupant of unauthorized use of service.
CNC2:
A second Field Activity that is inserted manually by Revenue Assurance personnel when there is no active service agreement and continuous unauthorized use of service.
Service Risk SP (SVC RISK) is initiated by Revenue Assurance when tampering or theft of service is detected. The characteristic prohibits certain Field Activities to be dispatched until the characteristic indicates “Released.” CAs will not have access to the details of the investigation.
A Service Risk hold means the caller needs to be referred to JEA in person to speak with Revenue Assurance. An appointment should be offered. The caller should not be provided any city phone number to call.
Tampering and Theft are crimes that can lead to arrest, fines and/or imprisonment.
Examples are meter bypass, jumpers in can, extension cords from one property to another, broken locks and seals, upside down meters, and straight pipes.
Fraud occurs when a person makes a written or verbal attempt to avoid payment or obtain services using falsified documents or identification.
Examples are falsified identification, transposed social security number digits, false date of birth, altered spelling of name and use of another party’s name.
Premise Note Case is a collection of information gathered during a Revenue Assurance investigation available in an online file that may be linked to the premise, case, and/or person.
NOTE:
Access to this case is limited to Revenue Assurance personnel.
An affidavit is a formal document detailing the results of JEA’s investigative findings which contains written statements of legal significance.
IMPORTANT
If a city phone number is not listed next to an Alert but you are providing the caller with a number; you are probably referring the customer to the wrong place for the Alert.

Customer / Caller Threats
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
A threat that arises to the level of possible arrest and prosecution requires rather specific language. Examples of this language include statements such as
“I will shoot anyone who comes in my yard”
or
“I’m going to come down there and shoot up the building”
.
Click Here for the Emergency Threat Process
Keeping employees safe is a shared responsibility. It is important that employees are aware of any potentially dangerous situation that they may face when interacting with customers.
Verified Threats
Once a threat is verified, a notification is sent by leadership (GL or Manager) to the Emergency Customer Contact email distribution list.
Specific information regarding the incident is provided in the email notification.
Revenue Assurance and Service Risk reviews the customer’s account to determine if a Service Risk flag is required.
If the premise is flagged, Revenue Assurance or Service Risk will place specific instructions on a customer contact.
Verified Threats With Pending Field Activity
If a threat is verified and the service is scheduled for disconnection or already disconnected for non-pay the account will be flagged with a
Service Risk Hold
.
The customer will be required to come to RA, and pay the full balance of the account in secured funds before the service is reconnected.
NOTE
Payment after a Service Risk Hold must be paid in cash, cashier check, or money order.

Reporting Fraud & ID Theft (RA Investigations Case)
Estimated reading: 5 minutes
Reports of Fraud & ID Theft are sent to Revenue Assurance by creating an Revenue Assurance Investigations Case.
Below are the differences between
Fraud
and
ID Theft
.
Fraud
ID Theft
Fraud
is a misrepresentation made to JEA for the purpose of obtaining or maintaining utility service(s). Customer Advisors must use due diligence in the prevention of fraud.
The following are examples of Fraud.
Submitting a fraudulent lease
Using social security numbers that do not exist
Altering name or DOB
Payment fraud (using an authorized account to pay bills)
Suspicious premise history or Customer Contacts
Previous tenants related to the current tenant with a high-risk account
Customer Advisors can help prevent Fraud by verifying lease agreements (request a full copy of the lease, review names/dates on the lease) and property owners (verify property owner on COJ.net).
ID Theft
is theft committed or attempted using the personal identifying information of another person without that person’s authority.
An example of ID Theft is below.
Using another individuals personally identifying information. i.e., name, social security number, and DOB
Police Report Requirements
For Fraud or ID Theft the customer should be informed to obtain a police report. The customer must file a police report and submit the report
BEFORE
a new account is created and/or service activated.
The report can be emailed to the Customer Advisor taking the call. Please forward the police report to the RA inbox at
revenueassuranceinternal@jea.com
. After the report is received and noted in the case, JEA will proceed with activating a new account while an investigation is being conducted.
It is important to state that there is no guarantee that the customer will not be responsible for the balance owed.
The caller should be advised that JEA works in collaboration with JSO Economic Crime Unit during the investigation. Investigations may take up to 90 days to complete.
If RA deems the claim a civil matter or is unable to confirm ID theft, the customer is responsible for the account balance.
About the Revenue Assurance Investigations Case
Fraud, ID Theft, or Debt Recovery requests should be reported to Revenue Assurance using the Revenue Assurance Investigations case in CCB.
NOTE
Our ID Theft subject matter expert has up to 90 days to confirm or unconfirm if a callers claim is valid. She then sends the customer a letter once she has reached a conclusion.

Tampering
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
Tampering is an attempt to gain unauthorized service without a contract. Altering, damaging, or misuse of the device(s) that register a commodity, or bypassing the device so that actual consumption is not captured.
For reporting theft of services and tampering in the field, create a Tampering Field Activity. For reported tampering that requires
immediate assistance
, please contact Clifford (Darin) Padgett (904) 376-5092 or Richard Dudley (904) 424-9218.
Examples of tampering include the following.
Meter bypass
Jumpers in a meter can
Broken locks and seals
Upside-down meters
Water straight pipes
Theft is the successful completion of tampering where the customer actually gains service without a contract.
This means that they have a meter or meter box and are gaining power through their meter without a contract.
Theft that is the result of tying into a neighbor’s power is NOT the form of theft that JEA investigates. If a customer is claiming that someone has tied into their power supply AFTER the meter, this is a civil matter and should be referred to JSO.
IMPORTANT
If JSO or other Law Enforcement Agencies are on-site and need assistance ASAP, do the following:
Enter a tampering FA and call Revenue Assurance dispatch at ext. 8745.
Advise the dispatcher that Law Enforcement is on site and has reported tampering or needs immediate assistance
DO NOT just create a FA. The FA will not get worked until the following day.

Service Risk Flags
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
Service Risk flags mean there is an active investigation being conducted on a person, account, or premise.
IMPORTANT
Please DO NOT relay any of the information to the customer or caller that you may find in in CCB relating to the investigation.
We do not want to tip the customer off as to what we are investigating. Please explain to the customer that they must come into our office and speak with our Revenue Assurance Department before service can be started.
If there is a SERVICE RISK alert on a premise as well as additional alerts such as SVC OFF > 1 YEAR, please advise the customer ALL the alerts on the premise must be cleared before referring the customer to RA. SERVICE RISK flags will remain on the service point until all actions required are deemed satisfied by the Revenue Assurance or Service Risk groups.
This will ensure that the customer is aware of the additional steps that will be required to activate service in addition to speaking with RA.
The caller needs to be referred to JEA in person to speak with Revenue Assurance. An appointment should be offered. The caller should not be provided any city phone number to call.
Service Risk Flag Removal for Landlords or Property Owners
Property Owner/Managers (when the premise is a rental) are not required to visit the Revenue Assurance department if you can verify ownership through the Property Appraiser’s website on COJ.net.
For these exceptions, please email your request and information to the Revenue Assurance mailbox to remove the flag. Please advise the customer that it can take up to 48 hours before RA will advise if the flag will be removed or if the customer is required to come to RA in person.
DO NOT advise property owners to come into the office. Always offer the alternative, which is to email the request to RA for flag removal.

Distributed Generation Application Process

Customers who purchase a renewable generation system for their home or business and wish to connect it to JEA’s power grid must apply for interconnection under the Distributed Generation Policy.
The requirements and application details are located on JEA.com.
Customers must use the
PowerClerk

Click here for Application Details via JEA.com
Questions about Distributed Generation or the application process can be submitted by Customer Advisors or customers to:
distgen@jea.com
or by phone at (904) 665-4440.
IMPORTANT
Interconnection agreements are required for customers that move into a home with an existing PV or PV + Battery system.
For systems installed after March 31, 2018, customers should use the “Move-In Existing System – DG” application form in PowerClerk.
For systems installed prior to March 31, 2018 that are grandfathered into JEA’s Net-Metering program, customers shoul use the “Move-In Existing System – NM” application form in PowerClerk.
Identifying a Net Metered Grandfathered Address
Net Metering preceded the DG program and is now retired. Net Metering customers are charged the same rate that our non-renewable customers are charged for electricity they buy from JEA when their system is not producing enough energy to meet the demand in their home/office. Customers who generate excess electricity and send it to JEA’s power grid will receive an energy credit that will help offset their overall monthly JEA bill.
All approved systems that passed permit final inspection by March 31, 2018 have been grandfathered under the retired net metering policy for 20 years. If a grandfathered net metering customer sells or rents their home, the new owner or renter will fall under the net metering policy until the grandfathering period has ended.
A premise can be identified to have been grandfathered by reviewing the PV meter’s Service Point Characteristics in CCB:
Grandfathered Value

PowerClerk
, a
Re-Bill (RSH_REBILL)
case may be needed so that we can adjust the previously billed month(‘s). The re-bill will go back to the Service Agreement start date.

Distributed Generation (PV Solar)
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
JEA’s Distributed Generation (DG) Policy reflects the changing energy landscape and growing popularity of solar energy. Under this policy, customers with renewable generation systems are able to buy energy from JEA when their system does not generate enough power to meet their home or business’s needs and sell any electricity they don’t use to JEA. JEA reimburses renewable generation customers at the fuel cost, while offering a new incentive to support the adoption of the next step in private solar: battery storage.
Distributed Generation is also known as Photovoltaic (PV) solar.
Click here for Distributed Generation via JEA.com
Program Highlights:
Customers who send energy to JEA will receive an energy credit at JEA’s fuel rate.
Customers are charged the same rate that JEA’s traditional customers are charged for electricity they buy from JEA.
Any energy credit received in excess of a customer’s bill will accrue through the calendar year. If at the end of the calendar year there is a remaining balance of energy credits, JEA will pay the customer for the amount of energy credits as specified in the Distributed Generation Policy.
The credit dollar amount will be calculated using the fuel rate multiplied by kWh sent to JEA.
Distributed Generation customers may not be enrolled in the JEA MyWay program.

Solar Battery Incentive Program
Estimated reading: 1 minute
Currently, JEA customers with rooftop solar panels must rely on JEA’s electric grid to provide energy when their solar panels don’t produce enough power to meet the home or business’s energy needs. When the solar panels generate more energy than is needed, the excess is sent to JEA.
When excess energy flows from the customer’s solar system back to the JEA grid, JEA values that energy at the fuel rate. With the addition of a battery, customers can store the excess energy generated by their solar system and draw on it as needed – maintaining the full retail value of that energy and reducing their need to receive electricity from the grid.
A new Battery Incentive Program is currently being designed for Fiscal Year 2023.

JEA SolarSmart (B)
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
IMPORTANT
SolarSmart calls should be handled by Full Service Customer Advisors.
JEA SolarSmart provides customers the opportunity to participate in solar energy. The program is for customers who want to invest in cleaner solar energy but do not have their own solar panels.
JEA offers SolarSmart energy “at cost”, as it does for the fuel used to generate electricity.
Customers can choose to receive from 1% up to 100% of their energy from JEA SolarSmart.
JEA offers solar energy at cost. The cost for JEA SolarSmart is $0.075 per kWh, less the Fuel Cost (
variable rate
). This results in a premium for the customer.
A customer with an average usage of 1,000 kWh who decides to participate at 1% will pay about $0.40 extra on their monthly bill; at 10% they will pay about $4 more per bill; 50% enrollment in JEA Solar Smart will increase their bill by about $20.
SolarSmart Benefits
Customer Benefits
JEA/Community Benefits
Allows customer participation in renewable energy at a level of the customer’s choice.
Customers can participate in solar energy generation without the requirement of having to purchase and install expensive equipment.
Allows customer participation in renewable energy even when logistical circumstances would ordinarily prevent participation, such as: rental property, condominiums, tree canopy, lack of direct sunshine, etc.
Businesses can demonstrate their support for renewable energy, and their participation in JEA SolarSmart, by showing their commitment for improving the environment to their customers and stakeholders.
JEA will provide a certificate and window decal for participating customers to display.
Demonstrates JEA’s commitment to preserving and protecting the environment
Provides a program of participation for customers who are highly favorable of environmental protection and preservation.
Research shows that many JEA customers have a high-level of passion for a healthy environment and are willing to invest at a premium to ensure that purposeful environmental practices are in-place, and are being used effectively.
This program, through customer participation, helps JEA to recover part of its investment in solar energy production.
Participating customers feel a part of “something good”.

1099-Misc Tax Form for Solar PV Credits
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
Solar PV customers “sell” their PV credits back to JEA. If they generate $600 or more in PV credits in a calendar year, JEA will issue the customer a 1099-MISC for the tax year by 01/31.
Form 1099-MISC is intended to report the income of taxpayers who are not employees, such as independent contractors, freelancers, sole-proprietors, and self-employed individuals.
The form is also used to report non-employee compensation such as rents, prizes, awards, healthcare payments, and payments to an attorney.
The credit generated by a customers PV system is therefore considered taxable income if the amount is $600 or more for the calendar year.
A grandfathered Net Metering customer is much more likely to be eligible for a 1099-MISC than a Distributed Generation customer because of the rate difference. If a customer is inquiring on the likelihood of receiving a 1099-MISC, use the chapter above titled Customer Application Process (Grandfathered Net Metering Program) to identify if a customer’s PV system is grandfathered or not. You also may review a sample of the customer’s bills (or previous tenants bills) to determine the average PV credit.
Customer Advisors can email the JEA tax department (
jeataxdepartment@jea.com
) to confirm if the customer generated $600 or more in credits for the calendar year.

Returning Customer
Estimated reading: 5 minutes
A returning customer is a customer who had previous service with JEA and is now choosing to reactivate their account.
A customer should have only one account and when returning, their old account should be used, in most circumstances.
When a customer returns to JEA to reactivate their account, the CA will need to verify and update the person and account information. The following information should be verified when updating a returning customer’s account:
DOB
Social Security Number
Employer
Spouse and/or Authorized User with DOB and Full SSN
Email Address
Phone Number/s
Update/Delete old Mailing Address
IMPORTANT
If a customer cannot verify their password, KIQ can be used to verify their identity. Once the caller’s identity has been verified, the password may be removed or updated. If the caller’s identity is not verified, they must come in with two forms of ID to update or change the password on the account.
Updating Person/Account Information
When a customer provides information that is not consistent with the existing account information, our first step should be to clarify our understanding of what we heard.
In the event the name, date of birth, or the last four of their social security number are different from what is recorded on the account, please take the following actions to resolve any discrepancies:
Verify Name
Verify DOB
Verify SSN
Verify Account Info
AutoPay
If the request is a minor correction in spelling, no verification or documentation is required. Simply correct the spelling in regular CCB. (Smith – Smyth). Name changes should never be made through the script.
If the request is a new last name, or legal name change, verification and/or documentation is required.
If the Date of Birth is incorrect or missing, call the Assist Line. Provide the account # and the customers full SSN to the assist line representative. The Assist line representative will use other tools available to verify that the information the customer is providing is correct.
If the DOB is verified by the assist and it is incorrect in the system …
You may change the DOB to the correct date and complete the customer’s request.
If the new information was not verified …
Contact Revenue Assurance at extension 6330 for assistance with verifying the new information.
If the Assist Line is not available …
Complete the above steps with a manager.
The process for updating a customer’s Social Security Numbers (SSN) requires the creation of a case before the information is updated on the account.
The Revenue Assurance team is the only group permitted by policy to update customers’ SSN in JEA’s Customer Billing System
. All SSN updates will adhere to a dual-control method which requires one person to create a case and a second to verify the information and update the account. The purpose of this change is to mitigate risk and assure consistent processes are followed.
Always update the Customer Characteristics which are the date of birth, employer, spouse, and authorized users.
Many times, with the exception of the date of birth, characteristics change, therefore you should, always verify the characteristics listed are still current.
Examples:
“Are you still employed with XYZ?”
“Would you still like to have XTZ listed on the account”?
If no characteristics are listed on the account, ask the customer to provide the required characteristics.
The system will create a
Customer Contact
for any changes that you make.
When a customer is Returning to JEA to start service and AutoPay was previously active on the account, the system will automatically restart AutoPay. It is important to verify with the customer that he/she would like the account to remain on Auto Pay.
If the customer no longer wants AutoPay on the account, a case must be submitted to cancel it or the customer may cancel via JEA.com.
Searching for a Returning Customer
Using the Start Process Script, search for the customer by Name and SSN. If a customer has multiple accounts they will appear on the
Customer Validation Page
.
The example below shows why you search by both Name and SSN. If there are multiple accounts under the same SSN it will populate when you search for your customer.
Results searching by name:
Click the image to enlarge.
Results searching by SSN:
Click the image to enlarge.
When you click on one of the accounts found, all accounts matching that SSN will populate for you to review if necessary:
Click the image to enlarge.
Because the script always searches for matching SSN, you will find different names associated with the last four of the SSN.
In regular CC&B many accounts were set up with zeros (000-00-1966) or nines (999-99-1966) for the first five numbers of their SSN. Therefore, you may find accounts that are not really associated to your account at all, but the last four of their SSN match.
If this happens, please contact the Assist Line to verify if the entire SSN is the same or if it is because of zero’s and/or nine’s. If it is because of the zero’s or nine’s, and after verifying your customers correct SSN, send a SSN Case to CART to update your customer’s SSN if that is the one that is incorrect. If it looks like fraud, follow the suspected fraud rules.

Transfer Service (A)
Estimated reading: 1 minute
When a customer has current active service and they are moving to another location within JEA’s service area they are requesting a transfer of service. Transferring service involves no interruption of service.
In order to transfer, a customer must provide you with the stop date for the current premise and the start date for the new premise during the same call.
The stop and start date can overlap for up to 30 days. If the customer is requesting both services active for greater than 30 days see the additional service process.
When transferring service the
Transfer
button MUST be selected for the transfer to be processed correctly. Failing to do so may cause a new deposit or the incorrect deposit amount to be billed to the customer.
IMPORTANT
If the transfer is not processed until the end of the script, no part of the start or stop will be completed.

Installation Requirements for Overhead Lights
To have an area light installed for a customer with overhead wiring:
The customer must have existing JEA owned overhead fed utility pole that are accessible by a JEA bucket truck.
If a 120V source is not available on the pole, JEA will run up to 500 ft of secondary at no cost. (Over 500 ft the customer will be billed the difference on the estimate generated by the engineer.
A 3 year service agreement is required.
Installation Requirements for Underground Lights
To have an area light installed a customer with underground wiring:
The post-top fixtures must already be located within the Right-of-Way and accessible by a JEA bucket truck. (If the requested location of the pole is not adjacent to an existing transformer, the customer must install a conduit prior to installation).
The customer will be billed a flat CIAC charge of $341.00 for each fixture prior to installation
A 3 year service agreement is required.

Returning Customer – Write-Offs / 4 Year Rule
Estimated reading: 4 minutes
“Write-offs” occur if an account is closed and the entire total balance due is not received. When a Write-off occurs the customer’s ICS is reduced by 750 points.
We will actively attempt to collect any outstanding debt for up to four years from the date the service was stopped. Following this period, we may inform the returning customer of the outstanding amount but cannot demand payment.
A prior write-off is one of the components reviewed to determine the deposit requirement.
Write-Off Amount Less Than 4 Years Old
The customer must pay a deposit and the write-off amount to start service.
OR
The customer must pay ½ of the deposit and ½ of the write-off amount.
The rest of the deposit is due in-full with the first bill. The remaining ½ write-off amount will be on the customer’s first bill. If they cannot pay the other half of the write-off by the due date on the bill, a PP or PA may be worked with the customer at JEA’s discretion. The customer must contact JEA and request the additional assistance.
NOTE
When you verify the Premise the system will automatically populate the Deposit amount that the customer will need to pay.

If they agree, you will run a Credit Check to determine the deposit requirement.
If you check the “Customer will not pay balance”, the system will automatically create a new account, then it will give you the wording to read to the customer asking to run an Identity Check leaving the credit score at 1000 (after you update all the customer’s information).
You will need to enter the SSN on the Customer Entry page to create the new account.
The system will also enter a contact on both accounts with the other account number as well as an Alert not to use the old account.

There are unique situations where a customer may not provide or have not been issued the standard forms of acceptable identification. To assist those individuals, please review the scenarios below for possible resolution.
If you are not sure how to handle the situation, reach out to the assist line.
IMPORTANT
Please be aware that in any instance where a Social Security card is not provided or cannot be verified, a Deposit will be assessed. The Deposit is not eligible for refund while the account is active.
Customer refuses/unable to provide SSN for starting service.
The customer will need to present an acceptable form of ID before the service will be activated. A deposit will be assessed that is not eligible for refund while the account is active.
Non-US Citizen applying for service that doesn’t have a SSN, but may have a passport with the I-551 Temporary US Immigration Stamp. Experian advises that two forms of ID are required.
If the customer provided a SSN when applying for service, then the customer must provide a SS card. If not, then one form of primary ID will be acceptable. A deposit will be assessed that is not eligible for refund while the account is active.
Non-US Citizen has active services with JEA and their account has an invalid / expired passport.
The customer will need to present an acceptable form of ID to update the account. If they do not have acceptable ID, a deposit will be assessed that is not eligible for refund while the account is active.
Non-US Citizen that previously had service with JEA (non-active account) and the account was started with only a passport that has no I-551 Temporary US Immigration Stamp, or Visa.
Since the account is not active, the customer will need to reapply for service as a returning customer. An acceptable form of ID must be presented to reactivate the service. If unable to validate the SSN listed on the account or if a SSN is not provided, a deposit will be assessed that is not eligible for refund while the account is active.
World Relief (refugees) who only have I-94, or Alien ID number.
Customers that are being assisted by World Relief will have a deposit assessed that is not eligible for refund while the account is active.

IMPORTANT
Start/Stop team: Do not process this transfer request; transfer the call to Full Service.

Starting Additional Service
Estimated reading: 7 minutes
Starting Additional Service for a customer is the process of starting another Premise or SA’s, in addition to the one(s) already active on their account.
In most circumstances, a customer may have only one account number, but have multiple premises on the account.
There are several important factors to consider when adding additional service:
MyBudget
Mailing Address
Past Due Balance
Deposit
Bill Cycle
When a customer is actively enrolled in MyBudget, the MyBudget plan must be canceled before the additional service can be added.
The customer can enroll in MyBudget again after all addresses have been active for at least 6 months.
IMPORTANT
Start/Stop Team ONLY: DO NOT process this request; transfer the call to the Billing/Full Service department at extension 4424.
When a customer is requesting additional service, the mailing address needs to be updated.
If the customer has their bill going to the premise as the mailing source, the premise will now be the newest address they started. Enter a checkmark in the
Mailing Address Same as Premise
box and once the new service is activated the mailing address will update to the new Premise.
If the customer wants the bill to be mailed to the original address or an address other than the new premise, you must uncheck the
Mailing Address Same as Premise
box and enter the address in the appropriate fields after verifying the address in USPS. Make sure to check the
Protect Bill Cycle
box so the bill will print at the same time.
When a customer is adding additional service, all past due amounts must be covered.
They can either pay the past due amount or, if they qualify, you may create a Pay Plan for the customer before you add additional service.
If the customer has an active deposit or an ICS of 800 or below an additional deposit amount must be added to the current active deposit. This requires the deposit amount for both premises to be reviewed and added together.
For example:
Existing Deposit Amount: $200
New Premise Amount: $350
The
Deposit SA
box must be checked when starting the additional service. The system will automatically add the new deposit amount onto the active deposit.
The required deposit increase for additional service will be $350.00. The deposit amount in the script will say $550, which is the total of both addresses. The account will only be billed for the increase amount.
If the customer wants the bill to go to the new premise leave the protect bill cycle unchecked.
If they want the bill to stay at the original address, then enter a checkmark in the “Protect Bill Cycle” box. We assume that if the customer wants the bill to stay at the original address they want the bill to print at the original time.
The only time you need to speak with the customer about the bill cycle is if they want to use the new address as their mailing address. Let the customer know the bill print date will change to the new cycle print date if different from what they have now.
IMPORTANT
You DO NOT ever change a Bill Cycle. You only
Protect
or
Unprotect
Bill Cycles.

CNC and Backdating Service Start
Estimated reading: 7 minutes
Backdating is used to bill a customer for service used in the past. In the case of starting service,
Alerts
will show that there is a
CNC
or you may see a
Pending FA
.
CNC
and a
Virtual Consumption No Contract (VCNC)
occur when a service is being used without the appropriate Service Agreements. This can happen for many reasons. The main reason is when a customer calls to stop service, it is stopped via the dispatch group MDMS.
MDMS is simply a reading completed by the system. When the reading is taken and the service agreement is stopped; the system expects the usage to stop as well.
When the usage is still being consumed by a refrigerator or even an A/C left on, the system will issue a
CNC
Field Activity to FMS to have the service physically turned off at the premise.
The type of
CNC
and the Field Activity status will determine if a backdate is considered or if Revenue Assurance needs to be involved.
CNC or VCNC
CNC2 – Pending FA
CNC2 – Completed FA
CNC Service Risk – Pending FA
CNC Service Risk – Completed FA
DO NOT refer the customer to Revenue Assurance. Use the tools provided to verify if a Backdate should be considered.
DO NOT refer the customer to the downtown office. There is an ongoing investigation by Revenue Assurance which may or may not result in tampering/fraud.
Once you determine that a Backdate should be considered, you may need to inform the Assist Line to remove the flag on the account.
The customer should be referred to Revenue Assurance prior to the start of service.
The exceptions to this are apartment complexes with landlord agreements and landlords with verified proof of ownership.
New applicants should only be told that a problem exists. We need to determine if Revenue Assurance can assist. Call Revenue Assurance at extension 6330.
NOTE
Information in a CNC FA should not be given out to the customer.
Call the Assist Line or a Manager because they can cancel the alert and the FA, and then you will follow the procedure to enter the request to start service for the customer as usual. There is no need to notify/contact Revenue Assurance.
The customer should be referred to Revenue Assurance prior to the start of service.
Determine to Backdate or Not Backdate
Determining if a Backdate should be considered starts with the
Premise Validation
page.
Water CNC
Electric Pole Disconect
Electric CNC
Last Customer at Premise
Field Activities
Using the example image above, pretend today’s date is 6/6/2017. Notice the End Date for the
Last Customer
at Premise
was 05/30/2017. Because there is a completed CNC after 5/30/2017, a new customer would need to be asked to be backdated
if there has been consumption used
after the end date.
IMPORTANT
If they are backdated, a Case and a REQ-ON FA must be created, as well the cancelation of the Pending Pole Disconnect and Water CNC. The Script will do these for you, but CAs must still
verify
that they are created/canceled.
To determine if there has been consumption since the last customer’s end date, use the Meter Data Management System (MDMS). MDMS provides JEA with daily readings for Electric, Water, and Irrigation meters. Most readings are retrieved from the meters just before midnight.
Use the following steps to access MDMS to retrieve the meter reads:
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
Step 4
Step 5
Step 6
From the
Script,
click on the
Go to MDMS
link in the left Dashboard.
Select the radial button next to
Address
and enter the address for the premise with the CNC in question, click search.
Select the Service Point you want to view consumption for.
The “lightning bolt” is Electric
The “Water drop” is Water or Irrigation
The following is a list of fields in MDMS that will help you determine usage:
MDMS Electric Meter Example
Read Date
Badge
Bill Read
Usage
Read Origin
MDMS Water Meter Example
Read Date
Badge
Bill Read
Usage
Read Origin
Review the
Usage
column since the previous customer’s
End Date.
If MDMS is showing zero (0) usage for the last 7 days or more …
A Backdate is not needed. Start service as of they day they request.
If MDMS is showing 2-3 kWh usage per day since the last customer’s End Date …
A Backdate is not needed. Start service as of they day they request.
If MDMS is showing the usage dropped after the last customer’s End Date, but then increased …
A Backdate should be requested from the customer.
If MDMS is showing the usage never changed from the last customer’s End Date ..
A Backdate should be requested from the customer.
If you determined that there was usage that qualifies for the account to be Backdated, ask the caller to validate when they moved in (i.e., provide a lease). In most cases, the customer will agree to a Backdate.
After talking about the previous unpaid consumption, if the customer states they did not use it, you will start the service for their requested date (i.e., today) without a lease.
Chapter Summary
Summary
Review the Last Customer at Premise:
Look for the End Date
Review MDMS to look at the usage
Ask the customer when they actually moved into the address:
Backdate when the customer states that they moved into the premise on a date in the past.
If the customer states that they moved in on the day (the same day they are contacting JEA), then start the service for the current date.

Returning Customer – Write-Off $25 or Less
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
If a returning customer has a write-off balance that is $25 or less and they will be paying the balance, you may restore the credit,
if it brings the ICS back to above 700.
Restoring the ICS to above 700 allows you to run a credit check to determine the deposit requirement.
The system will automatically restore the ICS once you enter a checkmark in the “Restore Credit” box on the Customer Validation Page. (If you forget to check these two boxes a case will need to be created in CC&B to restore the ICS).
Notice the
Next Activities
shows you what will be done for both scenarios.
NOTE:
Offer that the customer pays the balance while on the phone, using JEA.com or their mobile device.
Otherwise, the customer will need to submit the payment and call back.
IMPORTANT
Always review the account before restoring the credit to confirm the original write-off amount was not more than $25.
You can see the date the customer stopped service and the date of the last payment. If the payment was made after the stop date – the balance might have been brought down to $25.00 or less – meaning the final bill was not originally $25.00 or less and the account does not qualify to have the ICS restored.
The example below is a true $25.00 or less final bill. They final billed on 7/2/2015 and the last payment was before that date on 6/7/2015 meaning the final bill was $4.13.

Neighbor to Neighbor Donation
Estimated reading: 3 minutes
Founded in 1987, JEA’s Neighbor to Neighbor Fund is a way for customers and employees to provide temporary assistance to customers unable to pay their utility bill during a financial crisis. The Neighbor to Neighbor Fund helps elderly, disabled, and those less fortunate keep the lights on and water running.
Every dollar counts. Each year, over 550 families are able to maintain utility services as a result of Neighbor to Neighbor.
Each customer contribution goes directly to people in need. No expenses are deducted by JEA or the United Way.
Every donation is tax-deductible.

Returning Customer – Customer Claims ID Theft
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
When the customer states that they have been a victim of Identity Theft, a police report must be filed to begin the JEA process. The information below will allow service to be started for the customer prior to the balance being paid.
Filing a Police Report
Notifying JEA
Investigation
A Write-off amount that is more than four years old, and more than $25.00, and the customer claims identity theft is handled by our Revenue Assurance department.
Once the customer’s identity is verified, you may share any account information with the customer. The information can be used when the customer is filing the police report.
Once the police report is filed the customer has to bring a copy of the report to the JEA Customer Solutions Center (CSC). The CA will create a New Account, forward the information to Revenue Assurance, and create a case to mirror the credit score if less than 1000.
Upon receipt, the CSC will scan the police report and send via e-mail to the Revenue Assurance Mailbox, copying Tonya Waters and DeDe Lambert.
Revenue Assurance will investigate and determine the disposition of the write-off amount within ninety (90) days.
Once the new account has been created, the customer is responsible for any deposit required on the new premise before starting service. Please create detailed customer contacts on both the new and old account, explaining the situation.
Let the customer know six (6) months after JEA’s investigation proves Identity Theft, JEA will run a Credit Check on the customer. If the credit check results cause the deposit to be waived, we will credit back the deposit to their account. If not waived, the deposit will stay on the account.
If the investigation by Revenue Assurance deems the customer is responsible for the collection balance then create a
Recovery Case
to have the write-off balance transferred to the new account.

Temporary (Short-Term) Service
Estimated reading: 2 minutes
Temporary service (temp service or short-term service agreement) allows the customer to avoid paying the full deposit. Sometimes a customer just needs to show a house or clean in between tenants.
IMPORTANT
If the customer already has an account with JEA, and a Deposit is not required, the customer should start services and call back the business-day before they wish to stop services.
The start and stop requests must be created concurrently.
If this option for service is elected, you will need to transfer the customer to a Full Service Representative.
If the caller has an active account with a credit score above 700 and no deposit on hand …
Then no deposit is needed, no matter how long they want the service active. You can start the services, advise the customer to call back the business-day before they wish to stop services.
If the caller has an active account with a credit score 700 or below or has an active deposit on hand …
A start and stop must created concurrently. You must transfer the customer to Full Service to schedule the Temporary Service.
1 to 15 Days: A deposit payment is not required; transfer the caller to Full Service.
16 to 30 Days: A deposit payment of $60 per SP is required; transfer the caller to Full Service.
The full 30-days can be scheduled to Start and Stop within the same call.
If a new account is created a credit check must be run. If the deposit is waived …
Then no deposit is needed, no matter how long they want the service active. You can start the services, advise the customer to call back the business-day before they wish to stop services.
If a new account is created a credit check must be run. If the deposit is not waived …
A start and stop must created concurrently. You must transfer the customer to Full Service to schedule the Temporary Service.
1 to 15 Days: A deposit payment is not required; transfer the caller to Full Service.
16 to 30 Days: A deposit payment of $60 per SP is required; transfer the caller to Full Service.
The full 30-days can be scheduled to Start and Stop within the same call.

Start Option / Connection Fees (A)
Estimated reading: 1 minute
A Start Option (start fee / connection fee) is a charge on the initial bill for each new Service Agreement (SA) started.
Start Options are charged to all Service Points (SP’s) that are started in CCB.
Since water and sewer use only one meter, there will only be one service point, therefore one start option.
Connection Fees
The following is a breakdown of the Start Option Fees we use.
Prescheduled $10
Same Day AM $10
Same Day PM $25
Irrigation Restart $125
No Charge
Orders placed for future start date(‘s)
Orders placed before noon, same day start
Orders placed between 12-3, same day start
Irrigation/Reclaim water restarted for the same customer within a 6 month period.
Used ONLY for:
Landlord Agreements
JEA Errors
NOTES
After 3:00 PM, no starts will be completed same day.
The start of service can be requested Monday through Friday – Excluding Holidays. We do not start service on weekends.
Service can be scheduled to start up to 30 days from the request date.

MyWay Eligibility (A)
Estimated reading: 5 minutes
JEA MyWay is a prepaid utility program which allows customers to control the frequency and amount of their payments based on their usage habits.
This program is designed to assist customers with obtaining and managing their utility services.
This program is beneficial for customers who:
Are required to pay a large deposit.
Need assistance with managing high bills.
Are looking for a more intuitive, self-service type alternative.
The Benefits of JEA MyWay
Customers of JEA MyWay will receive the following benefits:
Freedom from deposits and late fees.
No electric reconnection fees (only water and irrigation have reconnect fees).
Access to consumption information 24/7.
Alert notifications when an account balance becomes low, is pending disconnection, or is disconnected.
Ability to defer a portion of the utility payment to outstanding balances.
New JEA MyWay customers will receive a
Welcome Packet
by email when starting new service. An example of the MyWay welcome email is below:
Click the image to enlarge.
JEA MyWay Eligibility Criteria
A customer must meet certain criteria in order to be eligible for JEA MyWay.
The criteria to meet includes requirements for:
Account
Premise
Meters
Prior to offering the JEA MyWay service to the customer, the following must be reviewed to determine if the account may be eligible:
Account
Premise
Water Meter
Electric Meter/Service
In order to take down the lines an remove the meter you must verify if the service is still active. If the Electric service point that the caller wants removed it is still active you must talk to the account holder and stop the service.
In order to be eligible for JEA MyWay the account must:
be Residential
not have a Medical Alert or Life Support Flag
not be a Commercial Account for Commercial Premise
have at least one method of Contact Information (phone, email)
have only one premise per account
have no Account Alerts such as Service Risk or Fraud
Will no longer be eligible for Monthly Billing Programs or Plans such as:
Pay Plans
Pay Arrangements
MyBudget
Residential Budget
AutoPay
eBill
The system will automatically stop the Billing Programs such as
Pay Plans, Pay Arrangements and MyBudget
upon converting to MyWay.
SPECIAL CIRCUMSTANCES
If a customer has a voucher, they may want to wait until the voucher is paid so they won’t lose the voucher before they start MyWay. You may also suggest that they call their agency to see if they would be willing to change the voucher to a Pre-Paid voucher.
If the account is in Collections or Severance, a Pay Plan must be created to address the severance amount temporarily to cancel the m-cut for non-pay Field Activity.
In order to be eligible for JEA MyWay the premise must:
have electric service
have no Water only service
have no Water/Sewer only service
have no Electric/Sewer only service
I
n order to be eligible for JEA MyWay the water meter must:
be on Network Meter Reading (NMR) route
Existing Customers
: have Automated Meter Read (AMR); reads showing in Meter Data Management System (MDMS) for the last five consecutive days. Also, read in gallons (10, 50, 100). If the Existing customer does NOT meet this criteria, use the Script to create a Damanged Meter FA. The customer can convert after the FA is completed by the Field and they have Billed.
Note:
This does not apply to New customers. Even if reads are EXT or 1000 gallons, service can be started; the script will create a Damanged Meter FA.
New and Existing Customers
: not have a CCF meter. If they have a CCF meter, a Damaged Meter FA must be created, completed by the Field, and they must Bill.
In order to be eligible for JEA My Way the electric service must:
be on Network Meter Reading (NMR) route. If it doesn’t have a 2-way meter, the Script will request a 2-way exchange meter Field Activity (FA).
have electric service with the following:
Amps-30
Class-200
Form-2s or 12s
Voltage-240
If the numbers are less than the above it is also good to start. It just cannot be higher.
Must NOT be a Commercial service point
Must NOT be 3-Phase, see images (below)
Example of a 3 Phase Electric Meter:
3 Phase Meter
Life Support Customers
Customers classified as Life Support cannot switch to MyWay unless they FIRST complete the Medically Essential Electric Service Decertification form.
To remove the account from a Medically Essential (Life Support) status, the customer and/or patient/guardian may either:
Complete the Medically Essential Electric Service Decertification form.
Part C of the form should be completed and mailed to:
JEA Customer Care Advocacy and Resolution Team
225 N. Pearl Street, FL 3
Jacksonville, FL 32202
After 24 months from the original designation, the Life Support status will expire. The account and premise will no longer be restricted from MyWay unless a new Medically Essential Electric Certification form is submitted.

Take Down Lines Pull Meter (TDLPM) Case
Estimated reading: 4 minutes
At times a caller will request that JEA remove the lines from their home and remove the meter. The process is called a Take Down Lines and Pull the Meter or TDLPM.
TDLPM’s are normally requested for the demolition of an existing home, or the removal of an old trailer.
IMPORTANT
For a line-drop only (home repair, tree trim, etc.), you must submit an FMS ticket, not a TDLPM case.
Active Service
Meter Already Removed
Meter Number
In order to take down the lines an remove the meter you must verify if the service is still active. If the Electric service point that the caller wants removed it is still active you must talk to the account holder and stop the service.
The TDLPM can be requested the next business day after the service is scheduled to stop.
TDPLM’s require a 24 hour notice. We cannot do same day requests.
Make sure to check the premise tree when a caller is requesting a TDLPM. If there is no meter at the location you can create a
TDL-ONLY
Field Activity. Once the meter has been removed the process is no longer a TDLPM.
In order to request a TDLPM the caller must provide you with the meter number they want removed. You cannot read the meter number in CC&B to the customer, the reason that we request the meter number from the customer is to ensure we are removing the correct meter from the location.
Taking Down TPFRs
Most (Temporary Pole Flat Rate) TPFR’s are not listed as addresses in CCB prior to 8/27/19; there is no monthly bill for this service type. If the TPFR was created prior to 8/27/19 and cannot be located in FMS, a non-Connected FMS ticket should be created by the Assist Line to take down the line from the Temp Pole.
TPFR’s created as of or after 8/27/19 can be viewed in CCB, FMS, and Master Premise Web and should be handled in CCB; if only taking down a line from a TPFR, create a
TDL-ONLY
Field Activity.
TPFRs or metered poles (ex: TP01) do not belong to JEA. The pole may be owned by the electrician or the builder.
Whoever owns the pole is responsible for removing it after it has been de-energized.
Temp Pole Assistance
Residential Customer Advisors should transfer customers to the BSC / Commercial department for assistance with temp pole service points including the starting or stopping of TPFR or TSRM temp poles.

If unable to verify Permit or Ownership, the customer is responsible for supplying the documentation. Documents can be faxed to CART.

Starting Service for a New Customer
Estimated reading: 10 minutes
Starting Service for a new customer is the process of initiating all Service Agreements the customer needs to receive service from JEA.
A customer can start service three ways:
Over the phone by calling (904) 665-6000
Online at
https://www.jea.com/
In-person at the JEA Customer Solutions Center (CSC)
A
Service Agreement
is a contract between JEA and the customer defining the services that will be provided and billed by JEA.
A customer may have several Service Agreements.
Commodity Service Agreements (Premise Based)
Non-Commodity Service Agreements
(Account Based)
SA Types:
Electric
Water
Irrigation/Reclaimed Water
Multi-Family Water
Area Light
Photovoltaic (PV) Solar Panels
NOTES
Irrigation
is potable water used to water the lawn.
Reclaimed
is high treated waste water used to water the lawn.
Photovoltaic service points require additional paperwork to be filled out and sent to JEA.
SA Types:
Over Payment
Deposit
Write-Off
Neighbor-to-Neighbor (NTN)
Prosperity Fund
Payment Arrangement
